petition.title: Defence Service Home Loans Scheme
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That changes to the Defence Service Home Loans Scheme will have the effect of reducing existing benefits to Servicemen and Veterans and are therefore to be condemned.
2. That the results of a review of the scheme should be published by the Government.

3. That the Scheme should be amended to increase the amount of the loan, speed up the processing of loans, and widen the eligibility to include all Servicemen by way of recognition of their service to Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Smoke Free Air Travel
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned:
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Australia Card Legislation
petition.para: To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

petition.title: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

2. That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

3. That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
4. That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That we believe there to be cheaper, more efficient means of combating social security and taxation fraud than those contained in the Australia Card Bill. Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Consider these alternatives and reject any legislation which seeks to implement the intrusive and expensive Australia Card proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Australia Card Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
1. We reject in principle the need for a national I.D. card on the basis that it will be a gross violation of individual liberty.
2. We reject the motion that the government can claim a mandate for the proposed legislation and state categorically it does not reflect our will.
3. We believe that, as with the proposed Bill of Rights legislation, the government's methods and arguments in promoting this legislation have been under-handed and undemocratic.

4. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and that its implementation will result in further attacks on individual freedom and responsibility, the family and the Church and that the real intent is the promotion of a powerful secular humanist ``big brother'' government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should together with the House of Representatives take action to reject this proposed legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Australia Card Legislation
petition.para: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable or responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Numbering System.

petition.title: Australia Broadcasting Corporation: Jack High Bowling Tournament
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation not to televise the Jack High Bowling Tournament in 1988 is cause for distress to the 500,000 bowlers and many non bowlers who, for years, have enjoyed this interesting programme for television.

2. The unilateral decision was taken after verbal assurances had been given that the 1988 event would be televised. This action is deplored and we feel should be reversed by the parliament in the interest of your many constituents.

petition.title: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Council, thereby reversing the decision of the Health Insurance Commission to close the agency on March 31, 1988. petition.title: Port Pirie Education Centre, South Australia: Restoration of Funding
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. has for twelve years fulfilled a wide range of educational needs among underprivileged and isolated rural people in the upper north of South Australia:
that the Federal Government's withdrawal of base grant funding will in effect cause the Centre to close at the end of 1987:

that Federal Government managerial incompetence is evident in deciding to cause the closure of the Centre at the same time as approving a Community Employment Program grant of approximately $50,000 to upgrade the Centre's grounds.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Federal Government will restore base grant funding for 1988 and beyond to ensure that the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. can continue to provide its wide range of educational services to the people of the upper north of South Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Supporting Parent's Benefits
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows that recent changes and further planned changes to Social Security Benefits payments will unduly prejudice and unfairly discriminate against certain members of the Australian community least able to cope with further financial loss.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:

(i) restore the Supporting Parent's Benefit and the Widow's A Pension to parents whose youngest child is both aged between 16 and 24 and is a full-time student: and restore the Class B Widow's Pension.
And
(ii) pay the full Family Allowance Supplement to all Australian Social Security Beneficiaries with dependent children in addition to their existing entitlements.
And
(iii) that student allowances and conditions at least equivalent to those available before the changes in October, 1986, be re-introduced for those sole parents who desire to further their education.

Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 30 April 1987 the Committee considered the Declaration of Pharmaceutical Benefits made on 18 March 1987 under section 85 of the National Health Act 1953. Your expert advice on an aspect of the Declaration would be welcomed by the Committee.

The Declaration replaces Schedules of drugs formerly set out in the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations. Schedule 1 to the Declaration contains provisions that permit certain drugs to be ``pharmaceutical benefits'' only with the authority of the Secretary of your Department. See, for example, ``Alfare'' on page 2 of the Declaration and several other examples. A refusal by the Secretary to exercise his or her discretion and issue an appropriate written authority means that the drugs in question are not available at reduced costs as pharmaceutical benefits for the treatment of particular patients suffering from particular illnesses.

The Committee readily admits that the use of certain drugs as pharmaceutical benefits for the treatment of certain illnesses must, as a matter of medical safety and public policy, be subject to careful controls. Nevertheless, administrative refusals to permit the use of certain drugs at reduced cost by persons who are sometimes in vulnerable circumstances can potentially be unfair, biased or erroneous. The Committee does not, of course, suggest that any past decisions have exhibited these flaws or that any future decisions will do so. However, the Committee is concerned with questions of principle pertaining to the possible infringement of the rights of individuals without any avenue of review or redress being easily accessible.

The existence of appropriately structured avenues of appeal, can serve to underwrite the quality of initial decisions and thus instil public confidence in the competence and professionalism of possibly hard decisions. Review procedures also facilitate the correction of unfair or erroneous decisions in the unlikely event that these occur.

Would you be good enough to help the Committee by advising it on the implications of a refusal by the Secretary to authorise the use of particular drugs; whether appeal or review procedures currently exist; and, if they do not, whether, perhaps in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department or the Administrative Review Council, some suitable avenue of appeal should not be put in place. In making these respectful requests for your assistance the Committee acknowledges that the discretionary decision whether to authorise use of a drug as a pharmaceutical benefit may often have medical policy as well as purely medical aspects. However, it is where difficulty in reconciling these possibly competing interests can cause injustice to individuals, that the need arises for an effective review of an initially adverse decision.
The Committee would be most grateful to have your advice on these matters.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman

Dear Senator Collins
I refer to Senator Cooney's letter of 6 May 1987, in which he sought advice about the power to review a decision not to issue an authority to prescribe a pharmaceutical benefit.

I am sorry that you have not previously received a reply to that letter. While a reply was being prepared, it was known that the Declaration of Pharmaceutical Benefits made on 18 March 1987, on which the letter was based, would be revoked by a new Declaration. Since the questions in that letter remained relevant for the new Declaration, it appeared to be more efficient on the resumption of Parliament and the completion of the Committee's new membership to provide the Committee with both the new Declaration and the information which was requested together. The declaration has now been forwarded to the Committee.
Sub-section 85 (2) of the National Health Act 1953 provides that the drugs and medicinal preparations to which Part VII of that Act (dealing with pharmaceutical benefits) applies are-
(a) drugs and medicinal preparations that are-
(i) declared by the Minister, in writing, to be drugs and medicinal preparations to which Part VII applies; or
(ii) included in a class of drugs and medicinal preparations declared by the Minister, in writing, to be a class of drugs and medicinal preparations to which Part VII applies;
(b) medicinal preparations composed of-

(i) one or more of the drugs and medicinal preparations referred to in paragraph (a), being a drug or medicinal preparation that is, or drugs and medicinal preparations that are, included in a class of drugs and medicinal preparations declared by the Minister, in writing, to be a class of drugs and medicinal preparations to which that paragraph applies; and
(ii) one or more of such additives as are declared by the Minister, in writing, to be additives to which that paragraph applies.
Under Part VII of the Act the Commonwealth shall provide benefits in respect of certain drugs and medicinal preparations.
The declaration under section 85 sets out the drugs and medicinal preparations to which Part VII applies as follows:
Schedule 1 lists the drugs and medicinal preparations that are available as pharmaceutical benefits and specifies the circumstances (if any) under which they are available.
Schedule 2 lists compounds of certain drugs and medicinal preparations that are available as pharmaceutical benefits.
Schedule 3 lists drug and medicinal preparations which may be used as ingredients of extemporaneously- prepared pharmaceutical benefits.
Schedule 4 lists the additives that may be used with drugs and medicinal preparations.
Schedule 5 lists pharmaceutical benefits available under special arrangements such as for people living in isolated areas.

Prior to 1 April 1987, the drugs and medicinal preparations to which Part VII of the Act applies were prescribed in Schedules to the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations. The Act was amended by the Health Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1986 (Act No. 94 of 1986) to provide, amongst other things, that the drugs and medicinal preparations to which Part VII applies shall be declared by the Minister. The relevant amendments to the Act and consequential amendments to the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations came into operation on 1 April 1987.

A drug or medicinal preparation shall only be made available as a pharmaceutical benefit if the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) has so recommended to the Minister for Community Services and Health. The PBAC is an independent statutory committee established under section 101 of the National Health act to advise the Minister for Community Services and Health on any matter concerning the listing of drugs and medicinal preparations as pharmaceutical benefits.

The Committee comprises six medical practitioners nominated by the Australian Medical Association, one pharmacist nominated by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, a pharmacologist and also a Department of Community Services and Health pharmacist.
The current membership of the Committee is:

Matters considered by the Committee include:
a. the addition of new items to or deletion of items from the Schedule of Benefits;
b. increases or decreases in the maximum allowable quantities of benefits or number of repeats;
c. amendment or removal of restrictions applied to benefits;
d. introduction of restrictions to non-restricted benefits; and
e. deletion of items.

Applications and representations about the listing of pharmaceutical benefits are received from diverse sources, including manufacturers, organisations (such as specialist medical colleges, asthma and diabetes associations and pensioner groups) and from medical practitioners and other individuals. The PBAC spends a significant proportion of its time reviewing such representations.

The Committee meets regularly with representatives of the medical colleges and societies and, where appropriate, seeks expert advice from such professional bodies and provides explanations of recommendations made (or not made) by the PBAC.

Advice may also be sought from individual specialists in the various branches of medicine, from specialist institutions and from such other expert sources as the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee and the Influenza Vaccine Committee. The Committee's decisions and recommendations are therefore drawn from a wide range of experts, including practising clinicians and pharmacologists.

The list of items available as benefits is continuously reviewed by the Committee. As a result of such reviews the Committee may recommend the listing of certain drugs, the imposition or variation of restrictions on the prescribing of particular drugs or groups of drugs, or the deletion of drugs whose availability as benefits is considered to be no longer warranted.

Where a drug is restricted on recommendation of the PBAC, to the treatment of a specific disease or condition, these restrictions are described in detail in the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits which is updated and distributed to all medical practitioners in Australia three times annually (copy enclosed). In addition the Committee often provides, for publication, the reasons for the recommendations it makes to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Frequently such advice takes the form of a circular letter from the Chairman to all medical practitioners. Articles may be arranged for publication in the medical press in support of the Committee's recommendations.

The medical community is therefore kept fully and adequately informed of the availability of drugs on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, restrictions if any applicable to the availability of certain drugs and the medical reason or reasons for those restrictions.

To obtain authority to prescribe a restricted benefit, the medical practitioner must forward to the Regional Director of the Department in his/her State a completed NHS Authority Prescription form (see attached) indicating, inter alia, the disease or purpose for which the benefit is required. Where the circumstances correspond with the authority requirements set out in the Declaration under Section 85 of the National Health Act, then the authority is approved.

As a drug may not be listed as a pharmaceutical benefit otherwise than upon a recommendation by the PBAC, the Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health has no discretionary power in relation to authorising the supply of a restricted benefit. The role of the Secretary or his delegate is therefore no more than an administrative function. In examining an application for Authority to prescribe, the Secretary or his delegate makes no medical judgements, and indeed has no power under the Act to do so, but merely conducts a routine check to ensure that the intended purpose as described in the application is consistent with that declared in the Schedule of Benefits. Should there be any doubt or ambiguity created as a result of the terminology employed by the doctor he/she is contacted by a qualified departmental pharmacist to clarify the terms of the application and then to assess consistency with the requirements under the Declaration under Section 85 of the National Health Act. The Secretary has no discretionary powers to act beyond the specific guidelines recommended by the PBAC and approved by the Minister. As mentioned above, where the Authority is consistent with the terms of the Declaration it is approved. It would be inappropriate to allow avenues of appeal against decisions of the Secretary or his delegate in these circumstances.
Yours sincerely

Dear Mr Austen,

At its meeting on 22 October 1987 the Committee considered AMLC Order No. M33/87 dated 25 June 1987 and tabled in the Senate on 6 October 1987. The Committee would be very grateful to have your advice on a technical legal matter arising under the Order.

Section 49a of the Act Interpretation Act 1901 provides that where an Act authorises the making of regulations, the regulations may apply, adopt or incorporate either, the provisions of any federal legislation as in force from time to time, or the provisions of any other instrument but only as in force at the time the regulations take effect. Subsection 16m (1) of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 applies section 49a to Orders as if Orders were regulations. Clause 3 of AMLC Order No. M33/87 provides that an ``AUS-MEAT'' accredited organisation means ``an establishment accredited in accordance with the AUS-MEAT Operations Manual, as amended from time to time, issued on behalf of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation''. In the same clause ``AUS-MEAT Operations Manual'' is expressed to mean ``the manual so designated, as amended from time to time, published by the Corporation''.''

At first sight, this would appear to infringe the prohibition expressed in section 49a of the Acts Interpretation Act. It may be that by making use of paragraph 46 (b) of that Act a court could read down to its lawful limits the offending definition in the Order. This is by no means certain, however, and it is certainly possible that in a strongly contested case, where very large commercial interests were at stake, the entire Order could be held to be invalid. The Committee would welcome your comments and advice on this question.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, will be absent from the chamber during Question Time today as she has had a minor accident. question.speaker: Cook Sen P.F.S.

talk.start.para: â€”Has the Minister for Finance read the truckling tribute to Sir Earle Page given by Senator Stone in his Earle Page Memorial Lecture and, in particular, his ringing endorsement of Page? He said:

question.para: I have been profoundly impressed both by the fertility of his ideas and the substance of his achievements . . . a visionary and an achiever . . . his achievement is as enduring as it is imposing.
Does the Minister know what these ideas are or were? Did the application of those ideas cause economic problems for Australia and do those ideas still cause problems?

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I take a point of order. I cannot see how this question relates in any way to the Minister's portfolio responsibilities. Clearly, it is a waste of Question Time and I suggest that you rule the question out of order.

â€”Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. In this place we can all learn from experience. Senator Walsh is the Finance Minister in this Government. It might be very enlightening to hear views about what errors there were in the past and how we might improve. Senator Chaney is always encouraging us to do that.
â€”I will allow the question on the basis that the Minister was asked a question about economic matters. I ask him to relate his answer to those areas of his portfolio that are relevant.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: â€”Certainly, Mr President. The ideas that were put forward by Sir Earle Page in his autobiography Truant Surgeon are certainly highly relevant to economic questions in general and to the question that has been asked in particular, with one possible exception. There were a number of obsessions brought out in Truant Surgeon, the first of which was that we should have lots of new States, which was probably a harmless enough eccentricity. The others were settling most of the returned soldiers on the land, on farms, redistributing the Empire's population-he actually used that term-in order to exploit the unlimited resources of the Empire, and damming every reasonable sized creek, particularly if it flowed towards the Pacific Ocean on the eastern coast of Australia in order to irrigate the land. All those three things did have very serious economic implications, particularly when they were put forward by someone who was unfettered by the remotest ideas of fundamental economic concepts such as opportunity cost, marginality or comparative advantage. In other words, they were far from harmless. They drove the reckless overseas borrowing by State and Federal governments during the 1920s, which ran up a debt three times as high as that proportion of gross domestic product we now have. That was run up to fund a host of crazy and uneconomical land settlement and irrigation schemes. Indeed, some responsible economic journalists have recently suggested that it took us 20 years to get over the hangover from that crazy borrowing spree of the 1920s.

answer.para: I am astounded that Senator Stone should be resurrecting such cargo cult policies and cargo cult expectations in the late 1980s, suggesting that Senator Button may not have been correct when he assumed that everybody learnt something. It would appear from Senator Stone's endorsement of Sir Earle Page's ideas that he has not learned very much at all. I did endorse another comment that Senator Stone made recently; that is, that the coalition is not fit for government-particularly as he is now part of it.

The fifth major idea or obsession which came through in Truant Surgeon was the policy of protection all round, after which a chapter was named and about which a chapter was written. In other words, that was the policy under which the most inefficient agricultural industries also got on to the feather-bed, or, to change the metaphor, managed to stick their snouts into the trough as well. It laid the foundations for the planned structural inefficiency, the full blossoming of which took place in the 1950s and the 1960s under another Country Party leader and which this Government is slowly correcting. As I said last week, it took us five years to clean up the financial mess which Mr Howard left behind him as Treasurer. It will take much more than five years to fix up the planned structural inefficiency which various coalition governments and National Party leaders in particular set up over many decades. On the matter of protection all round, I am equally astounded that Senator Stone wants to take us back for a replay of the 1920s and 1930s on that and on the other matter.

In closing, I note that he has in recent times endorsed such Country Party past luminaries as the former Queensland Premier and the Deputy Prime Minister in the Bruce-Page Government. I expect that he will be endorsing Sir John McEwen's policy shortly, but I do not expect him to go all the way and endorse the present National Party of Australia leadership and its policies.

question.block.title: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: MS W. BACON

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask the Minister: Can he tell the Senate the circumstances surrounding the hiring of journalist Wendy Bacon for a job with the new Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) television program The World Tonight and the subsequent reversal of that decision to hire her? Is it a fact that Ms Bacon's appointment was aborted on the ground that she was `unsuitable' for employment? If so, why has no more detailed explanation been given for the decision? Does her alleged unsuitability have anything to do with the fact that Ms Bacon is not well regarded by some of the Minister's mates in the New South Wales Labor Party? If the Minister has not inquired into this matter, which is causing concern among ABC staff and journalists generally, will he do so without delay and report to the Senate as soon as possible?

â€”I cannot tell Senator Chaney or anyone else of the circumstances surrounding this matter because I have not inquired into those circumstances, and I do not propose to do so. I believe that it would be quite inappropriate for me to do so. The ABC is an independent organisation. Once its manager is appointed, it is managed on a thoroughly independent basis. Ministers in this Parliament are constantly urging that that state of affairs continue. I propose to honour that spirit and state of affairs and will not interfere here or elsewhere in any way in staffing decisions of this kind.

â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's appeal to principle. I ask him: Is that principle thought to be abused in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation? In other words, is the real principle being applied that, if a person is one of Labor's mates or a former employee of a Labor Minister, he gets a job, no questions asked, but, if he is critical of this Government, he will not get a job? If that is the principle that is being applied, what recourse does the public have against that sort of abuse if the Minister wipes his hands of the matter?

â€”It does Senator Chaney no credit to make any such imputation. I do not know whether he thinks there is any factual foundation for it. I am not in a position to respond further, having taken the course that I have, and I do not propose to be intimidated or provoked into responding to that kind of squalid, sanctimonious, trivialising little foray.

â€”Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware that the Official Secretary to the Governor- General wrote to the Prime Minister on 4 December 1987 about reporting requirements under the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act 1987? Will the Government take action to ensure that the office of the Official Secretary complies with the reporting requirements of the equal employment legislation?

â€”The Office of the Governor-General is required to comply with the requirements of the equal employment opportunity legislation. I am aware that the Official Secretary wrote to the Prime Minister on 4 December 1987 in relation to reporting requirements under the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act. The Prime Minister will consider his reply in the light of the statutory provisions that are applicable. I note too that a report in a Sunday newspaper stated that the Secretary to the Office of the Governor-General had replied that he did not need to put in a report in compliance with the Act because there was no discrimination in that Office. If it is the case that that is the Secretary's view, I think the Secretary should again look at the provisions of the Act. All government authorities and bodies are required to comply with the Act whether or not discriminatory practices are implemented. Probably many bodies would say at this stage that they do not engage in discriminatory practices. Nonetheless, because the Government is seeking an adequate database and an adequate picture of where women are employed throughout the public sector, it is important that all agencies, including the Office of the Governor-General, reply, and I expect that that will happen in due course.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I draw the Minister's attention to resolution No. 2 of the second meeting of the Australian Soil Conservation Council (ASCC) held in February 1987, in which the Council noted that a meeting of State representatives has been arranged to redraft the national soil conservation strategy `which will then be released for public comment for a period of three months'. In the light of this resolution, I ask: Why has the Minister allowed only five weeks-from 6 November to 15 December-for public comment on this document? Will the Minister give a commitment to extend the time allowed for public comment on the draft national soil conservation strategy until at least 6 February 1988 to comply with the ASCC resolution?

â€”I certainly will not give any commitment to extend anything. My recollection of this matter is unsure. I think that Mr Kerin might be making some announcement about this tomorrow. Some extension will be announced then.

â€”Can the Minister for Transport and Communications provide any information in response to the assertion on 23 November by the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate that the only subjects the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) Radio National program First Edition ever examines are women's issues, the environment and the peace movement?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I have received some information from the ABC.
â€”It is up to the ABC, isn't it?

â€”That is true. I am not interfering with its management this time. I am defending the organisation publicly against a squalid and indefensible attack on its integrity. It should be evident to even the most mean-spirited observer and listener of the scene that, in fact, Senator Stone was absolutely in error and has as yet taken no steps whatsoever to correct the impression he made during the debate in this chamber on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, when he said:

answer.para: If one depended on First Edition for one's knowledge of the books that were to be reviewed in our community, one would imagine that nothing was ever written on subjects other than women's issues, the environment and the peace movement. Those are the only things the program ever talks about.

I just want to say that I have received, and now table for the information of honourable senators-Senator Stone in particular-summaries of 63 editions of the First Edition program as broadcast between 4 September 1986 and 27 November this year. Those programs cover not only a mass of Australian and overseas fiction, but also a whole variety of subject matters, including multiculturalism, children's literature, religion, domestic and overseas politics, photography, poetry, music, Australian history, world affairs, public administration, food, military history, Kim Philby, Rudyard Kipling and Neville Wran-I do not know whether he would appreciate being treated in the same breath.

I am uncertain whether Senator Stone's attack was prompted by the fact that he failed to get a run on the program either as a reviewer or as the subject of a book written by anybody else. However, I think he should acknowledge, as would any listener who is familiar with the Radio National program in particular, that First Edition provides a diverse and very valuable conduit for the community to become aware of the latest in literature, both here and overseas. It is a commendable element of Radio National programming. It does not involve any interference with management prerogatives for me to say so and to defend it vigorously on its behalf, because it is self-evidently the case in the public domain.

question.block.title: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: MS W. BACON

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and follows the latest defence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) that he gave. I wish to make an attack in this question on the ABC and its handling of the Ms Bacon employment and disemployment. I say that that was a squalid act and clearly related to the ABC's concern not to have anybody who would attack the Government. I ask: Does the Minister defend the ABC's treatment of Ms Bacon?

â€”That is a very cheap and pathetic debating point. For me to respond to that would involve an inquiry into the merits of a management decision. For me to respond to an honourable senator coming out with an assertion which is manifestly loony-the prerogative of prejudice combined with ignorance-and which is self-evidently the case to anyone who is remotely familiar with the public evidence available which does not involve tearing apart any veil or interfering with anybody, is a totally different state of affairs. If Senator Chaney were not in his post-election Christmas wind-down, he would have the intelligence to appreciate that fact.

â€”My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Commonwealth Government is continuing to provide the emergency relief funding to organisations and services which traditionally has been provided by State and non-government agencies? What is the level of that funding and has the Government provided any housing funds for low income earners?

â€”Yes, the Commonwealth is continuing to provide funding for emergency relief purposes to both State and non-government agencies. Of course, many of those agencies are well known to honourable senators and include organisations such as the Salvation Army, the Smith Family and the St Vincent de Paul Society, as well as a range of small community organisations in a particular locality. Senator Devereux will be pleased to hear that total funding for 1987-88 from the Commonwealth will be over $6.7m, which is an increase of $404,000 over the previous year. Of the total amount, some $538,000 will go specifically to Aboriginal organisations in recognition of the priority our Government places on assisting Aboriginal people to receive adequate assistance. All these grants have been approved after receiving advice from State advisory committees which incorporate representatives of voluntary agencies. The entire program could not exist without the significant contribution of agencies such as the Salvation Army and the Smith Family. It is a joint Commonwealth and community effort. When this financial year's grants are allocated, it is envisaged that some 650 organisations will receive funding assistance and that we will provide assistance to at least some 130,000 clients. I remind the Senate that in our last Budget poor families were the recipients of our new family assistance package, the most generous package of assistance to poor families ever made in the history of our nation. Our emergency relief efforts indicate a sensible working relationship with community bodies and governments working together to help the most disadvantaged in our community, which is and remains a top priority for our Government.

question.block.title: ABORIGINES: REQUESTS FOR SUPPORT FROM OVERSEAS

talk.start.para: â€”I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is it a fact that an Aboriginal delegation has approached the Soviet and Iranian embassies requesting Third World aid for its so-called Aboriginal nation? Have this delegation, and an organisation called the Committee to Defend Black Rights, which has a current Federal Government grant of $13,000, also requested the Soviet Union and Iran to support its request for sovereign status and for Aboriginal embassies to be established in those countries? Do the organisations comprising this delegation, which are the Treaty '88 Campaign, the Far South Coast Regional Land Council and Aboriginal radio, receive considerable direct or indirect funding and support from the present Federal Government? Is it also a fact that the church-funded Foundation for Aboriginal and Islander Research Action, supported by peak Aboriginal groups including the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations, the National Federation of Land Councils and the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, which receive government funding, has written to the embassies of the United States of America, the Soviet Union, France, Germany, China, Japan, the Scandinavian countries and others, capitalising on recent comments by the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister accusing Australia of `shameless racial discrimination', to seek funding for embassies in these countries and international condemnation of what it claims are Australia's racist policies? As these groups are obviously harming both the Aboriginal cause and Austra- lia's international reputation, thereby encouraging a possible white backlash, will the Govern- ment dissociate itself from these groups and cease to fund their destructive activities?

â€”It is ludicrous to ask a Minister representing a Minister in another place such a very complex and long question of which one would require at least some little notice in order to give the honourable senator the benefit of a considered reply. Therefore, I am unable to help the honourable senator or the chamber in regard to the important matters that he has raised. If it is the case that the Federal Government funds organisations which are seeking the assistance of overseas governments in order to press a claim within the Australian community for sovereignty, it is impossible to imagine how that would sit with Australian sovereignty. â€”I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. My question relates to dwelling approvals, an early indicator of housing industry activity. Is the Minister able to advise the Senate of the total number of dwelling approvals for the latest month for which figures are available-probably October? Is the Minister able to indicate whether there has been a turn- around in housing industry activity? If so, does this show the confidence of the housing industry following such factors as the Government's balanced Budget and falls in interest rates?

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: â€”It is the case that dwelling approvals provide an early indicator of housing industry activity, and the picture in those terms is very encouraging. Total dwelling approvals for October, in seasonally adjusted terms, continued the upward trend which has been evident over the last few months. Total dwelling approvals increased by 3.9 per cent to 11,484, the highest level since January 1986. The turnaround in industry activity is likely to continue, due to increased confidence following the Federal Government's balanced Budget, the reintroduction of negative gearing and the falls in interest rates.

answer.para: The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry has revised its dwelling commencement forecasts upwards to 133,000 for 1987-88 and between 140,000 and 150,000 for 1988-89. During October, the number of private sector housing approvals increased by 7.6 per cent to 8,905 in seasonally adjusted terms-the highest level since October 1985. The figure for private other dwellings approvals increased by 0.5 per cent to 1,947. Total public sector dwelling approvals fell by 1.5 per cent to 856. During the three months to October, total dwelling approvals increased by 5.8 per cent to 32,963, private sector housing approvals increased by 9 per cent to 24,677-both of those figures are seasonally adjusted-and there was a fall in the total number of public sector dwelling approvals to 2,600. Clearly, with regard to dwellings, particularly in the private sector, the picture is a very healthy one.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to an article appearing in a recent copy of the Australian Financial Review relating to changes to rules governing the application of sales tax, the mooted increase of as much as 10 per cent, and the fact that these rules may increase the retail cost of consumer goods. â€”Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of media reports today that some senior South Korean military personnel may seek political asylum in Australia if any of the non-government candidates win the forthcoming South Korean presidential election? question.block.title: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: SANCTUARY COVE PROGRAM

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”Lest Senator Chaney be minded to make another debating point, I repeat that the ABC is an independent statutory authority with full responsibility for its own programming activities and decisions. talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that the Minister has repeated the statement that he does not interfere with the ABC, how does he justify the comments made by Senator Reynolds?

â€”I refer the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer to an article on page 1 of today's Sydney Morning Herald reporting the defence of Senator Stone's recent attacks on the Opposition's economic policies by Queensland National Party President, Sir Robert Sparkes. In the case of the Opposition policy there was some $8 1/2 billion of cuts and, I think, in the case of the National Party policy there was about $14 billion, was there not?
â€”Yes.

â€”I thank Senator Stone. So the question is not based on an accurate statement of fact and, in any event, relates to the Opposition and not to the Government, which is mishandling this economy quite adequately on its own at this stage.

â€”Order! The question sought comments on economic policy and in that regard I will allow it. The question did not ask about Government policy but the second part of the question asked about Opposition policy. I ask the Minister not to answer that part of the question.

â€”It is certainly welcome news that a section of the National Party recognises that the policy put up by the Opposition before the last election was economically irresponsible. The reason it was economically irresponsible--
â€”I take a point of order, Mr President. Is the Minister responding in terms of your direction, or not? It seems to me that the Minister has immediately ignored your direction.
â€”I will listen to the Minister's answer.

â€”The first part of the question referred to the report in the Sydney Morning Herald. I am giving some of the content of that report. Mr Sparkes acknowledged-I welcome this acknowledgment-that it would be economically irresponsible for any party to propose to deliver massive tax cuts and instant increases in average living standards through some amalgam of cargo-cultism and supply side voodoo. Mr Sparkes is absolutely correct in coming to that conclusion.
â€”I raise a point of order, Mr President. The title of the President of the National Party is Sir Robert Sparkes. I ask you to call upon the Minister to use the correct title.
â€”There is no point of order.

â€”In other words, the conclusion reported in the Sydney Morning Herald was correct as far as it went, but unfortunately, it stopped short of recognising that there was an even bigger unfunded gap in the policy presented by the National Party before the election. As I recall it, there was $22 billion worth of tax cuts over three years and only $4 1/2 billion worth of expenditure reductions spelt out. I am waiting for the other $18 billion. I would be glad to receive them any time.

â€”I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. Was the clearance by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) of Federal Hotels Ltd for the Christmas Island casino licence conditional on Dr Stanley Ho divesting himself of his interests in Tal Holdings Ltd, Federal's owners? Has the Australian Federal Police ever had reservations about Dr Ho's involvement with Federal Hotels? Given that Dr Ho's shares were still on Tal's register on 18 November, will the Minister recommend new inquiries to ensure that there is no continuing connection between Dr Ho and Federal Hotels?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The question asked was in three parts and the answer to each of them is no. But I think the Senate deserves a fuller answer. It just so happens that I have a fairly extensive brief to fill out those simple `no' answers to the three parts of the question. I could do no better than to read from the brief. On 14 September 1987 the Federal Police provided me with advice on its investigations into Federal Hotels Ltd-that is, in relation to its proposed development of a casino on Christmas Island. I quote directly from the advice:

answer.para: On 4 June 1987 the then Minister for Territories, on behalf of the Commonwealth, entered into an agreement concerning the development of a hotel and casino on Christmas Island. The agreement requires that the casino licence be issued to a reputable casino operator, approved in writing by the Commonwealth. The developer has proposed Federal Hotels Ltd as the operator and has sought the Commonwealth's approval.

The Minister for Territories had indicated that before Federal Hotels' application be approved, the Commonwealth should ensure that it does not have undesirable financial connections. The AFP agreed to undertake this investigation with Federal Hotels Ltd meeting the costs.

The inquiry was conducted by a team from the AFP Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and included consultation with State and Territory police forces, licensing authorities which have had experience with Federal Hotels Ltd and certain overseas authorities. The investigation focused not only on the reputation and character of Federal Hotels Ltd, but also on companies and individuals who may have an interest in the company, as well as directors, major shareholders and senior employees identified as having a direct association with the proposed Christmas Island casino.
That was on 14 September. The advice goes on to say:

On the basis of information available, the inquiry did not reveal any matter which would cause the AFP to recommend against the company being granted a casino licence. Should the company's application proceed, however, and persons not currently connected with the application become directly involved in the casino establishment, the AFP would need to be advised so that this advice can be reviewed.

That is the end of the advice to me on 14 September. On 30 November the Federal Police provided me with further advice following allegations in Parliament on 27 October regarding a director of Federal Hotels Ltd and his association with persons and companies of alleged ill-repute. The AFP informed me that as a result of these allegations a number of Federal Hotels directors were re-interviewed. Those inquiries did not, however, alter the findings of the earlier advice given to me.

To get this matter in chronological perspective a little further-it may be in the back of the honourable senator's mind-the New South Wales police report on Federal Hotels was made in mid-year. The AFP investigation commenced in mid-July. I understand that on 14 May 1987 his fellow directors of Federal Hotels Ltd voted Dr Ho off the board. At the time of AFP advice of 14 September, Dr Ho had resigned as a director of Tal Holdings Ltd-the parent company of Federal Hotels-and of Federal Hotels Ltd although he still held 5.65 per cent of Tal shares. I was advised late last week that Dr Ho has since sold all his shares and no longer holds any interest in Tal Holdings or Federal Hotels.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister table the AFP reports on Federal Hotels?

â€”No, I will not table those reports. I have given a very full answer, as was contained in my brief, which is directly, and without any modification or deletion by me, what the AFP presented to me on 14 September and 30 November.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health and concerns the grant of $191,000 from medical research funds to utilitarian philosopher Professor Peter Singer for a project entitled `Bioethical Issues in the Use of Human Foetal Tissue, Embryos and Gametes'. Is it a fact that the latest grant is in addition to that of $258,000 for the same project, to the same bioethics centre, over the last three years, giving a total of some $450,000? Is it also a fact that Professor Singer's often published views are that the human embryo, the human foetus, and indeed a newborn child, have no inherent right to exist and, specifically, that a human embryo is of no more inherent worth than a lettuce? How many medical research projects have been approved by the National Health and Medical Research Council over the last three years but have not been funded because of lack of money in the medical research grants fund? Does the Minister not think that doctors and scientists starved of funds for beneficial research should feel cheated by the channelling of $450,000 worth of funds from the medical research grants fund to Professor Peter Singer's projects, which in the original application are admitted to be non-scientific? Is it a fact that the funds are now being used to prepare papers for publication and submission to government bodies and the media in support of the campaign to prevent the major question of human embryo experimentation from being properly determined by the elected representatives of the people, in Parliament?

â€”Partly as a result of earlier interest expressed by Senator Harradine in this medical research grant, the circumstances surrounding it and the competing applications that were made at the time, the matter is being investigated by Dr Blewett. When all the information is available, I will make sure that Senator Harradine has access to it.
â€”Mr President, I have a quick supplementary question. I raised this matter a month ago. Is it not proper that it should be detailed to Parliament before Wednesday?
â€”I will pass that expectation on to Dr Blewett.

â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the so-called clerical error in the estimate of business investment for the September quarter of this year, which resulted in the Australian Bureau of Statistics revising its previous estimate of new capital expenditure growth downwards from, in real terms, 11.8 per cent to 0.5 per cent during that quarter. I ask the Minister whether the Commonwealth Statistician's revision which, as one prominent commentator has said, `renders the Forward Estimates utterly useless', was known to him or his Department ahead of the quite falsely optimistic comments which he and the Treasurer made about Australia's economic prospects when releasing the Forward Estimates last Wednesday.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: â€”I would not have thought that Senator Stone would have the gall to ask this question. I nearly said, `that Senator Gall would have the stone'. There was, however, no pun intended-not consciously, anyway. Six weeks ago, Senator Stone was asserting that the estimates of the Budget outcome would be grossly in error because there would be a serious shortfall in taxation receipts and so on. Of course, there has been a formal official review of the Budget Estimates, the results of which were released by the Treasurer and me last Thursday. I do not have a perfect recall of what happened at that meeting, but I do not think a great deal was said about the economic outlook or that many bullish forecasts about the economic outlook were issued by the Treasurer. There were certainly none by me because, as I recall, I did not address the economic outlook at all.

answer.para: What I did draw attention to was the fact that in the last two Budgets that Mr Howard brought down as Treasurer the Forward Estimates of expenditure grew by 6 per cent in real terms in 1981, and by 8 per cent in real terms in 1982. In other words, not only was there a huge growth in government expenditure built into the Forward Estimates, built into policy, but also it was growing at an accelerated rate. Ever since this Government was elected, that growth rate in the Forward Estimates has been pegged back. It has taken us five years to clean up the mess that John Howard left behind him, but now we have finally done it. On a no policy change basis, for the first year of the Forward Estimates period there will be a real decline in public expenditure on present estimates and parameters.

Senator Stone referred, in the sneering tone that he customarily uses, to the revision as a so-called clerical error. I do not know whether we were meant to read into that that in fact it was not a clerical error, that there was some malfeasance on the part of the Statistician in producing the original figures. Perhaps he would care to explain that later on. Certainly this was a disappointment to the Government and, I would expect, a disappointment to everyone except the Opposition, of course, which is always trying to talk down the economy. Indeed, it wants a catastrophic recession because it can see that with the bunch of duds, as Senator Stone called them, which represent it-the duds purporting to be Opposition spokesmen; I think that is the correct word-the only hope it ever has of getting into government is for there to be some sort of catastrophic depression. The Opposition wants that, but I do not think anybody else does. It was a disappointment that that figure was revised downwards. The level to which it has been revised downwards is, if I recall correctly, not as good in that quarterly period as had been expected when the Budget Estimates were released, but it is not completely out of touch with it.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a brief supplementary question. Will the Minister now respond to my simple question? I asked him: Was the revision in question, the clerical error in question, known to him or his Department ahead of the comments which he and the Treasurer made when releasing the Forward Estimates last Wednesday? Would the Minister answer yes or no, and stop wasting the time of the Senate?
â€”I did not know the precise magnitude of the error, but I knew it was going to be revised downwards.
â€”You cheats!
â€”Order!
â€”`Harpy's' at it again.
â€”Order!

â€”I knew it was going to be revised downwards. I do not believe that the Department of Finance officially knew about that, although I did tell one Finance officer, if not immediately before, then very soon before the Press conference was held. I do not know whether the Treasury Secretary knew of it at that time. If the honourable senator wishes, I will ask Mr Keating whether he did.

â€”I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and for the Bicentenary to recent criticisms by the Opposition and some sections of the community concerning various facets of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary. This criticism ranges from the alleged dismantling of the Scottish bicentennial gift to the demolition of the Captain Cook memorial in England and certain aspects of the tall ships visit. Can the Minister explain to the Senate the current situation of these matters? Is it a fact that the Minister has received written assurances from the Opposition that it is in fact very supportive of the Government's plans for the Bicentenary? Can the Minister explain the role of the Opposition in the planning of the celebrations for the Bicentenary?

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: â€”It is the case that the Opposition has expressed its support for the bicentennial program, as Senator Puplick, on behalf of the Opposition, has made clear in writing. Of course, Senator Shirley Walters has been a member of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, the body charged with the development of the Commonwealth's major program for the Bicentennial. So the Government has good reason to expect ongoing bipartisan support for the program in general. In respect of some minor criticisms that have been raised, I have some information for the Senate. Senator Puplick expressed concern about the proposed demolition of a memorial to Captain Cook in a church in Cambridge in the United Kingdom. I am advised that this matter had been taken up with the Fraser Government and discussions have been continuing since 1980. The reason I was not aware of this matter when Senator Puplick raised it the other day is that it should not be considered in the context of the Bicentenary but quite properly it is a heritage matter. I understand that in recent months there has been correspondence between the Australian High Commission in London, the Parliament House Construction Authority and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories as to the possibility of relocating the plaque in Australia if its present custodians do not object to this and if funding for it can be found.

answer.para: There have also been criticisms in the newspapers about young people who had hoped to participate in the tall ships event as sailing trainees and who were not able to secure places. For the information of honourable senators, I point out that for the purposes of the tall ships event a tall ship is any sailing vessel with a minimum waterline length of just over nine metres or 30 feet. The crew must consist of at least 50 per cent of sail trainees between the ages of 16 and 25 and with no regular off-shore sailing experience. Of course this requirement maximises the opportunity for youth participation. We have now been advised that all young people seeking berths on tall ships training ships have been accommodated. In fact, a total of 26 young sail trainees gained places aboard vessels training for the trip to Sydney. In conclusion, it is clear that although we can expect the odd running criticism of various bicentennial events as they come on to the agenda, overall the aspirations of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, the Commonwealth Government and, I hope, the Opposition will be more than adequately fulfilled throughout the year.

talk.start.para: â€”Is the Minister for Transport and Communications unaware of or is he unconcerned at the serious impact Telecom's proposal to meter local calls will have on the elderly, the disabled, the isolated and the telephone counselling services? If he is aware of the detrimental effect these proposals will have, why has he not answered my representations in October and November on this matter on behalf of my constituents? When will he take action to see that these constituents are not disadvantaged by this Federal Government authority? Is his inaction due to the fact that he supports the Telecom proposals or is it simply that he is not prepared to answer his mail?

â€”The timing of local calls is a very sensitive and delicate issue in which it is very important that there be an extended process of consultation and discussion based on a clear understanding of both the problems and the principles involved before any decision is made. Telecom has been looking at this issue in fact for a number of years. But, as I said in response to a question asked during the Estimates committees debate in this place, the question is becoming a more urgent one because of the rapidly accelerating use, or perhaps misuse, of the local call regime by businesses engaged in data transmission and the use of the network for local calls for computer hook-ups of one kind or another. Certainly, I think that any resolution of this matter should involve, as I said, a process of extended debate. Any response to it should be at the very least one that is revenue neutral, that does not involve any massive additions to the revenue of the kinds that have been quite wrongly, I think, speculated about by some people in responding to newspaper reports. It should involve in that sense a regime which means the short calls will be significantly cheaper than they are now. But, more particularly, whatever else is done to soften any possible introduction of any such regime, it is particularly crucial, as Senator Newman says and I acknowledge, that very close consideration be given to the implications for the elderly, the disabled and others who might be thought to be disadvantaged in one way or another by any such proposal. I do not propose to comment further on this issue at this stage. I understand that Telecom will be making an announcement later this week-not deciding the issue because it is premature for all the reasons I have just indicated to decide the issue, but rather initiating a process of public discussion and debate on it. Under those circumstances where an announcement of that kind is imminent, I think it is inappropriate for me to contribute further to speculation on the subject.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs and it deals with what appears to be political discrimination in recruitment for the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC). Can the Minister comment on advertisements for positions within the Australian Electoral Commission which state that politically active applicants will not be considered for appointment? Does this form of employment discrimination contravene the provisions of the Public Service Act which specify very tight guidelines for employment? Will the Government review these electoral commission advertisements and guarantee that all applicants for positions within the Commission will get equal treatment?

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: â€”The question of political discrimination in the selection of personnel for some positions within the Electoral Commission has been raised, I think, by Senator Short at the Estimates committee hearings and certainly by Mr Don Cameron, MP, in a Press release issued on Saturday. I also acknowledge that Senator Burns has shown an interest in this particular matter which goes back some months. A belief that politically impartial, or at least non-active, personnel should be employed in sensitive positions with the Commonwealth Electoral Office dates back to before the First World War. I note that Senator Cook is not here; it even predates Sir Earle Page's entry into the Parliament. It is a time honoured tradition, I believe, and I assume that no honourable senator would like to see politically partisan activists exercising unfair power in relation to the conduct of elections. However, Labor governments have been committed to the elimination of discrimination in employment. They have promoted several pieces of legislation to that effect. There was the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975 and there was the Sex Discrimination Act of 1984. The Public Service Act acknowledges that these employment procedures set down in those two Acts are pre-eminent.

answer.para: The question has been raised whether or not the Australian Electoral Commission, by identifying some of its positions as politically sensitive, is in line with the Public Service policy on discrimination. Advertisements for some AEC positions include a paragraph stating that politically active applicants must undertake to refrain from such activity while being employed by the Commission. Section 33 of the Public Service Act outlines that discrimination that is essential for the effective performance of the duties to which the appointment relates is not unlawful. However, the Act states that such discrimination should be declared by the Act's regulations not to be discrimination. I accept Senator Burns's point in this regard and this particular section will be followed up. However, the Electoral Commissioner, Professor Hughes, did write to the Public Service Board on 9 September 1986 enclosing a copy of the policy of the Australian Electoral Commission in regard to these matters.

talk.start.para: â€”For the benefit of Senator Short, it was 9 September 1986. In that letter he said:

answer.para: The Board appreciates that the AEC is in a special situation in relation to political participation and recognises the importance of the Commission and its staff being seen to be, as well as in fact being, completely impartial as between the contesting parties in elections.
The Public Service Board's Assistant Commissioner went on to advise:

It is recognised in the case of the Australian Electoral Commission that the scope for conflict and apparent conflict, between political participation and the official duties of many Commission staff . . . is considerably greater than is generally the case elsewhere in the Service.
The Public Service Board letter concluded:

The Board's guidelines are necessarily at a level of generality; on many aspects, it is envisaged that individual departments and agencies will produce their own guidelines more directly applicable to their special circumstances.

On this advice, the Australian Electoral Commission has adopted its policy of signalling to prospective applicants that political impartiality will be an important consideration in determining any appointment. I would view with the greatest disappointment if any technicality prevented the Australian Electoral Commission from taking such precautions. As was pointed out at the Estimates Committee, in reply to questions from Senator Short, Professor Hughes himself was appointed as Chairman of the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation, under the Fraser Government, so he has had a fair degree of experience in running government policy on discrimination. Senior staff of the Australian Electoral Commission have been consulted on this matter and were in concurrence with the decision that certain areas within the Electoral Commission were out of bounds. Certain aspects within the Commission's activities are not politically sensitive, such as personnel and corporate services, and it is possible for people to pursue a career in those areas.

The action taken by the Australian Electoral Commission is consistent with government policy-of both this Labor Government and past Liberal governments-it is also consistent with the International Labour Organisation Covenant No. 101 that sensitive public positions should be subject to specific and special employment guidelines.

debate.sub1.title: Withdrawal of Proposal of Matter of Public Importance

It is not the wish of the Opposition unnecessarily to eat into the time that is required for legislation, as was indicated by the withdrawal of Senator Brownhill's matter of public importance. The reason this matter has been put forward-and Senator Puplick did not speak to his motion, again in the interests of not using up time; but the Senate now requires an explanation-is that in this, the last week of the session, the Government has introduced 47 Government papers. Given the fact that we have half an hour for discussion, it is quite clear that we will barely touch the sides. In the normal course we would deal with a few of these papers, but nowhere near the 47. In the area that was the subject of the motion by Senator Puplick-to bring up the report of the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, which is the thirty-second paper on the list-we are acting this way because last Friday a substantial announcement was made by the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, relating to a matter of great importance to not only Queensland but also the rest of Australia, namely, the intentions of the Government on the World Heritage listing of the Daintree rainforest. The Opposition understands, again because of the exigencies of the Government's program, that Senator Richardson does not propose to make a statement to the Senate on this important matter. This was one of the few opportunities that arose to deal with this matter and to have some debate in the Senate during the final week of sitting before we rise for the summer recess.

speech.para: That was the reason for our action. I thought there would be a very considerable Democrat interest in this matter-the Australian Democrats always pretend to be concerned about these matters.
