talk.start.para: â€”The Opposition continues to oppose the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill 1987, the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Bill 1987, the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Interest on Underpayments) Bill 1987 and the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987, which introduce a petroleum resource rent tax on oil producers in the off-shore areas of Australia, other than the existing oilfields of Bass Strait in what are known as the off-shore green field areas. The reasons for our opposition to this new tax are set out fully in the speech I made in the Senate on behalf of the Opposition on 5 May. I do not propose at this stage to go over the whole of that ground again. On 5 May we had a very full debate in the Senate, in which a number of honourable senators took part. The debate, however, was adjourned by the Government and was not reintroduced. Because of the stance the Opposition and the Australian Democrats took, it was obvious that the legislation would be defeated. The Government took the legislation off the Notice Paper with the calling of the double dissolution in July this year.

speech.para: The Government has now reintroduced these Bills in exactly the same form as they were in in May. I sincerely hope that the Democrats will not be bought off with the 30 pieces of silver which the Government has offered them as token money for solar research and that they will maintain their strong opposition to this measure which was so clearly stated by Senator Sanders on their behalf in a debate in this chamber in May. I have some concern about whether the Democrats will maintain that opposition to the legislation in the light of the offer the Government has made to them in the form of money for solar energy research. Successive governments have spent money on solar energy research either through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council program or through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. There has also been a good deal of research done in the States on solar energy. I have not seen the details of what the Government has offered. Is it to be a net sum of, reputedly, $5m? Is it to be $5m per annum or over a period of time or what? In any event, the Government seems to be making only a token gesture in support of alternative energy research.

The Opposition is not opposed, by any means, to further research being done on alternative energy resources or on the development of technology for the use of solar energy in various forms. We certainly support that. We supported that research when we were in government. But the Opposition questions the practicality of replacing the existing energy resources, such as oil, coal and uranium, with alternative renewable energy resources in the immediate or even in the foreseeable future. Desirable as it may be that, in due course, we replace our existing sources of energy-it is a world-wide problem; it is not confined to Australia, and it is being addressed world-wide-nevertheless, the opinion at the moment is that despite the advances being made with solar energy technology, a recent example of which is the solar-powered cars which made the historic trip from north to south across Australia, the practicality of resorting to alternative forms of energy in a major way is remote at this stage and will remain so until the end of this century and maybe beyond.

Although we agree fully with the need to pursue and develop alternative and renewable energy resources-resources that do not involve the serious problems of the traditional resources-we are faced in the immediate future with meeting the growing energy demands in a growing economy and with providing, in particular, electricity by traditional means. Here we are talking about the need, as far as possible, for Australian self-sufficiency in oil. Even with the possible development of alternative sources of energy for the production of electricity, there is clearly a need for oil and petroleum for transport needs. Even though oil may have been largely replaced by coal and uranium for the production of electricity around the world, it is clearly required and will be required for a long time yet as a means of fuelling transportation. That is of vast importance to Australia in particular because of our great distances and the dwindling of our existing reserves of oil.

Only last week Esso Australia Ltd, a partner with Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) in Bass Strait, the only really major oil field in Australia, downgraded Australia's crude oil discovery potential. A news release from Esso in Sydney on Sunday 6 December stated:
. . . announced a downward revision of approximately 25 per cent for Australia's crude oil discovery potential but forecast there are more reserves yet to be found than have been produced to date.
However, because it appears unlikely there will be more very large oil fields discovered, the additional reserves will be in smaller pools, harder and more expensive to find.

It is quite clear now, not only from that announcement but also from the experience of the oil exploration industry in Australia in recent years, that the prospect of Australia finding another oil field of the magnitude, or even the approximate magnitude, of our Bass Strait oil field is becoming very unlikely. The efforts of recent years have shown that Australia does not enjoy a great prospectivity for oil either on-shore or off-shore. By common consent, we have one of the lowest prospects for the discovery of oil anywhere in the world. As a result of the collapse of oil prices in 1986 and the accompanying severe decline in oil exploration in Australia during that time, this problem is becoming even more acute. In these circumstances, one would have thought that the policy of a responsible Federal government would be to encourage, as much as it possibly could, exploration for a product that is so desperately required in Australia. The former Department of Resources and Energy forecast that, in the absence of any further oil discoveries, by 1992-93 we will have to be importing oil to the tune of some $3 billion-a further $3 billion drain on our current account. By the year 2000, if that continues, that cost will be of the order of $4 1/2 billion.

Statements made by Australian oil explorers and producers, in particular Esso and BHP, and the many other smaller companies in the business, show clearly that there is a prospect, although it is a low one, of finding smaller amounts of oil. They may not be of the order of the Bass Strait fields, but there are smaller pools around the country, and small pools are certainly of great importance when one considers the problem which is staring us in the face and which will get worse long before the year 2000, which is only 12 years away. Therefore, if we can even find smaller oil fields than Bass Strait over that period, it will help to tide us over a critical period for Australia's overseas current account. I do not need to labour the point about the need not only for improving exports but also for saving imports. It has been well and truly brought home to us over the last year or two.

The Government should, in these circumstances, be following a policy of incentive for exploration, for companies to go out and find some of the oil that is obviously still to be found in Australia, both on-shore and off-shore, but particularly off-shore. In 1985, 49 off-shore wells were drilled, but it is estimated that in 1987 only 12 will be drilled. Although the picture has improved somewhat on-shore, there is a pretty wide consensus within the industry that it is within the off-shore, not the on-shore, fields that we are likely to find the larger pools, despite the extra cost and the extra difficulties of discovery.

This Government, instead of encouraging and giving greater incentives to oil exploration, has placed further disincentives on oil companies. One might have thought that, if it was going to create more incentives, it would at least not create disincentives and put greater burdens on the exploration industry. That is quite the reverse of what has happened in other parts of the world, particularly in the United States of America, Canada and the United Kingdom in the past 12 months. Those countries have been reacting to the problem experienced by their oil industries as well as ours, namely, the virtual halving of oil prices. Naturally, that in itself has been a great disincentive. In those countries there has been some reduction in the tax regimes, the secondary taxes as they are generally called, on the oil exploration and production industries. Yet in Australia the Government has not only imposed new secondary taxes on the production of oil, particularly off-shore, such as that which is known as the new oil tax, but also introduced other taxes. I refer to general taxes such as the capital gains tax, which has had an effect on the farm-in, farm-out arrangements, and the fringe benefits tax. It has also now introduced the resource rent tax, something that was announced as Government policy three years ago. We have a climate in which there have been great disincentives for the oil industry not only in the lack of prospectivity, with which I have already dealt, but also in the great fall in the price of oil which occurred in 1986 and which continues. Indeed, there could be a further fall in the price of oil as a result of the problems currently within the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

So in a situation where these sorts of secondary taxes were introduced on oil producers around the world-and in Australia-in the 1970s in the context of the price of oil being $US30 a barrel and sometimes higher, this Government is proposing to introduce another secondary tax in the shape of the resource rent tax when the price of oil is around $US17 a barrel. The price could fall further, as it did during 1986. It is all very well for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, to talk about the price of oil being the major factor: it is an important factor but there are other factors. It is difficult to find oil in Australia and a producer has to look to the after tax profit, not simply the total derived income from the resource. It is in this field of producer realisation that this series of Government taxes, and the new resource rent tax, are such an important factor in the decision to explore.

The Opposition has consistently opposed the Government's proposals for this new tax. I emphasise that it is a new tax. It is a replacement in the green fields, the off-shore areas, for the existing tax regime; it is not on top of it. But it is on top of a number of other taxes that I have already mentioned and, of course, on top of the ordinary company tax, which has been increased by this Government recently. In a climate in which the Government should be giving further incentives to Australian oil producers, it is proposing to create further burdens for them, further disincentives, in the shape of a new taxation regime by introducing this legislation.

As I have said, the Opposition is opposed to this legislation. In the event that it is passed, the Opposition will propose to reduce the incidence of the tax. Although this tax is said to be a profits based tax, it deals only with expenditures on a particular permit area where production is occurring under a production licence. Any exploration expenditures outside that permit area virtually will not be deductible against this resource rent tax. Apart from the tax, that is a great disincentive because, as I have said, Australia has low productivity for exploration. Exploration effort throughout all of the off-shore areas of Australia is desirable; the deduction should not be confined only to the area where a company is lucky enough to find oil on a particular permit area. And a great deal of luck in involved in many cases. A company should have the incentive to find oil by being given the benefit of some deduction for the area it has explored.

So, for all these reasons, I reiterate the Opposition's total rejection of this legislation. As I said, in the event that the legislation is not totally rejected in the Senate, despite our continuing opposition to these proposals, we hope that the Senate will give consideration to amendments to alleviate to some extent the incidence of this tax. This is an alternative proposal the Opposition will put forward.

speech.speaker: Sanders Sen N.K.

talk.start.para: â€”I think it should be noted that this is the first time in my presence in the Senate that Senator Durack has not spoken for his full time. I do not know what this indicates. The Australian Democrats support the resource rental tax: it is our policy to support such taxes. We believe that the companies involved-the mining companies, the oil companies-are using the people's resource. They do not often recognise that fact; they choose not to recognise it. After all, it is not theirs; it belongs to the people of Australia and the people of Australia should benefit from it far more than they do. All the loopholes, rorts and devious machinations of the oil companies and mining companies to avoid paying taxes are well known and I think it is good that the Government is finally starting to make sure that the people of Australia benefit as much as the oil companies do. We wanted more for the people in this legislation. The last time it was around we felt that the people were not getting a good enough deal and also that the future was not being looked after. We were opposed to the legislation. We support it now. We feel that the people of Australia-especially the people of future Australia-are being looked after by the Government.

speech.para: I suppose one reason that Senator Durack did not take his full half hour is that the oil companies are not all that opposed to the legislation. After all, the Hawke conservative Government is not really going to do anything to disadvantage the oil companies or any of its major supporters-Mr Murdoch, Mr Bond and Mr Packer. So we can take it as read that the oil companies are not really going to be disadvantaged by this legislation as much as they would say. They can live with it. I will give a quote further down the line which shows that they can live with it. The position will be a little harder for them than it has been and they do not like it. However, we support the legislation because the people will get a little better deal.

The Liberals are grandstanding over this because they shot themselves in the foot in the first place. Really, what they are involved in is a squabble between Esso and Exxon and all that, the Americans, and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), the `Big Australian', is caught in the middle. BHP does want this resource rental tax because the Jabiru field was set up on the basis of the resource rental tax being initiated. If the resource rental tax system is not introduced, BHP immediately will be up for a whole bunch of excise back taxes. Of course, with the resource rental tax this expenditure is pushed on down the line a bit and so BHP is for it. So BHP wants it; Esso does not want it.

BHP has been screaming to me about deductibility. It wants deductibility. It has deductibility applicable on its company tax. It is not being hurt here; it does not need it. I think it is screaming as a knee-jerk reaction, as it always does. It wants 1,000 per cent of the cake-it wants everything and then some. It is still getting a pretty good slice of the cake but the Australian people are getting some as well.

What about the campaign of the oil companies? Is it reasonable? The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA) runs advertisements which state that Australia is running out of oil. We are told in a full page advertisement in the Canberra Times of 27 April 1987, showing a picture of an oil drum, that Australia is running out of oil. This is supposed to scare us into allowing the oil companies to drill for more oil and to give them even more concessions than we already give them. What utter rubbish! They already have the moon. What do they want? Another advertisement in the Australian Financial Review dated Friday, 6 March says, `Where is the incentive to find more oil?'. Implicit in all this is the belief that somehow, if we merely drill for more oil and find it all our problems will be solved. The earth is made of oil, all we have to do is go out and drill for it. What utter rubbish!

Another assumption is made by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association. A letter on this matter was addressed to the Australian Democrats but APEA turned it into a media statement because we did not agree with Keith Orchison, who wrote it. It became a public letter and I will now quote from it. I think that it indicates the Association's single minded approach to the whole energy question. It says:
APEA supports the view that the self-sufficiency problem can and should be addressed in part by recourse by substituting LPG and NGV for gasoline by conversion of natural gas to liquid fuels . . .

Okay, maybe, perhaps we can push it a little along that line. But what about something else that has been concerning everyone lately? This is directly related to the use of, exploration for and production of oil-the greenhouse effect. Where does this guy live? Does he live on earth? Apparently he does, but he does not take any responsibility for living on earth. He says that we should completely convert all our fossil fuels to carbon dioxide. That would be his approach. What would happen if we did that? We have just had the Greenhouse '87 conference in Melbourne and scientists all agreed that the result of burning fossil fuels is an increase in carbon dioxide and a warming up of the earth's atmosphere. There was no disagreement about that; there was a bit of disagreement over what year this might occur but there was no disagreement at all about the fact that burning fossil fuels will change our climate.

One would think that a moderately intelligent person-even an honourable senator in this place-would take some responsibility for the future, but Mr Keith Orchison does not and the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association does not. Apparently Senator Durack does not; he is not concerned about the greenhouse effect, he wants to drill for and burn more oil. What do the scientists say? They say that there will be a massive increase in fire danger, there will be floods and major portions of the coastal cities will be flooded. The list goes on and on. This is not pie in the sky stuff, it is scientific reality. Scientists have been mentioning this for 20 years. We have had the troglodytes saying-as troglodytes do in this Senate-`Oh, it will never happen'. Well it may not happen in the lifetime of the geriatric people around here, but it will happen and it cannot be ignored. One cannot just brush it under the table. Often honourable senators in this chamber try to negate an argument by personal abuse. That does not work in the real world. This is not a section of the real world.

We live in a lucky country. An interesting article appeared in the Petroleum Gazette, Volume 25 in the autumn of this year. It was written by G. G. Harvey, who is General Manager of BP Petroleum Development Australia Pty Ltd. It is an extract from his paper to the Bureau of Mineral Resources' 1987 petroleum and minerals review conference in Canberra on 18 March. He asks, `Can Australia regain its status as a lucky country?'. He says that we are a lucky country in oil but he goes on to say:
Our view, shared by many, has put a far lower estimate on the cost of alternative energy supplies than those we made in the 1970s.

Here is a man in the oil industry who says that alternative energy may be more economically attractive than he thought. So there are some thinkers in the oil industry after all. He goes on with this message for Australia:
BP estimates that Australia's yet to be discovered reserves are very low, a little more than 0.5 per cent of the NCWs, 300 billion barrels of reserves.

As Senator Durack said and as Mr Harvey points out, we do not have a lot of oil here anyway. The implication for this would be: why are we spending all this money looking for a dwindling oil resource when if we put the same amount of money into renewables we could get a lot more for our bucks? Mr Harvey makes another interesting comment. While Senator Durack was screaming about the poor benighted oil companies which are being so mistreated by the Government under the tax regime, Mr Harvey of BP says:
On the relative attractiveness of the tax regime, Australia appears to be moving in the right direction.

Here is a major oil executive saying that the Government is doing the right thing. He mentioned renewables as I did and as even Senator Durack did. Why are renewables not being utilised? Is it because they are uneconomic? No, in fact they are being utilised in many parts of the world. Is the technology not developed? Do we need more research? No, we do not. The technology is very well developed in many areas. We have seen the Press reports on the Sunraycer which went from Darwin to Adelaide on solar power at an average speed of 66.92 kilometres an hour. That is pretty good for anybody. It shows that the technology is developed if only we had the will to use it.

A report in the Australian on 7 October 1987 was headed, `Solar power shines brightest among alternative sources'; another in the Canberra Times on 25 October 1987 was entitled, `Harnessing the sun and the wind: we have the power'. The media in general are full of articles about the technology, how we have it and how it will work. Why is it not implemented? When I was assistant professor of geography at the University of California at Santa Barbara, I invited a vice-president of Exxon Oil to speak to my class about environmental pollution. One of the kids asked me a question. He said, `What about solar power?'. This guy was an American; unlike Australian oil executives who want to laugh all the way to the bank and be loved while they are doing it, the Americans do not mind making a lot of money and being hated. Therefore, he was willing to tell the truth. He said, `Look, if we could throw a blanket around the sun and drill a hole in it we would be into solar tomorrow. We are only interested in something on which we can have a vertical integrated system. We explore for it, we pull it out of the ground, refine it and sell it. We can control all aspects of the marketing of it. That is the way you make a buck; that is the American way'. That is true, he was being honest. The reason business does not like renewables is that it cannot control the source. The wind and the sun are free and business is not into it. These people will not get into it until they have to-not until they have burned their last bit of oil and coal. Then honourable senators can be sure that solar will come on and it will be their prime concern.

What about the various technologies? What about wind? I have just returned from a trip to Europe and in the Copenhagen Airport terminal there was a closed circuit television showing commercials. Why anybody would want to sit around and watch closed circuit commercials I have no idea, but the point was that wind power was being advertised as one of the products of Danish industry-off the shelf wind power. It can and does work. Two year ago I went to Hawaii and I sought out the wind farms on the big island. I found 250 25-kilowatt Jacobs going around and I thought that was really something. I was very impressed and I told the people who manage the field that I was quite impressed. They told me that this was nothing, that I should go to San Gorgonio Pass in California where there are 1,000 aero generators. So I went there. I crested the rise and looked out over the valley and there they were-lots and lots of windmills, I do not know how many. I went to see the guy in charge of the Southern California Edison Wind Project who had aero generators rating from 2 megawatts to about 50 kilowatts. He was a redneck-he had a hard hat and a red neck. He was the sort of person who in Tasmania would have a bumper sticker that says, `Fertilise the south west, bulldoze a greenie'. This guy in California said, `Look, wind power-there is nothing to stop it. It is a goer. The only thing that can stop it is nuclear war'. In America very many people are concerned, and rightly so, about nuclear war. In 1985, Southern California Edison had produced 662 gigawatt hours of electricity from the wind. That is about 10 per cent of total Tasmanian production, and we produce a lot of electricity in Tasmania. This year, in 1987, it has installed 1,000 megawatts in wind. I said, `Gee, that is good. How many windmills do you have around here?' A representative of the project said, `I think there are 1,500, but I am not sure because they are going in at such a rate. But we do not have many. You should go out to Alta Mont Pass where there are over 4,000'. I did not get up there. The point I am making is that technology works. Southern California Edison, which is a big business, is very convinced that it works and it has invested in it. In fact, it is a viable technology right now. We do not need to develop the technology; we do not need more research; we need the will to implement it.

What about the local situation? What happens here with wind power? I think it is interesting to examine the response of our own Hydro-Electric Commission. How did it respond to wind power? In the first place I must point out that Russ Ashton, who is no longer the Commissioner, is a civil engineer. I think probably one of the reasons why we do not have renewable energy is that many of the engineers in positions of high power are civil engineers who are used to pouring concrete. They are not mechanical or electrical engineers; they are used to big, heavy duty projects. Russ Ashton said that wind would not work, that the windmills would all fall down, and the reason was that they had 300-tonne blades. Mr Ashton explained that these windmill blades would weigh as much as 300 tonnes. If people build windmill blades out of reinforced concrete I suppose that they will have pretty heavy blades. This is the type of uneducated response we get from a civil engineer bureaucrat.

What has been done with the wind energy section report on the Franklin Dam alternatives? In order to knock it down the wind farm was to be located in south-west Tasmania, not in the windiest part which is north-western Tasmania. If it is to be located in that wilderness area the wilderness will have to be knocked down. It would cost $25m for site development and the knocking down of that area. It is also on the other side of Macquarie Harbour from the road so a bridge would have to be built across Macquarie Harbour at a cost of $42m. Because it is so isolated $9m would have to be paid for a camp. But the biggest cruncher of all is that here people were talking about 159 megawatts of wind power. They wanted to put in 300 megawatts of hydro back-up; in other words, twice as much hydro back-up as wind power, and that was going to cost $96m.

That was the bureaucratic approach to wind power which is absolute and utter rubbish. It is unscientific, it is unprofessional and it is intellectually dishonest. Bureaucrats, by their very nature, are conservative. They simply do not want to face anything new. They can deal with coal, and oil has been around for long enough so they can deal with that. So generally they are quite conservative. The other thing about bureaucrats is that there are job interchanges amongst them. Many bureaucrats go back and forth between industry and government. I guess in the jargon it is called going native when a bureaucrat actually takes on the role of industry more than he takes on the responsibility of the people of Australia. But there is certainly a lot of interchange and I suppose that that is understandable. If someone is an expert in a field and he works in industry and the Government needs this expertise that person will be hired by the Government. So there is a lot of commitment to existing technologies in that area.

I think one of the best indications of that is to be found in the 10 volumes of Energy 2000 which was put out by the former Department of Resources and Energy. There are a number of sections dealing with synthetic fuels, natural gas, coal, et cetera but the thinnest, scrawniest volume, which deals with renewable energy, states:
The major impediment facing most renewables is their intrinsic lack of economic viability.

People in the former Department of Resources and Energy never talked to Southern California Edison, to the Danes or to the Hawaiians. They have just come up with this because it is the traditional way of the bureaucracy responding to renewable energy. What does the former Department say about the future? It is even more grim than that. It states under the heading `Overall Outlook for Renewable Energy':
Forecasts of this nature are inherently uncertain-
that is true-
Nevertheless there would seem to be no fundamental urgency for a significant increase in renewables use in Australia to the year 2000.

With the bureaucrats not pushing it, with the former Department not pushing it, with the politicians not pushing it and with industry not pushing it, it is no wonder that we do not have very much in the way of renewables.

Why do politicians not like renewable energy? Generally, because politicians have short attention spans and they do not want to understand a system put together from a bunch of little pieces, which is what renewable energy is. Renewable energy involves a diverse contribution to the energy problem. Politicians like things that appear simple. Politicians love nuclear power because they can go to a big building and throw a switch and, wow, it all lights up. They do not care that it is the world's most complicated technology and it could not possibly exist without a whole lot of subsidies-which, incidentally, renewables do not get; they want a nice big picture of them in the paper throwing a switch on something that goes whizz, bang and looks really great. The idea of actually going out into a cow pasture and turning on a switch of a windmill, which is one of thousands scattered around the place, simply does not appeal to politicians. They cannot grasp the significance of it anyway. What do we need to do? We need to institute a new commitment to renewable resources.

talk.start.para: â€”Hear, hear!

â€”It is about time. I thought the honourable senator was asleep. The rabble opposite has been carrying on and I did not get any protection from the Chair. But I am glad that my Democrat colleagues have now entered the fray. We certainly need a new commitment to renewables because the amount of funding is decreasing all the time. Let me quote from an article in the Canberra Times dated 13 November 1987 which is headed, `$2.1m for research into renewable energy' quotes a spokeswoman for the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) as saying:

speech.para: . . . the amount being funded for solar and other renewable energy forms had decreased, one reason being that the Government had received 25 per cent fewer applications this year.

It has decreased in real terms over the years and there are two reasons why nobody is making applications. The first reason is that they know that they will get knocked back if they are still in the business of doing renewable research any- way and the second reason is that a lot of them have simply left the field because the money has been so slow in coming. I am afraid that that is a reflection both on the Government and on the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC), which was set up to manage funds for renewable energy. Unfortunately, most of its money goes into coal, synthetic fuels, and various big hit, high technologies. Very few of its priorities are for the soft options-wind and solar energies-although it spends a good deal on conservation, for which I applaud it. It is true that it is far more economical to save energy rather than producing it in any way.

NERDDC has three priority levels: high, which gets the most money; medium, which gets some money; and low, which gets very little money. The high priority level involves mainly fossil fuels along with conservation. Solar energy is only a medium priority and electric vehicles are a low priority. Of course, both of these should be promoted to the high priorities. We have seen what electric vehicles do in running from Darwin to Adelaide on solar power alone. But the new magnequench motor that General Motors has developed for the Sunraycer is a very efficient motor. It is a new technology which has not been seen before. It improves the efficiency of electric vehicles and it has definite application in commuter vehicles, so it should be a high priority. Wave, tidal, ocean, thermal, geothermal and biomass are now low, and they should be at least medium priorities. Solar's share of the general round of grants should very definitely rise.

NERDDC's image amongst the solar community is very poor. People with good solar credentials should be making the decisions on funding. NERDDC needs new blood. We should also take a look at energy accounting methods. The Energy 2000 paper says that renewables supply 6.3 per cent of Australian energy. But if we look at it in the light of the real situation, renewables supply more than 99.99 per cent of energy in Australia. That may sound like a lot, but honourable senators have to remember that renewables include photosynthesis. All our agricultural produce-I know this interests Madam Acting Deputy President-is grown by sun power. Honourable senators should consider the amount of energy it takes to run an electric clothes drier versus hanging clothes on the line. That is also solar power. I bet Senator Richardson never thought of that. He looks stunned by the revelation.

talk.start.para: â€”I will have to concede, Senator Sanders, that I had not thought of that.

â€”Yes. Solar power, in fact, does work; it works every day and we take it for granted. I think it is time we appreciated it. What are we going to do? One thing we can do is set up a fund to fill the gaps that NERDDC is now not addressing to put a new life, a new impetus into renewable energy demonstration in Australia. We do not really need any more research; the research exists. NERDDC does fund research. We actually need community programs to get the technology from the laboratory into the field to where it is needed. We should also have a mechanism whereby the community can feed back to industry and government; we should set up communication channels so that we can get renewables working in Australia. It is not happening at the moment. We need liaison; we need this knowledge from the community to be put to use.

speech.para: The Government has agreed to put a flat $5m into a trust account which, as I understand it, will be available on 1 July 1988. It is hoped that applications for these funds will start coming in on 1 January 1988. The funds will be used to take on areas that NERDDC is not now looking at and will not be used merely to offset any funds that NERDDC is now getting; in other words, NERDDC's funding should be increased. It should not be decreased in any way because of the new trust fund which is being set up.

The whole point of all this is that we are running out of oil. We do have a problem and it is time that we face it now. It is as if we are driving along a road and there is a sign ahead that says, `Bridge out'. We look down and see that there is no bridge across the river. At the moment we have our feet on the accelerator; we are just going full tilt for that bridgeless gap. It makes perfectly good sense, if we are intelligent beings-I hope that we, as politicians, can exert some leadership here, not just keep our feet on the accelerator and head over the precipice-to look ahead, exert some leadership and do something which will benefit the country not just now, but for the future.

Everyone agrees that the future at some time will be solar. Our entire society will work on renewable energy. It has to come sooner or later, why not sooner? Why not avoid the difficulties? Why not stop before we hit that precipice, before we hit that gap? It makes good sense. It is time to renew our commitment to energy independence and common sense. The Government has taken a major step towards facing the future with the resource rent tax and it has rekindled interest in renewables. Our kids will be grateful.

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: â€”In view of that recent speech, I have to read the name of the main Bill in this package of allied Bills again-it is the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill 1987. When listening to Senator Sanders, one can half understand what he means by wind power. The best description one could give of him is that he really is the Flintstone of the Senate. He would have us going back to pedalling motor cars and I do not know how he will run an aeroplane with a windmill. Senator Sanders has ignored the fact that we are talking about liquid fuels, not coal, uranium or solar power which can be used to generate electricity. One can excuse the Australian Labor Party for pursuing its resource rent tax (RRT) because, after all, it is part of its platform. I think this is the second or third time that we have spoken about this very matter. I know that the industry hoped for a long time that through discussion it would be able to get the Government to review the approach it would take, but it neglected the fact that it was part of its platform and that is what it is implementing.

speech.para: The position taken by Senator Sanders was totally unintelligible. I only hope that Senator Macklin, who will follow me, will add some sensibility to the approach taken by the Australian Democrats, which I think is beyond everyone else's comprehension. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is very fond of telling us how simple and equitable the taxation system is but, in fact, the resource rent tax is a discriminatory tax. It is a secondary tax which is a disincentive to exploration. Every Australian must know that the crude oil industry is the most heavily taxed industry in Australia. It pays about 69c in the dollar in taxation. It is not the companies that are paying this tax, it is the people of Australia. More important is the disincentive of these charges to go out and find more oil. I will come to that later.

I will give some idea of the burden the industry bears in regard to the very savage tax regime. It pays the normal corporate rate of tax of 49 per cent. It has additional secondary taxes on on-shore and established off-shore areas where the Government royalty is 10 per cent to 12.5 per cent of well head value. There is also an excise on crude oil and certain off-shore liquid petroleum gas production. We will have a resource rent tax for off-shore green fields areas. We have recently passed-it was opposed by the Liberal-National Party Opposition-cash bonus bidding legislation which applies to so-called highly prospective acreages in Australia. I think everyone is aware of the fact that `highly prospective' in Australia means very low prospective in most other countries which are oil provinces throughout the world. On top of that is the 20c a litre fuel excise tax which is paid by the motorist. The very thing that the Treasurer of this country talked about-the tax man at the petrol bowser-continues.

The so-called windfall gains from rising oil prices in the late 1970s which triggered the introduction of secondary taxes on crude oil production have disappeared, but the taxes remain. It must also be remembered that the aim of those particular taxes was so that people would conserve liquid fuels. Most people have forgotten that back in the early 1960s there was great concern amongst the then Government of Australia that we would have an enormous import bill to pay in the future unless oil was discovered in Australia. More importantly, I suppose that we would be relying on other countries for the supply of essential liquid fuels for machinery production.

During the oil shocks of the 1970s the price of Saudi Arabian light crude was in excess of $US30 a barrel. By comparison, the latest figures show that oil is now just $US17 a barrel. In real terms, adjusted for inflation, it is no higher than it was in 1973-74. The devaluation of the dollar had something to do with that. The Government refuses to give up its huge revenues from the oil industry despite the clear evidence that the industry cannot afford to pay it. In the long run it is not the oil companies or the oil industry that will suffer, it is the people of Australia.

What are the effects of the resource rent tax? The major effect is a deterrent to investment in the industry. Despite the oil price collapse, the Government continues to use the industry as a milch cow, blissfully ignoring the disastrous effects its punitive tax regime is having on the industry and Australia's economy in general. The resource rent tax and other secondary taxes, such as cash bonus bidding, are deterring oil companies from exploration at a time when there has never been a greater need to find more oil.

Australia is running out of oil. We are consuming it much faster than we can find it. In 1985 we were around 100 per cent self-sufficient in oil, but existing reserves are now expected to supply only 25 per cent of demand by the year 2000. What does this mean? It means that if by the year 2000 we are to be only 50 per cent self-sufficient, we will need to discover, the Government has estimated, another 1.8 billion barrels between now and the year 2000. The Australian petroleum export industry has calculated that $26 billion, more than $2 billion a year, would have to be spent on oil exploration and 1,400 wildcat wells would have to be drilled if we are to achieve 50 per cent self-sufficiency.

Instead of exploration increasing in Australia, the reverse is happening. I again point out that it is not a matter of people such as Senator Sanders saying, `Let us go for solar; let us go for the renewable resources'. We are talking about liquid fuels. We are talking not about fuels to run power stations but fuels to run motor cars and jet aeroplanes. I do not see any alternative other than liquid fuels. I agree that there are renewable fuels-and they have been discussed-such as cassava and sugarcane. However, they are well down the track. We can also convert coal to oil-at a price.

As I have mentioned, the number of wildcat wells drilled has dropped dramatically from 47 wells in 1983 to about 11 this year. As at the end of September, only two off-shore drilling vessels were active and three were lying idle. We cannot afford this to happen in this country and we have to look at this. Off-shore seismic activity fell by some 35 per cent in 1986 and only 3,000 kilometres were recorded in the first nine months of 1987 compared with 28,000 kilometres in 1986. The short-sightedness of this Government's revenue grabbing policies is highlighted by the policy, for instance, of the Cana- dian Government, which earlier this year announced a subsidised incentive program for exploration and development drilling. The Canadian Government provides direct funding for one-third of the cost of a well up to a maximum of $Can3.3m a year for each qualifying company. In other words, the Canadian Government recognises the importance of the continued supply of liquid fuels into its economy.

The Australian oil company Crusader Oil NL has moved its exploration operations to Canada rather than persist in Australia and it has blamed the Hawke Government's neglect of the industry for its move. Also, the Australian petroleum industry estimates that other Australian companies have spent more than $100m acquiring overseas exploration acreage and a further $60m on exploration activity in other countries in the past 12 months.

The resource rent tax is an added disincentive to exploration in a country which, as I have already said, is a high risk country with a high cost environment. Despite what the Government says, Australia is not a prospective country and I think that fact is well recognised by the departmental officers who put together the Energy 2000 report. It never has been; it never will be. We were very fortunate to discover the Bass Strait basin. Most people will realise that back in the 1960s that was a wildcat well. It was not thought to be a prospective area. Recently Esso Australia Ltd revised downwards its assessment of crude oil discovery potential by some 25 per cent. It believes that only about 3 billion barrels of oil may be left to be found. This is a very paltry figure when compared with oil reserves of other countries. For example, the United States of America has 34.5 billion barrels, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics 42 billion barrels, Mexico 48 billion barrels, the United Kingdom 13.2 billion barrels, while in the Middle East Saudi Arabia has 166 billion barrels. I repeat that according to Esso's estimates, Australia has 3 billion barrels of oil reserves. So what we must be doing in this country is providing incentives for people to drill wells and look for oil and, hopefully, find some, because if we do not, it is estimated that in about 1992 our oil import bill will be in the order of $3 billion and by 1995 it will be about $5 billion.

The Government's justification for secondary tax is that petroleum resources are community property and that the whole community should share returns from those resources. Certainly the resources we have in our country belong to the people of this country. No one would deny that. The point is: do we want them discovered? Reserves are resources only if they can be found and developed. It is no good having what we think might be reserves if people are not prepared to risk money-it is a high risk venture-to find out. Using secondary taxes at the most opportune time in our history is killing the potential golden goose which may lay the golden egg for Australians. If the oil industry is prevented, by silly, stupid taxation, from exploring the finding new reserves, the community, far from sharing in returns from oil, will pay dearly for imports.

I think Senator Sanders said that he had made a deal with the Government whereby some $5m of resource rent money would go into alternative energy research. I am not sure whether that is what he meant or whether that is what he said; it was very difficult to follow him. But if he did mean that, what is the use-the Government is well aware of this fact, which would be the reason it would be only too happy to accommodate the honourable senator-of 100 per cent of nothing? That is what we could be looking at down the track.

The National Institute of Economic and Industry Research has produced some figures which show the disastrous effects the looming oil drought will have on our balance of payments. The Institute found that a massive crude oil bill will result in a deterioration in the current account deficit of $14 billion, in 1996 prices, by the middle of the next decade. To put it another way, the additional current account burden from this oil bill is equal to 2.3 per cent of gross domestic product, about the same reduction in the current account deficit which is now necessary if Australia is to return to any realistic debt servicing ratio and keep its foreign debt manageable. Even if the country manages to improve its balance of payments, which is highly unlikely, the additional burden of paying for our oil imports will return the nation to square one in the mid-1990s. That is what we are looking at.

The other point I make is that this tax is not a profit-based tax as it allows a deduction for exploration costs only in the immediate vicinity of the project, whereas in a percentage business such as exploration, all exploration costs can be considered attributable to the rare discovery that pays off.

My colleague Senator Durack has foreshadowed moving some amendments at the committee stage, and I think this is what we are really talking about. Discussions were held within both the industry and various political parties as to what could be done to correct the grossly inequitable situation. Under this current RRT deductions can be allowed on the resource rent tax only in a particular permit area. In other words, for drilling exploration holes outside that permit area there can be no deduction from RRT as it applies to that permit area.

It was hoped that the Government would see the wisdom in allowing deductions for exploration outside a particular permit area as an encouragement for people to drill holes in those places. In the absence of that, it was decided that an attempt would be made to convince the Government at least to look at the possibility of allowing a 50 per cent tax deduction on money spent exploring areas outside the permit area and, in the event of oil being discovered, to allow a 100 per cent deduction. Our understanding is that that will not be supported by the Australian Democrats. As I said earlier, it has nothing to do with the oil companies, it is a matter of people getting out there with the risk capital and being prepared to spend the money to drill holes so that Australia can at least move in the direction of some sort of self-sufficiency. Unless we move in that direction, the next generation of young Australians will look back and say, `Why did those clowns do that back in those days? Why did they introduce a disincentive? Why are we now paying around $5 billion for imports because a disincentive was introduced in 1987 or 1988?'

The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association has indicated that we face a bill of some $26 billion for exploration if we are to be 50 per cent self-sufficient in liquid fuels by the year 2000. If, in a country that is not recognised as an oil province, we implement legislation such as this which says, in effect, `If you find oil and, if you find more than we think you will, we will hit you with a punitive tax', what effect will that have on the prospectivity of discovering liquid fuels? I mention liquid fuels because one would have thought from the remarks of the previous speaker, Senator Sanders, that we were not speaking about them at all. If he was speaking about them, he was talking some nonsense about being able to use an alternative fuel to fly aeroplanes. I do not know how one would fly a jet without liquid fuels. Maybe he has got some--

talk.start.para: â€”Maybe he found out when he was in Russia.
â€”I thank Senator Durack. Maybe he has some Flintstone method of doing that.
â€”Have you not heard of the use of hydrogen?
â€”I am delighted to hear Senator Coulter. Here is someone who is proposing the hydrogen car. I thought that theory was debunked a few years ago. I have heard of hydrogen.
â€”I have heard of somebody else who supported that.
â€”That is right. We now have the new Democrats supporting us.
â€”Don't you know that it does work? There are cars using hydrogen power.

â€”There are cars using hydrogen gas. Of course, it is not just a matter of saying one does not have the key. I recapitulate that we are running short of oil. We are running short of liquid fuels. We need to create an incentive in this country, a country which is not known for its prospectivity for oil, for more people to go out and drill more holes. If we do not, it is only a matter of less than a decade when we will be adding to our import bill somewhere between $3 billion and $5 billion a year. The people who will be responsible for that will be members of this Government, with the support of the Australian Democrats.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The last time the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill 1987 and allied Bills were before the Senate, they were defeated on the combined vote of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. At that stage my party gave its reasons why it did not wish to support the Bills. As the Senate will remember, our reasons were quite different from those given by the Opposition parties. The Opposition parties took a position that Senator Durack again has outlined in regard to these Bills.

speech.para: Unlike the Opposition parties, our position was that the Bills were not sufficiently hard to take back from the oil companies that which we believed belonged to the people of Australia as the owners of the resource. It is a philosophical position with which, seemingly, the Opposition does not agree. Nevertheless, it has been our proposition throughout the debates on this legislation that petroleum, as a resource, is owned by the people of this country. It is mined and exploited by private companies, but there is a requirement to pay for the ownership of that resource in the form of some method of taxation, and that money should be returned to the people by way of that taxation regime.

Until relatively recently the taxation regime was based on a combination of excise and royalties. That, of course, is the possible fall-back position for the Government with regard to its taxing regime if the resource rent tax fails to go through. I am sure that Senator Durack would agree that, for all the opposition by the oil companies to the resource rent tax, if the choice is between that tax and a combination of royalty and excise, quite clearly the oil companies will opt for the resource rent tax.

Since the earlier debate on these Bills we have had a number of discussions with the Government in regard to a number of items. One of those concerned the impact of the resource rent tax and the amount of tax which is likely to be raised by it. We have been convinced that the take from the resource rent tax will, in fact, be greater than we first anticipated. While it is a shaded tax and does not meet a number of the other criteria which are in our party policy, we believe that it is a better form of taxation and that it comes closer to what we would be looking for than does the previous regime. Hence there are not many options left with regard to the implementation of our policy.

One matter which figured in Senator Sanders's comments in the previous debate was the lack of thrust of this Government and previous governments in regard to alternative or renewable energy sources. The Government, in reviewing its policy in this area, has agreed with us and is now seeking at least to make some move in that direction. I agree with Senator Durack that the move is relatively minor.

talk.start.para: â€”It is a much more logical development.

â€”Yes; I will go on to make some comments about that. Of course, it is in addition to the moneys that have already been made available through a variety of other sources. We have a proposition in regard to the additional sums, which hopefully, the Government will take some note of. I must admit that our interest at this point lies more on the development side than it does on the research side. We would be looking for some type of demonstration of the viability of development processes. Many of them are viable and are operating as viable commercial enterprises in other countries. That could be done here if it were done in a way that was reasonable and acceptable.

speech.para: I raise a point in regard to part of my own State. I refer to the islands of the Torres Strait. Many of those islands are very small and, obviously, have only a small need for energy. Nevertheless, on some of those islands every house has ended up being equipped with a diesel. Anyone who has ever been on those islands at night when the lights go on and every house sets up its diesel would know that it sounds like a large jumbo jet coming in to land. It is extraordinary when we think of the enormous amount of sunlight that falls on the islands. At last there is a project under way to equip one of the islands, Banana Island, with a source of energy based on solar power. That, hopefully, will demonstrate to the people of the other islands that there are more acceptable, cheaper, more economical and less intrusive ways of dealing with the energy problem in their locality.

Another interesting example from my own State is the operation of the Gladstone power station and the insatiable desire of the Queensland Government, among others, to centralise electricity power generation at one point. A power station owned by the Roma Town Council and employing local people used to be operated at Roma. That station, which ran on a very good contract negotiated with the natural gas supplier, was an admirable way of providing the people of Roma with their electricity-and, of course, of making a profit, thereby lowering the rates for the citizens of Roma. The Queensland Government closed down that power station and the people had to get their electricity from the grid at Gladstone. Unfortunately, this move was completed just before a number of power strikes took place. As a result, Roma ended up having its first power cuts for as long as anybody could remember. But that is beside the point. The point is, as was stated by Senator Sanders, that decisions about the use of power are often made by governments. They are often made not in terms of the most efficient or effective method of providing power or the long term viability of the power source.

As Senator Parer mentioned, the Bills before us are directed at oil exploration effort. One problem with which we are confronted is that the use of oil depends also on the propositions that I have raised. Without a doubt the cheapest way of acquiring additional energy is conservation. Innumerable studies have been done but, unfortunately, they have been carried out mainly in the United States of America. I want to make some points later about the work done here in Australia. One study carried out in the United States on the efficient use of energy turned up figures which illustrate the sorts of savings that can be made in our total use of non-renewable resources, let alone starting on the development of renewable resources. The study states:
. . . energy use in residential and commercial buildings could have been about one-fifth of the actual amount recorded without loss of comfort or amenities.
That is, if the most efficient methods of use had been employed. It continues:
Similarly, transportation energy-
I draw this to the attention of Senator Parer, who was wondering about the aircraft and so on-
use could have been down by 70% for the same number of passenger miles travelled and ton-mile of goods moved.
Let us remember that this is American research. It continues:
The industrial output . . . could have been produced with about 40% of the energy actually used.

The figures in that study, even if one wanted to be conservative and halve them or even take only about one-tenth of them, would provide a staggering cost saving to the community. When talking about the insatiable need for more oil, we must remember to consider the cost-benefit arrangement. Surely, in any industry, in any business, one does not seek to squander as much as one can. Presumably, one seeks to use the resource that one has in as economical a way as possible. But I do not believe that is being done. Oddly enough, the moves that were made after the energy crunch do not seem to have been maintained. That is a pity, particularly when one looks at industrialised countries. Certainly, there are some pretty good examples around the world of countries which have sought to conserve non-renewables by more efficient use. But Australia has been sadly lacking in its efforts.

The issue of renewable energy resources is attractive to many people, but is often put down. The former Department of Resources and Energy put out Discussion Paper No. 6, March 1986, entitled Energy 2000 Policy Review. A whole range of documents have been put out on this subject; there were 10 at that stage. This is the slimmest volume and, unfortunately, it has the least amount of good material in it. However, I think its stance will explain its size. It states:
From this standpoint-
that is, the general approach that has gone before in this paper-

there seem to be no urgent decisions to be made with respect to renewables, either by the Commonwealth or state governments, which will have a substantial impact on the nature of overall Australian energy demand. From both price and resource-depletion aspects, there does not seem to be a compelling argument for government initiatives in the market to encourage the development of renewables.
Senator Durack may know how difficult it is in discussion to get a government to move anywhere when it is confronted with a stance like that.

Interestingly enough, we live in a continent in which many of our population could successfully generate their own power. This would result in a significant lowering or containment of costs in areas in which we have been seeking to do that for a long time. I refer particularly to rural industries. The work that has been done in Australia into applying overseas and locally generated research to Australian conditions, particularly rural conditions, has demonstrated clearly that the material is available; promotional work has been done. But, without the co-operation of governments-the quote I have just given suggests just how unco-operative governments are likely to be in this area-there does not seem to be much support for the rural sector to take up alternative power methods which could save a considerable amount of money, whether they be based on direct solar energy or indirect solar energy such as wind or, more particularly, biomass.

The various methods that are available are relatively well known and Australia is fairly well placed with regard to most of them. But, without the policy-makers taking an interest in this area and without there being substantial funding, it is unlikely that Australia will make much progress. If I juxtapose here the considerable amount of money that Australia has spent over the years on nuclear research with the incredibly little amount it has spent on renewable energy resources, I think one can see that the final policy position now is that, although we have a research operation and we have spent money in this area, we will not be using nuclear power in Australia. Luckily, we have gained a few useful spinoffs for the community from this source in a number of small areas, particularly in the area of medicine. Without going into that matter, I think it is a pity that the policy decisions that are made concentrate on the non-renewables, as is again the case in this area. We have yet to see a sizable legislative initiative in the area of non-renewable resources.

A number of factors were involved in the discussion of these Bills. One factor was in relation to how close this piece of legislation was to a resource rent tax or profit-based tax. Senator Durack's amendments were, of course, canvassed extensively. I refer to the problems surrounding deductibility. It seems to me that there are problems with the Bill in that regard. However, for reasons which will become obvious, I do not find acceptable the way in which the Opposition has sought to amend the Bill. I point out that the propositions that could be acceptable, such as that some added deductibility be made available for areas in the same basin, do present enormously complex problems-certainly, problems which were beyond the drafting abilities that we had available to us.

It was at that point that the alternative proposition of 50 per cent deductibility and the more extensive exercise-the one that the Opposition previously removed in the House of Representatives, concerning total deductibility-obviously had to be taken into account. In the end it did not seem to us that any of those achieved what we were trying to achieve-that is, to look at a method of deductibility which would have made the operations with regard to exploration somewhat more rational. Since we failed successfully to draft amendments which would have encompassed that point, and since the Government indicated that it was totally unwilling to accept any such amendments anyway-and would, in fact, look to move back to the old excise and royalties proposition-it did not seem to us politic to continue down that line. Therefore, there were very few propositions to consider at the end of that discussion.

From our discussion with the various exploration companies, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association and the various groups as they came to see us, it was obvious that there was a divergence of views. I think it would not be too far off the mark to suggest that the divergence of views was based on the commercial interests of the various groups which talked to us, and their exploration propositions. Hence, if one looks around Australia at the exercises and exploration that are currently being undertaken, and the possibilities for the future with regard to various mining leases which are controlled by the various companies, one could easily discover on which side of the argument of any of these propositions a particular company would be. Our view, after all of those discussions was that there did not seem to be an alternative to what the Government was proposing that would provide a rational way of dealing with the issue-and I do not believe that the excise and royalties method is a rational way of dealing with the issue-which would still recognise the basic policy point which I have addressed in this speech; that is the philosophical point of the ownership of these resources by the people of Australia and the need to return, through some tax regime, a reasonable amount to those people.

The previous Fraser Government increased the tax on petrol by pegging the price of petrol to the world parity price. At the time, one of the reasons given for that operation, other than its being a very good revenue source, was to try to dampen energy usage. We have always thought that there are two other ways which have been neglected, and which I raise today. One is the undertaking of immediate, extensive and intensive research and development. Indeed, at that time-I am not quite sure how many years ago it was-we raised in the debate the need for the additional revenue that was gained from that world parity pricing policy to be allocated to the renewable energy resource research and development program. That did not happen. I have also raised the other way-that is, an education program in our community, in order to look at ways in which we are able to conserve energy. Rather than simply imposing a penalty, we should also work constructively with the community-with architects, builders and community groups-to demonstrate how, in the use of energy for heating, cooling and water cooling, there are ways in which every householder is able to take steps to assist in the general conservation of energy.

I, like Senator Durack and Senator Parer, am concerned that, in the medium term, we are faced with an enormously difficult problem. As our oil runs out, undoubtedly, without the development of renewable resources, we will be faced with ever increasing imports and ever increasing costs. At some stage, of course, it will dawn on somebody in government that now is the time to put vast amounts of money into the exercise of renewables. It has been demonstrated that it is possible to turn over to that sector of the energy generating industry-that is, the renewables-a whole host of domestic requirements. Indeed, publicity around Australia has been given in the last couple of years to people in urban residences cutting themselves off from the urban electricity supply, in other words, making themselves energy independent. We know that this is possible. The costs, of course, are still too high for most householders to contemplate. But those costs are partly a function of demand and partly a function of the capacity of the various companies to come up with an acceptable product. In the last 12 months the quality of such products which are available in domestic areas has improved in leaps and bounds. What we now need is quantity. If we move into producing such goods in quantity, we will see a rapid price reduction, which will provide the best incentive for householders to become more energy independent. I am not saying that overnight we are able to move from non-renewables to renewables. Obviously, that is not the case. If that were the case it would have occurred long ago. There are still major handicaps to being able to do so. What Senator Sanders said, and what I am saying, is that unless we start an intensive program we will not be able to do the things we are capable of doing now, nor will we be in a position to apply the research as it becomes available to us. It is that approach we recommend.

It is interesting to note that countries that are nowhere near as lucky as we are with regard, for example, to solar power are nevertheless developing technologies far more extensively than we are. We are catching up, but in many cases the work that is now being done in Australia is, unfortunately, being done under lease, which adds to our export costs. We have the research base here in Australia. Some tremendous work is currently being done. What we need now is a promotional exercise by the Government to interest the wider community in the possibilities that exist, thereby generating a climate for further development.

Whilst people may wave their arms and make predictions that one per cent or 10 per cent, or whatever it is, is able to be achieved I instance the development of the motor car. When one compares the early motor car, which appeared at the beginning of this century, with the motor car available now, one notes the extraordinary difference between them, although they do much the same thing, that is, take people from A to B. The developments have been brought about by market pressure, which might appeal to the Opposition parties. As market pressure built up research took place, innovation occurred and new developments came on to the market. The developments occurred as a result of the market being there, as a result of people seeking new items, better efficiencies, greater power, more comfort and the ability to start the car without getting out in the rain. All of the things we take for granted now in cars came about as a result of market pressure. I am suggesting a very similar operation with regard to renewables. Without the market operating in Australia there will be very little pressure and all the predictions we make will be as nought. If we get the market going, as the pressure occurs the research will come about to satisfy the demands and we will have much greater progress in this area than we have had to date.
