debate.title:
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1987
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX BILL 1987
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX (INTEREST ON UNDERPAYMENTS) BILL 1987
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1987

proctext.para: Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”Before dinner we had established that the Australian Democrats will be voting with the Government in support of this petroleum resource rent tax legislation, even though they recognise that in the medium term-at least Senator Macklin, in a rational if nonetheless unreasonable speech, conceded that it was in the medium term-there is nothing in what they are recommending that will solve the clear problem emerging for the Australian economy as a result of Australia running out of oil without further exploration. At least Senator Macklin recognises the existence of a problem, even though he has no solution to that problem. It is extraordinary that in that context the Australian Democrats have now conceded, through Senator Sanders from Tasmania-Sanders of the River; how could I forget?-by way of interjection, that the Democrats' policy on oil was not to have any further exploration and to leave oil in the ground-I cannot say for some future use, because he is opposed to its extraction and use and their policy is simply to leave it in the ground.

speech.para: It is bad enough for the Australian Democrats to have adopted this approach at a time when we are facing a medium term, and, of course, long term energy crisis and certainly a crisis involving the enormous cost of oil imports that will result from Australia's failure to maintain anything like an acceptable level of exploration and discovery of oil. But it is even worse that the Government is actually introducing this legislation anyway. The reason it is introducing the legislation is for short term gain, short term benefit, to try to resolve its immediate budgetary problems. This was revealed in effect in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 22 October, which stated: The Federal Government has doubled its expectations of earnings from the proposed new Resource Rent Tax which is to be applied to new offshore oil discoveries'. The resource rent tax will now earn `at least $100 million' by next financial year. It was previously estimated that the revenue from the resource rent tax would not be seen until 1990-91, when it would have amounted to only about $20m.

So now we see why the Government is persisting with this legislation. It is for short term benefit-to the long term disadvantage of Australia. I suppose it is reasonable for the Labor Government to take that approach. After all, it will not have to cope with the long term problems it is creating, because it will not be in government to do so. But what it is doing here is grabbing, in the next financial year, $100m in revenue and costing the Australian economy, according to independent research from universities, billions of dollars of foreign exchange because of the impact that this legislation will clearly have on the search for oil in Australia.

The background to this is very simple. For the past 10 years Australia has been consuming more oil than it has been discovering. In the period from 1977 to 1986 Australia's consumption totalled almost two billion barrels against discoveries of about only 830 million barrels. So there we have almost 2 1/2 times as much consumption as discovery. Demand for crude oil and condensate in Australia is forecast by the Federal Government itself to rise from about 560,000 barrels a day last year to 680,000 barrels a day within about five years. Once again we can see an enormous increase in consumption which, of course, is not being met by production. Production of crude oil and concentrates in Australia from existing fields is forecast by the Government once again to fall from 546,000 barrels a day, which is close to our current consumption, to 280,000 barrels a day in five years-in other words, to something like a third of our consumption. We will have to discover an awful lot more oil to solve that problem; otherwise we will be importing enormous quantities of oil at enormous cost. New discoveries are estimated by the Federal Government to add something like 80,000 barrels a day to production within five years, but, according to the forecast, this will leave Australia with something like a 50 per cent chance of having to import 320,000 barrels of crude oil a day by then. The cost of importing crude oil at this level will be about $3 billion-provided that there is an exchange rate of about US70c to one Australian dollar and an oil price of about $US18 a barrel-and, given those assumptions, we shall then have an immense burden, within five years, of $3 billion a year.

Nothing that this Government is doing will do anything to encourage a sufficient pick-up in the search for oil to offset that problem. We can see what happened in 1987. Only seven wildcat wells were drilled in the first nine months of 1987, compared with 19 wells in the same period in 1986. At the end of September 1987, there were only two off-shore drilling vessels active, and three were sitting idle. We see here the disastrous consequences of a combination of lower oil prices and perhaps a market crash-although it had not crashed by September, and since then there will be even less chance of getting equity capital and other funds-but, mainly, the Government's policies and indecisions, and concern about Government policies. In the first nine months of this year, off-shore seismic activity fell by 35 per cent compared to the same period of the previous year. In the first nine months of this year, only 3,000 kilometres of seismic activity were recorded, compared with 20,000 kilometres in 1986. In other words, there has been something like an 85 per cent cut in seismic activity.

The outlook for the off-shore exploration industry should be of major concern to the Federal Government, and that has been pointed out by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association. The need for this concern is the growing gap between crude oil production and consumption and the assessment that off-shore sedimentary basins have the most potential for providing significant additions to Australian oil reserves, and that is exactly where this exploration should be concentrated. In fact, this legislation is aimed specifically against the very area where our only chances of real success exist.

The problem is that the resource rent tax is being defended by people saying that it is simply to replace excise that goes everywhere else. This defence is simply basically untrue. The excise and the resource rent tax do not replace anything. They are both new secondary taxes that did not exist in 1983 and did not exist when there was a level of exploration off-shore in Australia that enabled significant discoveries to be made. This is a brand new tax, introduced by this Government. To pretend that it somehow replaces an existing tax is simply false, deceptive, misleading and typical of the nature of the debate undertaken by this Government. Certainly, this Government has introduced an on-shore excise, which I believe has done nothing to assist on-shore exploration. To introduce an off-shore tax and say that it is a much better tax than we might otherwise have had would at least be an honest way to do it. But the Government is saying that it is a better tax than the one it is replacing. It is not replacing any tax; it is replacing perhaps the prospect of a different kind of tax-the prospect only. This Government is introducing new taxes at a time when what is needed is even greater incentive.

APEA has pointed out that off-shore petroleum taxes, including the resource rent tax, the new oil excise and cash bonus bidding for off-shore acreage, together with high company taxes and high finding costs, act to depress exploration except in the most prospective areas. That has already happened. The statistics show a dramatic reduction in off-shore oil exploration-the one type of exploration we desperately need. As APEA says, it is a fundamental requirement of the Federal Government to give greater encouragement to off-shore exploration than at present. This is a major failure of Government policy. It is no wonder there has been a decline. As has been pointed out repeatedly, the impending decline in Australia's production and in self-sufficiency will have important ramifications for Australia's balance of payments, for Government revenues and for security of supply. As an APEA publication pointed out recently, the former Department of Resources and Energy established that each percentage point fall in Australia's level of self-sufficiency means about 2.1 million barrels of additional crude oil imports are needed, at an annual cost of $58m. However, Government revenues from crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas excise and royalties in 1990-91 can be expected to fall to half the $2.37 billion that was raised in 1986-87.

The obvious solution is to find more crude oil. That is what we are suggesting. If, instead of hitting the exploration industry with an effective 70 per cent tax rate, which is what this legislation does, the Government got rid of this additional tax and hit it just with the normal taxes-the company taxes and the other taxes that the industry has to pay-there would be greater encouragement to produce more oil and therefore it would give the Government more revenue. In fact, lowering the tax rate to a reasonable level, instead of the penal level of 70 per cent, would result in more oil being produced and therefore, quaintly, more revenue for this Government. More importantly, it would save us from the disastrous balance of payments impact of having to import more and more oil when in fact we are not able to produce anything like our requirements in the next few years.

speech.speaker: Knowles Sen S.C.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish this evening to talk on the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill 1987 and allied Bills. This legislation, I believe, symbolises the real short-sightedness and blinkered ideology of both the Hawke Government and the Australian Democrats because what we are up against is an attitude that the oil industry, and its exploration arm in particular, are there to be farmed as a source of taxation revenue. I am rather pleased that my colleague Senator Michael Baume had at least a few minutes after the dinner break to talk on the legislation without the incessant interjections from Senator Sanders who, sadly for Senator Michael Baume, sits in very close proximity. Senator Sanders made a ludicrous contribution to the debate today.
â€”I wonder where he is now.

â€”That is a very good question. I presume he is still at dinner or he has gone to bed-one or the other. Senator Sanders made the most outrageous accusation during his speech this afternoon. In the first instance, he accused Senator Durack of not using his full time, when we disagree with the legislation. We have all become used to listening to absurdities from the Democrats but this really touched on the unbelievable. There are a number of reasons why Senator Durack and many of the Opposition senators are not using their full time at the moment. They are virtually all attributable to the Democrats and their behaviour, particularly their behaviour of last week. We have a number of Bills to get through before this Parliament rises at the end of this week. But the Democrats insist on getting up at a certain time. They will not sit late; they will not sit any extra days. Yet in the last week they have monopolised the broadcast time. The moment the broadcasting lights go on in this chamber the Democrats go into an absolute verbal frenzy. That was exactly what we saw last week. They called nine divisions on the last broadcast day when they were the only ones to vote for their absolutely absurd amendments.
â€”How much time did we waste? About 1 1/2 hours.

â€”That is correct; we did waste about 1 1/2 hours because the Democrats decided that they were going to call all these outrageous divisions. Added to that, Senator Haines on television this morning had the audacity to say that one of the things she has been able to curb in her 10 years in the Senate is her temper. We can all have a good old chuckle about that because we all saw the effects of her temper last week when she called divisions and quorums for the rest of the day, expressing her glee. No, not her glee but her temper.
â€”She must have thought it was April Fool's Day.

â€”She would be an April Fool every day of the year. The Democrats not only called unnecessary divisions, but they also called quorums constantly. Whilst continually wasting the time of the Senate, the Democrats were not even here last Thursday night to keep the Senate sitting.
â€”I rise on a point of order. I remind the honourable senator that she is not addressing the point at issue at all.

â€”Speaking to the point of order, I point out that I am addressing the debate that has gone on here before because I am trying to illustrate the absolutely despicable way in which Senator Sanders has contributed to this debate and, at the same time, retaliate to some of the accusations he has made.
â€”There is no point of order. Carry on, Senator Knowles.

â€”Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I will continue because I think this debate on the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Bill is particularly important. The problems that we are facing this evening are compounded by an ideology that implicitly regards the oil industry as exploitative and its profits as illegitimate. This is an ideology to which the Democrats hold so strongly that they rejected this Bill in the last Parliament. Why? Because it did not go far enough.
â€”We thought it was unwise. We can think of a better alternative.

â€”It was not because the Democrats thought it was unwise at all. It was simply because they thought it did not go far enough. Senator McLean was not even here in the last Parliament so I think it is rather unwise of him even to interject in the first instance. Hopefully, for the rest of us, he will not be here in the next Parliament.

speech.para: We have every reason for concern that the Bill may now pass at the price of further provisions that will drive more nails into the coffin of the off-shore exploration industry. The Opposition believes that the community is entitled to a fair return from the profits of resource industries through royalties and the standard rate of company taxation paid by all business enterprises. Where we differ strongly from the Government and the Democrats is that we believe that the primary objective of a responsible Federal government is to increase energy self-sufficiency as a higher priority than the safeguarding of a useful revenue source.

This legislation increases the taxation strait-jacket on the oil industry and therefore can only discourage the exploration as the key to arresting a rapid decline in oil self-sufficiency. We must remember that if there is a decline in oil self-sufficiency then we will all suffer. As my colleagues have said previously today, we suffer in terms of the sheer price of oil. Senator Sanders yet again said that we should be looking at other forms of energy. What he failed to remember was simply the Bill that he was meant to be debating. When he was talking about nothing being done about other forms of energy, he was wrong yet again. The Queensland Government and the Coconut Island solar electric project have done a lot to look on other forms of energy, as have the Northern Territory Government and the business sector of Western Australia. So we must remember that this evening we are talking about liquid fuels.

The Opposition is convinced that common sense demands that a $3 billion loss in foreign exchange through oil imports by 1992 must be the central economic issue of this whole question. The question that the Government fails to ask is: How can we best structure a tax regime to encourage oil exploration as a major national priority? Instead I suppose that at best we can only conclude that the Government's starting point is: How can we extract the best possible revenue return from the oil well and the petrol bowser without killing the goose? I believe that that is simply not good enough. We must be looking at the broader aspect of this whole topic. Let there be no question that Australia faces a spiralling oil import bill unless major new reserves are discovered.

On 16 March this year the former Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) admitted that oil production from Bass Strait would be halved by 1990 and that Australia's oil self-sufficiency would decline from 95 per cent to 40 per cent. Effectively, only two years away, our self-sufficiency will go from 95 per cent to 40 per cent. Every percentage point off oil self-sufficiency means another 2.1 million barrels imported at a cost of $58m. By the turn of the century the shortfall will reach 390,000 barrels per day and the cost to our balance of payments will be $4.5 billion. The economic consequences of this drain and the decline in the local oil industry may dwarf our current problems.

According to the Victorian Department of Industry, Technology and Resources, a 60 per cent shortfall in energy in the year 2000 will mean a $7.7 billion decline in gross domestic product on 1980 prices and a fall in manufacturing output of $2.8 billion. It will mean the loss of 225,000 jobs and a fall in wage rates of $24 per week, adjusted for inflation. The Government and, I suppose, the Democrats, believe in job creation, in keeping everyone in jobs and in keeping everyone on a reasonable rate of salary and income, yet we are being faced with 225,000 jobs being knocked out and relative wage rates being reduced by $24 per week.

We should not lose sight of the fact that declining self-sufficiency in liquid fuels will involve an ominous dependence on overseas supplies from volatile and unstable parts of the world. The Democrats in particular would do well to remember, before they denigrate the Western alliance, that we will need to guarantee our sea lanes. I reiterate that these facts are not in serious dispute and that the Government has no excuse for failing to encourage oil exploration instead of slugging it with taxation. That is all that is being done at the moment. This industry is being hit time and again. I will talk later about the way in which this industry has been hit not only in taxation on its production but also in taxation in other forms via the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax.

Spending on oil exploration has declined 54 per cent since 1985 when, to maintain self-sufficiency, we needed to discover fresh reserves at the rate of 120 million barrels a year with the average over the last 15 years being only 75 million barrels. Last year, the Bureau of Mineral Resources estimated that there could be undiscovered reserves of three billion to five billion barrels, some four billion barrels having been discovered since 1950, and that the greatest potential lay off-shore. This may sound encouraging but the facts are that these reserves must be sought over an area of six million square kilometres. In comparison, estimated undiscovered reserves in the North Sea of 15 billion barrels need be sought over only 0.7 million square kilometres.

Only a couple of weeks ago we learned that Esso Australia Ltd has lowered its early estimates of undiscovered reserves by 25 per cent to a most likely three billion barrels. It is also reported that this downward revision is greater than the Government expected, yet it still proceeds with this legislation. In all sanity, when a company such as Esso has given those types of estimates, why would a government persist with this legislation? It is highly significant that Esso considers that the remaining reserves are in smaller pools than was previously thought when this legislation provides concessions only for contiguous permit areas. With new discoveries on this estimate we may still have 47 per cent self-sufficiency in the year 2000, otherwise it will be a mere 25 per cent in the year 2000. It is as simple as that. That is what we are looking at and that is what this Government and the Australian Democrats refuse to address.

The facts are that Australia does not have the strong geological database that makes exploration in many overseas countries a far more attractive prospect. The Hawke Government also forgets that exploration costs are much greater than in countries within our own region. The cost of operating a drill ship is 78 per cent higher than in a place such as Indonesia and the cost of a standby boat is 275 per cent higher. Altogether, it costs an extra $1.3m to drill a 35-day well off Australia than is the case in Indonesia or Malaysia.

Essentially, the exploration industry depends on risk capital. The recent collapse of stock market prices is likely to have a long term effect on those companies which engage in risk taking and cannot guarantee a steady return. Investors need to be able to look forward to the chance of what this Labor Government and the Democrats might term a windfall profit if they are to commit capital to an uncertain and immensely expensive exercise. The Government should recognise that these sources of capital are likely to diminish in the aftermath of the stock market crash and should review its tax measures. I believe that that should, in fact, be starting with this Bill. But, sadly, that is obviously not going to be the case.

I do not think it is at all convincing for the Government to claim that this 40 per cent resource rent tax (RRT) does not actually increase the imposition on oil companies as it replaces an existing excise and royalty system. This argument ignores the broader question that taxes on the oil industry are too high and a major factor in discouraging exploration. The fact is that pre-1975 oil pays tax at the total rate of 91 per cent. While we may agree that this old oil should make a higher contribution to revenue than the profits from new ventures, a figure of 91 per cent tax speaks for itself. It naturally restricts the ability of the producers to channel profits into exploration. Surely that is what we should be encouraging? But, no, it is quite the reverse. We are looking at slugging them with a 91 per cent tax rate on pre-1975 oil. With this legislation so-called new oil will be taxed at the rate of nearly 70 per cent when the resource rent tax is superimposed over company tax and other impositions. In contrast, we should recognise that in the United States oil producers are taxed at the rate of 45 per cent and in Canada at 39 per cent-45 per cent and 39 per cent compared with Australia at 91 per cent for the old oil and 70 per cent for the new oil. No other industry in Australia pays as much in both primary and secondary taxes, contributing some $7 billion to revenue.

Over the last 10 years the oil industry has contributed 12 per cent of Federal Government revenue. At the final point of sale the Government's share of the price of a litre of petrol is 58 per cent, with 51 per cent of that 58 per cent going to the Federal Government. At the same time, we should remember that 75 per cent of petroleum products are business inputs and that the Federal Government tax binge not only discourages exploration but also has a constant inflationary effect on the productive economy, so that every time the Government raises the cost of fuel it impinges on every other industry that uses fuel. But that is all a bit too simplistic for this Government to understand. It keeps raising the price of fuel.

This Government made a promise in 1983 when it was elected. In 1984, after it had broken its promise not to have an early election, it again promised us cheaper fuel. We have not seen a reduction in the price of fuel-rather, quite the reverse-since the day this Government took office.

The resource rent tax cannot be considered in isolation. Australia has a high rate of corporate taxation-49 per cent-and such Labor innovations as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax impact heavily on the oil exploration industry. This industry has suffered through the short-sightedness of a government that cannot, for the life of it, understand why it needs to employ people in remote areas, why it needs to pay people who work in remote areas special benefits and why it needs to give people general benefits to get them to work in these areas. The capital gains tax hits the profits made by farm-outs and sole risk operations in the oil exploration industry. In a wider sense, it further discourages individual investors in speculative activity where large capital profits must offset the risk.

Coupled with the resource rent tax is the cash bidding system, about which I spoke earlier this year. An analogy is bidding for a horse in a sweep and then giving 40 per cent of the winnings to the Government, because it is about the same odds. When the question is asked why only a handful of 43 Australian drilling rigs are working in Australian waters, the taxation policies of this Government are an obvious answer. While we have had to wait until this year for this legislation, the prospect of the resource rent tax has been an inhibiting factor since 1984. Three years ago the industry had this tax hanging over its head.

It is a matter of record that after a previous Labor Minister had done his best to strangle our resource industry, the Fraser Liberal Government, in its seven years in office, saw oil exploration spending rise from $80m to more than $1,000m. Yet this Government has the audacity still to blame the Fraser Government for deficiencies. I wish that this Government could suffer the same deficiency, so to speak, in this field, because we would then see oil exploration going ahead instead of backwards.

In the Fraser Government period, new oil fields attracted no tax other than royalties and company tax. Look at what they attract today. The Opposition will ensure, in government, that future oil discoveries will attract a total top tax rate of 49.25 per cent, a significant difference from the 70 per cent the Labor Party is demanding in these Bills.

Before the Labor Government and the Australian Democrats decide to try to win popularity by attacking tax breaks for oil companies, they should probably note that a survey of over 2,000 Australians made available to the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association showed that 81 per cent of those surveyed believed that the finding of more oil was very important to Australia's economic future. That just goes to highlight exactly how much more aware the public, the constituency of Australia, is than both the Government and the Democrats. Some 57 per cent of those people also believed that the Federal Government should strongly encourage more exploration, but only 11 per cent believed that it was providing that encouragement. It just goes to show that the public cannot be bluffed; the public knows what is going on. Both the Government and, in particular, the Democrats, who are so fond of testing the temperature with their finger or foot, whichever way it goes, should look at what the public believes and also at what is in the best interests of the future of this country before they vote the way they intend to on this legislation.

Under this legislation a well must be producing a 27 per cent profit before it becomes liable for the resource rent tax. The Government may well stress that expenditure compounded at the gross domestic product deflator rate can be offset against later profits, but this concession has serious limitations that render this legislation a continued overall disincentive to oil exploration. Retention lease projects are excluded from deductibility, as are the costs of cash bidding for exploration leases. This is what we fought so hard about only a few short months ago.

Downstream activities such as refining and marketing cannot be deducted; neither can interest payments or the cost of income tax fringe benefits tax be deducted. However, most seriously, deductibility at the augmented bond rate applies only to an individual permit area. The fact is that it is estimated that 70 per cent of future oil discoveries will be made in fields producing fewer than fifty million barrels. I believe that this limitation, therefore, discourages exploration over wider and non-contiguous areas. The Opposition, in the committee stage of the debate, will be proposing amendments that will extend deductibility to include any exploration expenditure.

The simple question as to whether we want to encourage as much exploration as possible must be asked again and again. If both the Government and the Australian Democrats can answer that question in the affirmative, we might get somewhere. However, at this stage it is quite apparent that neither the Government nor the Democrats wish to encourage exploration. We will also move to include the cost of cash bidding as a deductible expenditure. The fact remains that these Bills are just one more step in the process of attracting the maximum possible revenue from an industry that is far too important to Australia to be treated as a `cash cow', as it was described by Mr Stuart McGill of Esso Australia Ltd last year. He warned at that time that such treatment of an enterprise in the business world without adequate reinvestment causes business failure. Certainly, this Labor Government does nothing to encourage reinvestment.

It is significant that the oil industry has suffered 30 new or increased tax impositions since 1983. As I said only last Thursday in the tax debate, this is a government which said that its taxation system would be easier, simpler and so forth. It has become more complicated. The taxation legislation has some 400 extra pages for people to go through, to sort out. The oil industry alone has suffered 30 new or increased tax impositions in that time. Most seriously, the actions of this Government have increased both the expense and the uncertainty of oil exploration. These Bills are a tax on risk taking and represent levies on projects rather than corporations. These are both principles that discriminate against Australian resource industries.

Legislation that was first proposed in 1984 is no longer relevant to the Australia of 1987, when falls in oil production are well and truly with us, when other nations have greater potential reserves and lower costs, and when risk capital is fast drying up. I believe that a responsible government would scrap these Bills and look to the urgent stimulation of oil exploration through a more neutral tax regime that allowed full reward for risks taken in a vital national priority. However, sadly, I think the Opposition is going to be very much a Robinson Crusoe throughout this debate because we have seen in the past, as we have witnessed today, how both the Government and the Australian Democrats care little, if anything, about the future of this country, its oil exploration and the future of liquid fuels.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: â€”We are debating the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill, the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Bill, the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Interest on Underpayments) Bill 1987 and the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill which essentially are intended to provide a resource rent tax for the Government. This group of Bills was first introduced before the dissolution of the previous Parliament. It was not passed on that occasion and, accordingly, the Bills appropriately and properly lapsed. Regrettably, the Government has not put the time since then to good use and has presented us with Bills which contain all the flaws, all the failures and all the unwanted ingredients of the original legislation.

speech.para: The resource rent tax legislation affects companies with off-shore production licences which have come into effect since 1 July 1984, when the Government first announced the tax. The legislation displays the kind of contempt for taxpayers for which this Government has become uniquely notorious. In July 1984 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) issued a scrappy little Press release and then waited until earlier this year, the first part of 1987-almost three years after the first Press statement, the first official notice to the industry and the community as a whole-before introducing legislation of 66 pages and containing 114 clauses. For three years the industry has known nothing more than what was contained in a Press statement. Three years later it gets the full meat of the legislation. The industry and taxpayers as a whole had nothing more nor less upon which to seek to make definitive judgments than that first Press statement. However, this Government, a government by fiat, a government under sufferance by way of legislation, believes that it can now legitimately introduce legislation and backdate it to 1984.

I raise that matter because it is becoming fashionable-in fact it is being enshrined in the functioning of this Government-to think that, if one issues a Press statement containing broad and general guideline principles, that automatically gives one an imprimatur to introduce legislation at a later date which, and this has happened in many cases, may be quite different and separate from the impression given by the vagaries of a Press statement. This inexcusable delay really displays the failure of this Government to appreciate the difficulties faced by business in tax planning. In fact it shows gross contempt for the Parliament and the community as a whole. The Australian Labor Party displays a contempt for the principle that the Parliament, not the executive government, should impose tax measures. This Government seems to assume that, because it has issued a Press statement, everything is all right. That is not the case.

This legislation attempts to shift petroleum taxation from the present excise arrangements, which are based on the time that the oil is discovered and the quantity produced, to one based essentially on profit. In calculating profit, the legislation in essence works on a cash flow basis. It allows deductions for expenditure incurred in production areas, whether in the nature of capital outgoings or normal expenditure. Where in the early stages of a project the moneys expended exceed the revenue gained, the excess expenditure can be carried forward at a compounding rate. If the excess expenditure has occurred in the last five years the excess compounds at the long term bond rate plus 15 per cent. If it has occurred outside the last five years, it compounds at a rate equal to the implicit price deflator for gross domestic product. When incoming funds, whether they be of a capital or a revenue nature, exceed the expenditure which has been carried forward, the rate of taxation shall be cast at 40 per cent.

Of course, the company will still be liable for income tax on top of resource rent tax, but the amount paid in resource rent tax is deductible, and will be allowed as a deduction, under the income tax laws. By way of example, for a company which makes $1m from petroleum, $400,000 will, of course, automatically be lost by way of the resource rent tax. As this is income tax deductible, the amount which is assessed as company tax is $600,000 and a further $300,000 must be paid in company tax at the rate of 49c in the dollar. So an oil company, from the original profit of $1m, through this iniquitous, obscene and objectionable piece of legislation and through the notoriously high level of company tax, pays a total of $700,000 in taxation.

It is important, in assessing the legislation before the Senate, to understand the state of the industry. The Government and, perhaps, the community seem to have gained the rather misleading impression that the Australian petroleum industry has flourished in recent times-perhaps as a result of the extensive oil reserves which were discovered in Bass Strait in the early 1960s. In July this year, of the 571,000 barrels of crude produced per day, 443,000 came from the Gippsland Basin or, in other words, Bass Strait-that is, 77 per cent of Australia's total production came from this area.

Successive governments-I do not refer exclusively to the present Government or the previous Government, but I include previous governments-seem to hold the view that the oil industry is nothing more than a cow that is waiting to be milked. It was only three years ago that the vast majority of Bass Strait crude was taxed at the exorbitant rate of 87 per cent of the price of each barrel. Of the revenue earned in Bass Strait, an average of 79 per cent was taken in crude oil excise. Even after the concessions which have subsequently been granted, the top tax rate paid on Bass Strait crude is 79 per cent.

The dominance and the profitability of the Bass Strait area, combined with the dramatic price increase in the 1970s, led, in my view, to the erroneous assumption that the oil industry, more than any other industry, was there to be bled and milked, and that it was simply a licence to print money. Nothing could be further from the truth. The off-shore recovery to discovery ratio is only 5:100-5 per cent-for the remainder of the country. Of companies in that 5 per cent, about only half have commercially viable options and, of those, a considerable number will recover only enough to break even on their exploration and development expenditure. With the indulgence of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, I wish to have incorporated two tables. The first is compiled by the Bureau of Mineral Resources Geology and Geophysics and shows the success rate-or perhaps one could say it shows the failure rate-of drilling in various basins in Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”In addition to the difficulties of low prospectivity Australia faces very high production costs. Esso estimates that Australia's costs for marine seismic work are about 70 per cent higher than the world average. Off-shore drilling costs are said to be three times as expensive as they are in the United States. Another factor which has a great impact on this industry is the lower world price for oil. I will quote:

speech.para: In May 1985, Australian crude prices were $44.97 per barrel. By August of 1986 they had declined to $15.75. Since that low, they have recovered partially to now stand at $27.02 per barrel.

The combined effect of low prospectivity, high costs and low oil prices has been devastating on the industry. This has been manifested and reflected in exploration expenditure. It is shown in those areas where low prices in the variables I refer to are likely to be most susceptible to an industry downturn. In the 12 months to June 1987, only 18 off-shore wells were drilled, totalling 33,600 metres. By comparison, in 1983, 49 wells were drilled totalling 137,000 metres. Off-shore drilling expenditure fell from $473m in 1983-84 to $78m in the year to June 1987. In September this year only two off-shore drilling rigs were working around Australia. Three were idle. By any measure, and certainly by these measures, the industry is not in good health. One would be hopeful that, with the recent modest upturn in prices-the level has come from the bottom-there will be some modest recovery.

Self-sufficiency is a matter which ought to be on the minds of all honourable senators when they are contemplating this legislation. Currently we are using up our reserves a great deal faster than we are replacing them. In the 10 years from 1977 to 1986 we consumed 1,950 million barrels while we added only 830 million barrels to our reserves. Bass Strait reserves, we are told in Budget Paper No. 1 at page 331, are two-thirds depleted. In 1984 the Government estimated that Australia would be 95 per cent self-sufficient by 1990. That figure has subsequently been revised. The current suggestion is that it will be 65 per cent self-sufficient by that date. There are even suggestions that further revision will demonstrate that self-sufficiency will be as low as 50 per cent. Our forecast is that production from existing fields will fall by 266,000 barrels per day and will be replaced by discoveries totalling no more than 80,000 barrels per day. If that proves to be correct, by 1992 we will need to be importing 320,000 barrels of oil per year. If one assumes a price of $US18 a barrel and, optimistically, an exchange rate of US70c to $A1, this will add another $3 billion to our import bill. So our present direction can lead only to current account problems and a very real dependence on external supplies. It seems to me that our only real escape is to discover the greatest number of economic oil reserves possible. Under those circumstances we need industry conditions which are conducive to oil exploration.

I turn to the resource rent tax itself. There are for me two main difficulties. The first is simply the rate of taxation. The Government is very fond of saying that a resource rent tax taxes only economic rents. Allegedly, economic rents occur where a company derives returns from an activity which are well above its production costs. The theory goes that as a result some of the profit can be taken by taxation without affecting the production decisions of the company. Allegedly, it is a perfect tax in that it can be raised without the normal disincentive effects. That would be true perhaps in the case of a well that was up and running and where, at the exploration stage, the company had no notice and therefore no disincentive through the Government's intention to impose the tax. It certainly does not apply when companies are at the exploration stage and they know that the resource rent tax is to be put in place.

As I have indicated, the combined effect of resource rent tax and income tax will be to impose a tax equal to 70 per cent of the profit of the company. Exploration companies view the many dry wells that they strike as an inevitable cost in what they hope will be ultimately a viable commercial find. Companies can afford to explore in the less prospective areas only in the belief that they will have that rare find which will keep them going and the money so received from that rare find will cover the higher levels of expenses. Cutting the return and reducing the number of areas which are considered viable for exploration represent a disincentive for companies to invest, explore and seek to exploit in the less likely areas.

The second defect in the Bill is its failure, in my view, to truly tax profits. Under the income tax law, exploration expenditure of oil companies is a deductible expense regardless of where it is incurred. It has been recognised that exploration expenditure in several or all areas is still part of the one big operation of finding commercial wells. The resource rent tax, in principle, does not recognise that. In general, it limits the deductibility of expenditure to that incurred on the one project. In clause 36 there is provision for projects within the one exploration permit to be taken to be in one project group and for the expenditure of one-by definition of that one exploration group-to be set off against the revenue of another.

Apart from the limited provision for the Minister to issue a certificate to combine projects, there is no potential in the Bill for the expenditure in one exploration permit to be offset against revenues earned in another completely separate permit. That is totally out of step with the way in which the industry operates. It is even out of step with the way in which the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 operates. It is absolutely ridiculous to suggest that when a company takes out several exploration permits, a failure in one area is not all part and parcel of the finding of a successful area. Exploration is a probability industry. Yet if this Bill becomes law, the Government will give no deductions for the unsuccessful permits while standing ready to put its hand out the moment a company is successful. In my view, this is simply not a true calculation of profit. It amounts to the artificial inflation of the profits of producing wells. In effect, the tax imposed on successful projects is even higher than the 70c in the dollar that I mentioned earlier. Instead of producing a climate which is conducive to oil exploration, the Government is adding yet another disincentive to the already difficult Australian exploration conditions.

I said at the outset that successive governments have regarded the oil industry as simply waiting to be milked. I quickly make some brief comments about the level of taxation which is imposed on the industry in general. I give an indication of what consumers pay in tax each time they buy a litre of petrol. Currently, Australia imposes a crude oil excise anywhere between zero and 79c. The Federal Government imposes a petroleum products excise on items such as petrol, dieseline and kerosene, to name but a few. For petrol this equates to 20.83c a litre. The Royal Automobile Club of Western Australia has estimated that the combined cost of the Federal Government's crude oil and petroleum products excises amounts to 27.6c per litre of fuel. Royalties are imposed on sections of the industry and a franchise fee is imposed on service stations by all States except Queensland. These amount to another 5.8c per litre of fuel. In total, 33.4c is paid in taxes on fuel which would otherwise cost 26.9c per litre. This amounts to a total tax of 124 per cent on the cost of the product. In addition, the companies involved are required to pay 49c in every dollar they earn in profits.

Clearly, the petroleum and petroleum products industry is, as it says, the most highly taxed industry in Australia. The crude oil excise is in effect wholly borne by the industry, as it is fixed on the basis of import parity-although, of course, a great deal of this tax is passed on to the consumer. A report released by the Industries Assistance Commission last year clearly demonstrates how both Federal and State governments have grown increasingly dependent on the oil industry for revenue. Not only is this not good for the industry, but also it is simply not good government to depend so heavily on one industry for revenue. As with the mistletoe on the tree, the more governments feed on the industry, the more they weaken it and the more they contribute to its demise. This industry has certainly already begun to wane.

Future governments will find it difficult enough as it is to grapple with the natural depletion of our oil reserves. These problems will be compounded dramatically if any avaricious grab for more money by governments such as this continues to draw from the life of the industry. That is what this legislation will do. It imposes extortionate taxes and it assesses them in a manner which shows no understanding of the speculative nature of the exploration industry. By killing off exploration the Government kills off the growth in the industry, kills off the source of its own revenue and places the whole economy in jeopardy. I take the view that this legislation has no virtue, no intrinsic merit and no logical conclusion. Rather, it is simply another form of taxation or revenue collection which this Government seeks to impose on a particular industry which it judges-or misjudges-able to pay. It is likely to further cripple and debase the industry.

I hope that the common sense of the Australian Democrats will prevail and that they will do as they did last time; that is, indicate their intention to vote against this legislation and do so. I would be greatly disappointed if I thought the Democrats were prepared to be bought off for a miserable $5m so that they could continue to tilt at windmills.

talk.start.para: â€”You give too much weight to their importance.

â€”Perhaps I do. Perhaps I have placed too much emphasis on their integrity, their sense of justice and fairness or their sense of believing in any principle. I recall their saying last time this legislation was before us that it had no merit, that it deserved to be defeated and that it was their intention to have it defeated. But now I understand that for the princely sum of five--
â€”Five pieces of silver.
â€”Yes, five pieces of silver-they have cast this industry upon a cross and have chosen to ensure that it will be crippled in the future.

talk.start.para: â€”The Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill, the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Bill, the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Interest on Underpayments) Bill and the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill have had a very long gestation period, something over four years. This is a fact of which I am well aware because when the legislation was first introduced I had the primary responsibility for dealing with it for the Government. I did not think it would take this long-indeed, a bit more than double the gestation period for an elephant. There were a number of reasons for that. The first was the need to have a fairly protracted series of negotiations with the States and the industry. Following that, there had to be negotiations, with which I was not directly involved-Senator Gareth Evans had taken over the primary responsibility for the legislation by that time-with the Australian Democrats, in particular in order to ensure the passage of the legislation.
â€”You would never have offered the Democrats $5m.

â€”Well, as I said, that happened after I was involved in the matter. But it was necessary for the Government to negotiate with the Democrats, because the troglodytes in the official Opposition-and this has come out again in the second reading debate, although I am sure that this is not true of Senator Stone, who did not speak in this debate-clearly have no conceptual understanding of the proposal. In other words, their general economic ignorance and illiteracy carry over into this policy proposition and this debate. So there was no point in discussing anything with the troglodytes in the Opposition and they have demonstrated again, in the amendments of which they have given notice, that they have still learnt nothing. Like the Bourbons, they have learnt nothing; I am not sure whether they have forgotten anything.

speech.para: I want to make a few points on as much of the second reading debate as I heard. Firstly-and again with that qualification, on as much as I heard of the debate, which was less than 100 per cent-there has been no recognition of the fact that this proposition is part of a package. The element of that package which has been ignored is that the pre-existing royalty in off-shore areas, that is the well-head value royalty in off-shore areas not subject to the 1979 Act, which was pushed through by the Fraser Government-rather shamefully, if I may say so-is to be abolished. The possibility exists-indeed it is not just a possibility but a probability, so far as the Jabiru field is concerned-that in fact the resource rent tax (RRT) payments will be less than the royalty payments which would otherwise have been due. In other words, it is not primarily an exercise about increasing government revenue. It may or may not have that effect. Nobody can predict in advance of a great deal of detailed knowledge, which cannot be possessed at this stage, whether the tax take would be higher or lower under the rent tax regime than it would have been under the well-head royalty regime. The resource rent tax imposes a much more rational tax and one which will have a much less distortionary effect on rational investment decisions.

Senator Durack specifically mentioned that oil prices are now lower than they were when this tax was being planned. That is true. He said that oil prices will be lower in the future. That may be true but obviously nobody can know for certain. What he appears not to understand is that if oil prices are lower both a royalty regime and a rent tax regime will reduce the amount of tax payable by producers, but the rent tax regime, under those circumstances, will skew the tax payment downwards relative to that which would be payable under a royalty regime. In other words, it has a self-correcting mechanism by the nature of its design.

There has been some mention of wider deductibility, that is, allowing for the assessment of RRT liability. Exploration expenditure incurred outside the permit area, which is ultimately convertible, is ultimately converted into a production licence which may or may not cover the whole permit area. In principle there is a valid argument for that, which was put to the industry by me 18 months ago or thereabouts with the proviso that of course there would have to be an offset; that is, if wider deductibility were to be allowed, either the threshold rate at which the original expenditure is compounded or the RRT rate would have to be adjusted. The industry at that stage, I think unanimously, said it was not interested in wider deductibility; it was interested only in the threshold rate of return and the tax rate itself. In other words, the industry was given the option-an option which, by the way, in my view would have made this a marginally better tax than it finally is-at that time, and it made its decision. The industry was vehement about the question and the Government, given that it is a marginal issue, decided to comply with its wishes. I know that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) in particular would have preferred to have some wider deductibility, and if I may pay a compliment to BHP, it has been more rational about this issue, all the way along, than any of the other major producers. One or two of the minor producers have been equally rational. As far as I and the Government are concerned, the decision was effectively made by the industry a couple of years ago and we cannot review it now.

The other point I mention is that the amendments of which the Opposition has given notice, although I was made aware of them only about five minutes ago, are essentially the same amendments moved by the Opposition when this legislation was last before the Senate in late May or early June of this year. They are technically flawed, as they were technically flawed when they were moved then. They fall into three categories. The first is the question of wider deductibility, which I have already mentioned. The third is to increase the threshold rate. The Government will not be accepting either of those. The second, which is the proposed amendment to clause 32, is an attempt, so I am advised-read in isolation, it does not mean much at all-to repeal the cash bidding regulation which the Government put through in 1985 legislation.

This is a complicated issue and it is an excellent one on which to demonstrate the economic ignorance and illiteracy of the Opposition. The Opposition opposed cash bidding which, for the benefit of those who are listening, if anybody is, is a system in which an area of land-in this case read `sea' for `land'-is thrown open for exploration and if the exploration is successful, ultimately, presumably, for production. Companies which wish to explore the area are invited to submit a cash bid for the right to do so. It is a system that has been used in the United States of America and a number of other countries. It is one way of extracting, right up front, the economic rent which actually exists or is perceived to exist.

The Opposition is opposed to this policy on the completely spurious grounds that Australia is not sufficiently prospective and that, if a cash bidding system were in operation, judgment would be made that the alleged low prospectivity of Australian off-shore areas, in conjunction with lower oil prices and a few other things, would kill off exploration activity. I am amazed that even some of the mental retards in the Opposition cannot see the flaw in that argument because, if the industry made that judgment, there would be no cash bid. If the industry had made the judgment that the price of oil and the prospectivity of a particular area were so low that it was not worth a cash bid, there would be no cash bid. I would have thought that even the National Party of Australia could understand that. But no, not only the National Party but the troglodytes or the trucklers of the Liberal Party, even though they have had this, I would have thought, fairly elementary piece of logic put before them many times, persist with this specious argument. This admits only two possible conclusions-one, that they are too stupid to know any better and the other that they are being bought off, in one way or another, by the oil industry.

talk.start.para: â€”As I foreshadowed when I spoke in the second reading debate, I have circulated to honourable senators a number of amendments that I propose to move as a whole as they really deal with one subject. Before I proceed to move the amendments, I want to raise one or two matters with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). I want to raise a question which has figured prominently in the debate about the Government's resource rent tax proposal. When the legislation was brought into this chamber and debated on 5 May, as is now well known, Senator Sanders, speaking on behalf of the Australian Democrats, announced pretty much to the surprise of most people that the Democrats would oppose the legislation. He said that the reasons for the Democrats' opposition to the legislation were:

speech.para: The Government has raised the threshold rates and reduced the tax rates to the point where, while in name it is a resource rent tax, in practice it is not; it is a give-away tax, a give-away to the oil companies.

. . . the petroleum companies will pay no tax whatsoever. They have paid none in the last three years in this respect. I put it to the Senate that they will never pay any tax on this, and the Government knows this.
The first reason that was advanced by the Democrats was that the tax was just not heavy enough. Senator Sanders then went on to say:

We are unhappy with this legislation. We feel that this Bill pays no attention to renewable resources. It is time that we in the Senate, the Government and this country took some cognisance of finite world economics.
I think he meant finite world resources. He continued:

We must go to renewable resources. This Bill does not address that. It makes no provision for channelling any of the funds gained-if they are ever gained-from the resource rent tax into renewable resources.
