â€”The statement will not be functionally related to this legislation. My advice is that this measure will not require any legislation at all because a trust account will be set up under the Audit Act. I do not want to pre-empt Mr Kerin or the Minister for Resources, Mr Peter Morris, or whoever makes the statement. However, I think I can give a general outline of the decision. As I have already mentioned, a trust account will be administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It will not be funded from resource rent tax (RRT) revenue and, therefore it is not, in any legalistic sense, related to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill. At this stage the anticipated revenue from the RRT will be very substantially in excess of the amount of money which will be provided for research into alternative forms of energy.

speech.para: I repeat the caveat that I do not want to pre-empt a statement of either Mr Kerin or Mr Morris that the priorities for specific applications will be determined ultimately by the Minister but, in practice, they are more likely to be determined by the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council, as has been the case for many years. Under the previous Government, formal ministerial approval was given for energy research projects nominated by that Council. It is anticipated that there will be additional expenditure of about $1m a year.

Senator Durack has not formally moved the amendments but I presume that he will do so later, so I will speak to them now-although I covered them in my speech in the second reading debate. There are essentially three amendments: one on cash bidding, one on wider deductibility-the Government will accept neither of these amendments-and one on the threshold rate at which undeducted expenditure will compound. I have given the reasons why the Government will not accept these amendments. However, I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate that there were technical defects in the amendments relating to wider deductibility. I am advised that the technical deficiency in the amendments in their present form is that, although they alter the manner in which exploration expenditure is treated, they fail to make corresponding alterations to the treatment of assessable receipts. That lack of flow-through to the assessability provisions would result in receipts from the sale of petroleum obtained during the exploration stage not being assessable. I doubt whether even the Opposition intended that to be the case.

I am also advised that the amendments would allow deductibility for exploration expenditure incurred outside a resource rent tax area. In other words, if the amendments were carried the oil companies, or producers or potential producers, would be getting it both ways. This is a situation which was described succinctly, if I may say so, by Senator Stone in his address to the National Agricultural Outlook Conference, I think it was in January 1981, when he delivered a well-deserved shaft at the provisions the Fraser Government had enacted for farmers to be able to opt in or opt out of the tax averaging provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. If I remember correctly, Senator Stone said, `This is an arrangement under which, heads, farmers win, and tails, all other taxpayers lose'. Although one needs in this case to transpose farmers for oil producers, what the Opposition is doing here, wittingly or unwittingly, is something similar; that is to allow deductibility of expenditure incurred in an area where revenue would not be exposed to resource rent tax.

I understand, although I do not think it necessary to go through all this as well, that should the amendments of which Senator Durack has given notice be carried they would, for technical reasons, require a number of consequential amendments to other clauses of the Bill.

speech.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) seems very anxious to move into consideration of the amendments that the Opposition has moved. He seems very reluctant indeed to give any detail about that secret side deal the Government has done with the Australian Democrats in regard to something which Senator Walsh says technically is not part of the legislation. Technically that may be true. It is as plain as a pikestaff of course that the legislation in no way whatsoever deals with the creation of any trust fund or any appropriation of that kind by the Government for any particular purpose at all. What the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has failed to address is the highly significant fact that whatever the Government has done and secretly conveyed to the Democrats has dramatically changed the passage of this legislation through the Parliament.

speech.para: The function of a second reading speech-something that may have escaped Senator Walsh, although he is capable of very effective after dinner speeches; one of which we have heard tonight-is to enlighten the Parliament as to the intentions and objects of the legislation and the effect of Government policy which is contained within the legislation. This has been done at great length, I might say, in the second reading speech to this legislation-as, indeed, it is done in relation to most legislation. However, in this case the Parliament has been totally deprived of a very significant piece of information, so significant in fact that a party with the balance of power in the Parliament has changed its vote.

talk.start.para: â€”Your problem is that you didn't listen to my speech. I explained all that but you didn't listen.
â€”I am not objecting to the Australian Democrats. I am objecting to what the Government has done.
â€”Tell the Democrats, too. They don't know.

â€”Yes, that may help the Democrats because there seems to be confusion amongst them. In this regard we are being asked to pass legislation which contains another significant element. As I said, it is so significant that another party has changed its intention as a result of it. We have had a very reluctant Minister giving us some very vague indication of the Government's apparent proposal to establish a trust fund.
â€”The Minister earlier denied any involvement in the negotiations, yet they have been negotiated by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
â€”You don't listen-$5m flat.

â€”But all that the Minister for Finance has told us is that there will be a trust fund into which $1m a year will be paid. He does not even tell us for how many years that will be paid. Perhaps Senator Walsh will at least tell us what is the total limit. Is this a yearly payment, indefinitely, of $1m? Is it a payment over so many years? Is it a lump sum that will be paid over this period? What is the general purpose of it? Presumably it will be by way of an appropriation. But whether we will get any detail before then, or other legislation to give effect to it, is at this stage totally vague. Before we proceed any further into a detailed discussion of this legislation-I know Senator Walsh is anxious to get on with the debate-it is only proper that the Senate should be informed of at least the total commitment that the Government has given in relation to these payments which have bought off the Democrats and encouraged them to change their vote.

â€”I will be pretty brief. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) mentioned $5m. By way of interjection, Senator Sanders has clarified this by saying that it is $5m flat. I do not know what that means or what period it is over. But the Minister has said that the $5m will go into a trust account and it will not come from the resource rent tax (RRT). In the second reading debate Senator Sanders said that this amount of $5m for windmills, pushbikes or whatever would not affect current expenditure by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) on alternative forms of energy. So, the question we are all asking is: Where is the money coming from if it is not coming from RRT but from some other source? Senator Sanders made it quite clear that it is not coming from NERDDC, so, presumably, the existing expenditure on alternative forms will not change. I ask the Minister to clarify this, not only for us but also for the Democrats, who seem to be as unsure as we are of what this is all about.

â€”I have just had another quick glance at the second reading speech, a copy of which I have here and which sets out the rationale behind the legislation. I do not use that term at all pejoratively; I use it in the sense that it explains the underlying economic logic of this form of taxation. I am sorry if Senator Durack cannot understand that, but I do not think that is my fault. Senator Durack and Senator Parer raised other questions. I thought I had made things clear in my earlier remarks but, if I did not, I apologise. As I understand it, the announcement which Mr Kerin or Mr Peter Morris will make-I do not know whether it will be this week or some time later-is that $1m a year will be paid into a trust account for each of the next five years.
â€”From where?

â€”From Consolidated Revenue. One of the few things that Malcolm Fraser ever said that were correct was that there is no such thing as a free lunch. Things have to be paid for sooner or later. I am disappointed to see that over the last 12 months the Liberal Party of Australia has degenerated to the point that it is now running with the proposition that there is such a thing as a free lunch-that one can have $8 billion worth of tax cuts offset by $2 1/2 billion worth of expenditure cuts, or something like that. So $1m a year for each of the next five years will be paid into a trust account and used to enhance existing expenditure on alternative energy research. As I understand it, that is the proposition which will be announced some time in the near future. Recommendations will be made to the Minister by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, known as NERDDC. Senator Durack and others are perfectly entitled to criticise that decision if they wish. I guess they could even have a go in the House of Representatives, at amending the consequential appropriation Bill that will eventually provide the money for it, if they want to. But if they want to make these sorts of initial decisions, they will have to be in government, not in opposition.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I am not too sure whether the Opposition is complaining about the amount of money, where it is coming from or, indeed, how it is to be spent. I suspect, from the remarks which were made during the second reading debate, that it is particularly concerned that money should be spent on alternative energy. I will say a few words on that subject. The analysis which the Opposition has made is quite sound, but the conclusion it draws is quite false. It seems to be saying that Australia is running short of liquid fuels. That is perfectly true; we are running short of liquid fuels. Indeed, the world is running short of liquid fuels. As an aside, I note that the market system on which both the Opposition and the Government tend to rely--
â€”Is that why the price is falling?

â€”If Senator Stone will listen, he will find that I am explaining that. The market system on which his Party and, indeed, the Government rely does not take account of future shortages; it takes account only of instantaneous supply and demand. The fact that by the mid-1990s fuel prices are expected to rise-and rise perhaps much more steeply than we saw in the early 1970s--
â€”What were they expected to rise to in 1982, Senator? They were expected to rise to $80 by this time, weren't they?

â€”The situation now is somewhat different from that which caused the price rises of 1972, 1973 and 1974. Those price rises occurred substantially because of a political situation in the Middle East in which the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries chose to exercise its political power in the face of quite adequate supplies of petroleum. Of course, since then we have seen the exploitation of North Sea oil, which, on all projections, will run down very substantially in the next few years. The best figures which I have seen suggest that there will be a steep rise in price in the mid-1990s.
â€”Where did you get this from?
â€”If one reads journals like Science, Nature, and so on, one will find those sorts of figures.
â€”You ought to read a couple of economic journals.

â€”It is very significant that these people who are economists take no account of the real world-the real, natural world-at all. They simply deal with money. They fail to realise that money must have its roots in real resources and, unless it does, we are headed for a very serious fall.

speech.para: As I have indicated, there is a growing shortage of liquid fuels. That is true both of Australia and of the world as a whole. Furthermore, a statement was made by the Opposition that the rate of exploitation of petroleum has exceeded the rate of new discoveries for a considerable amount of time. That is also true of Australia and the rest of the world-it is particularly true in Australia. Interestingly, Senator Knowles said that the Fraser Government increased expenditure on exploration from $80m to $1,000m. Yet the statement was made a moment later that 77 per cent of the oil was still coming from Bass Strait and that that oil was discovered in the 1960s. Clearly, we had spent roughly $1 billion on further exploration which had produced very little result. Yet we seem to be being told by the Opposition that we need to spend more money on exploration.

talk.start.para: â€”They take the risk, not the Government.

â€”I do not mind whether it comes from private companies or from the Government. The fact is that it comes from the Australian economy and, on the Opposition's own statements, we have spent $1 billion which have produced very little result. Yet the Opposition is now arguing that we need to spend even more money on exploration. It has also stated quite clearly and repeatedly that the prospectivity-it is a horrible word-of Australia is poor. It is one of the poorest countries in the world in this respect, yet somehow we need to scrape together more money to go out and explore for more oil.
â€”Not the taxpayer.

â€”Yes, the taxpayer, either directly or indirectly. What does the honourable senator think profits are, if not a private form of taxation? It comes out of the national revenue, whether from private or government sources. The sources of the wealth of the country are the resources on which the country is built and the work of its people. If that comes from private sources, so be it. If it comes through government sources it is essentially part of the same national revenue. The Opposition seems to have failed to realise that future generations also have a right to some of those resources. It is quite unrealistic simply to rip these resources out of the ground and exploit them in the view that the present generation has a perfect right to do that.
â€”Do you not understand that there will not be any if they are not found in the first place?

â€”That is rather interesting. Senator Stone does not seem to realise that we-the human race-are now taking out of the ground, world wide, fossil fuels at a rate approximately one million times the rate at which nature laid those resources down so many million years ago.
â€”If that is your problem, why are you opposed to nuclear energy? Your proposition is false in the first place.
â€”Order! I ask that remarks be directed through the Chair. There are too many interjections.

â€”Thank you, Madam Chair. I would much rather speak to you than the interjections. But what is being said simply underlines the extremely simple analysis which is all that the Opposition seems to be capable of. It does not seem to be able to understand relatively simple scientific facts in relation to the observation that the human economy is only a part, a subset, of the total world ecology. The human economy can grow and expand only at the expense of the natural world. To the extent that it grows--
â€”Rubbish!

â€”I hear the remark `Rubbish'. That is the crux of this argument. The Opposition simply does not understand that we are dealing with a finite earth and we cannot go on exploiting it in this way. The Australian Democrats have sought and achieved the agreement of the Government to spend a small amount of money-we believe it is far too small-to find a real solution to this problem, which is the provision of energy for us and future generations. That requires a relatively long lead time. One of the faults in the Opposition's argument is that it does not realise that we cannot solve this problem in one or two years. The implementation of the technology will require relatively long periods of application. I mention here one of the failures of the Government. Insufficient attention was given in the so-called Button car plan to fuel efficiency in the manufacture of Australian cars. While Senator Knowles said that rising fuel costs will raise the cost of everything and therefore cause inflation, she fails to recognise that we do not need a certain quantity of fuel. We need transport and we can achieve that and, in fact, decrease costs, by using fuel more efficiently. While we increase the cost per unit per litre, we may well, if we go down the efficiency road, use sufficiently less fuel and decrease costs overall.

speech.para: As to the alternatives which have been mentioned, Senator Sanders pointed out that a number of these are already technically feasible. They are already economic. What is required is the will to put them in place.

talk.start.para: â€”Which ones are economic?

â€”I thank Senator Parer for that question. I will answer it. As I hope the economists in the chamber will know, a mix of factors go into lifetime costs. There is the initial capital cost of buying the equipment and there are the running costs. One area in which solar energy is eminently successful and can compete very successfully with either gas or electricity is the provision of hot water. The initial capital cost of solar units is very large. The Australian electricity energy industry has uniformly amortised the capital cost of generating equipment into the cost of electricity so that there is a hidden subsidy in the cost of electricity which distorts the market's impression to the point where it appears to be cheaper to go out to buy an electric hot water service.

speech.para: Studies were done in South Australia several years ago by the Stewart committee which showed that wind energy-another alternative Senator Sanders mentioned-is cheaper than central coal-based electricity. I invite fellow senators to look at the Stewart committee report to see that central coal-based power was costing 4c per kilowatt hour and that wind energy-and this goes back several years-could be produced at about 3.8c per kilowatt hour. These studies were done by engineers for the Department of Mines and Energy in South Australia, a department which is not given to praising the alternatives; on the contrary, it has been trying very hard to prove the opposite.

A number of impediments which have been built into cost structures militate against the use of the alternatives which, in fact, are economic on a lifetime basis. What is being attempted is the engineering of some funds which will move us-the Democrats would believe far too slowly; we would like to see more funds available-down the road to the imposition of these alternatives which will not only ameliorate our demand for oil but will also be far less polluting. What has not been picked up, and which will limit the use of fossil fuels, particularly liquid fuels, is the amount of pollution such fuels cause not only in terms of unburnt hydrocarbons and in terms of carbon dioxide, which causes the greenhouse effect, but also in terms of the heat which is released to the surface of the earth. I do not think those trained in economics realise that the energy throughput of the earth's human population is now greater than the energy throughput of all other plants and animals on the face of the globe. This gives an indication of the level of pollution which one species alone is already causing, and this problem will be exacerbated by a further increase in the use of these fuels. Therefore, the Democrats are very anxious to support this small amount of funding and hope that it will be increased in the future.

speech.speaker: Sanders Sen N.K.

talk.start.para: â€”I have often observed in this place that, when there is no logical basis for the Opposition's arguments, it resorts to personal abuse. We have certainly seen a lot of that. It is also, I am afraid, a great indication of the ego and, probably, the self-aggrandisement of politicians. Because they are paid a fat salary and have a big white car to ride around in and a private subsidised dining room, they think that they are somebody, that perhaps they know it all. I thought that Senator Coulter put a fairly understated case for the use of renewable energy, referring to the fact that the earth is running out of resources. Senator Sheil said, `Rubbish, rubbish' when Senator Coulter said that we are running out of oil and minerals. When Senator Coulter said that honourable senators could refer to articles in Science or Nature, Senator Paper scoffed and said, `Ah, Nature! Do you have to take off your clothes to read this magazine?'. Apparently he does not know that it is an authoritative magazine.
â€”I didn't say that.

â€”His colleague who sits next to him said it. Those people celebrate their own ignorance before the nation. We often deny reality in this chamber, with its artificial lighting and with its windows blanked out so we cannot see the real world. It is a bit like a bunch of ants sitting in an ant-hill discussing whether or not they will allow the sun to rise the next day. Some of our discussions have that much relation to reality. I think it is time that honourable senators actually opened their eyes to reality, and to the fact that this is a finite earth and we are damaging and overexploiting it. I hear a sigh from Senator Parer behind me. They say, `This is not happening'. While it is not happening on the scale that they have perhaps noticed over the last 10 minutes, 10 hours, 10 days or even 10 years, looking at it in terms of geologic time, which as a geologist I do, it is happening at an accelerated pace.

speech.para: I have been talking about the greenhouse effect for 20 years, and now people accept it. If we had listened 20 years ago to people who were talking about it, we might have been able to do something then. We are trying to do something now. It behoves all honourable senators to take a non-political look at what is happening to the real world-to open their eyes for once without the party leanings or the trappings of political power-and to try to think for the future instead of the present.

In this entire debate, speaker after speaker from the Opposition has protected the oil industry, protected the richest companies on earth. The product of these companies is worth more every year than the gross national product of most countries. What an incredible state of affairs it is for those people to be protecting the richest and most powerful organisations on earth. Why do they do so? I have no idea, except that I think they buy the advertisements. I think they believe those wonderful ads on television from BP Australia Ltd, the quiet achiever, which says that it really wants to go out and explore and find more for the people of Australia. It certainly does not want to do it for profits! No, it does it for the people of Australia. Also there is the big Australian, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. It does all these wonderful things for the people of Australia! What rubbish! These companies do these things for themselves. But I think these people in the Opposition believe that they are in fact helping Australia in the process. They are not; they are helping themselves.

I turn to the amendments. I was wondering whether we would ever get to the amendments. I presume we will. I refer to the matter of deductibility, since it has been mentioned. The oil companies already have massive deductions and massive tax help. What about thresholds? They should be lowered, if anything-certainly not raised. There has been a lot of talk about renewable energy. People have said, `If we do not like oil we should build nuclear power reactors'. I will not even get into that fatuous argument. To attack just a little corner of it, I make the point that nuclear energy releases heat into the atmosphere. How will Senator Stone account for that? The point is that Opposition senators have said of petroleum resources, `Look, we need it for our transport system'.

talk.start.para: â€”Are you going to restructure society?

â€”Somebody said, `Are you going to restructure society?'. Yes, we must restructure society. We have to have efficient transit systems in the cities. For small delivery vehicles and perhaps for specialised commuting tasks we need to move to electrical power. We must also-listen for it, folks; we will hear a screech from the back row-we have to reinstitute such forms of transportation as bicycles. There is dead silence in the chamber-stunned silence, I suppose. Yes, I said `bicycles'.
â€”Rickshaws?

â€”No, not rickshaws-bicycles. The bicycle is the most energy efficient form of transportation ever invented. it is humanity's most benign invention. It is a wonderful thing. It travels quietly, with great energy efficiency. It is easy to park and easy to buy. Millions of Chinese use them. Millions of other people in what we consider the undeveloped world use them. We somehow have got away from them. Bicycles can be a viable alternative option. In fact, we are selling far more bicycles in Australia every year than we are cars. Many bicycles get sold. What we need for bicycles to become a truly viable option is bikeways.

â€”Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. This is a very entertaining speech, but I fear it has got slightly off the track-be it a single or dual track. I ask you to call the honourable senator to order. It is getting quite late. There is an extraordinary amount of business to get through, not only today but the rest of this week. With a bit of discipline all around, we can do it.

â€”I point out to the Committee that we are at the committee stage of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill. I believe that the debate is moving somewhat off that direction. It sounds often more like a second reading debate. I draw the attention of the whole Committee to the point of order.

â€”Of course, this matter is central to the debate. One of the difficulties we have in the Senate is that we never really address the real problems; we just glance off them. This is an attempt to address the real problems. We do need alternative energy structures. We need a new look at the way we run our society. It will come. We can either choose to do it of our own volition or it can be imposed upon us.

â€”Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I rise to support the point of order previously made by Senator McKiernan and to point out in passing that Senator Sanders, in response to your ruling from the chair, has in effect debated your ruling which, I think, under the Standing Orders, he is not permitted to do. Moreover, having debated it, he has immediately compounded the offence by continuing in the same manner as previously. After all, what Senator McKiernan ought to have said was: `The Government has paid for the silence of the Democrats. Why do they go on?'.
â€”Once again I remind the Committee of the Bill we are addressing. I ask all senators to address their remarks to the Bill before us.
â€”You have another 15 minutes in which to do it, Senator.

â€”No, I do not wish to delay this Bill. Senator Stone's fatuous outburst deserves no reply, so I will not give it one. I do not wish to take the 15 minutes that Senator Stone has apparently now given me, but we must take action now on the resource rent tax, on the renewable situation and on restructuring our society. Are we going to take this action or are we going to wait until it is too late? From the speeches I have heard in here, and from the interjections, I think this Parliament would be quite happy to postpone this until it is too late. I think we must take action now. I believe that this Bill, unamended and with the spin-off of a sunshine fund, is an important first step towards a rational energy program. I recommend the Bill and I recommend voting against the amendments.

â€”I raise another matter with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) of a threshold nature. Under the regime of off-shore taxation of oil production there was a Commonwealth-State agreement about the sharing of royalties that occurred in the areas of what are known as joint authorities between the Commonwealth and the States, under which the Commonwealth and the States shared royalty payments. As this new regime of a resource rent tax is replacing the royalty payments which the States shared, as well as some excise arrangements which were imposed by the Commonwealth, the States stand to lose quite considerably as a result of the Government's proposals when they ultimately take effect, as they clearly will now because of the support the Democrats are giving the Government. On the face of things the States will lose quite heavily from these arrangements. I would like the Minister to tell us-I remind the chamber that he is the Minister for Finance and presumably he has been engaged in discussions with the States, and I would be very surprised if they have not raised this matter with the Government because some of them have already raised it with the Opposition-what new arrangements will exist between the Commonwealth and the States. Are there any in relation to sharing the resource rent tax revenues that are received? If not, are other arrangements being put in place for revenue sharing between the Commonwealth and the States to replace the revenue that the States have lost? Or is the Government simply taking the attitude that it is just too bad for the States and they will have to wear the loss of revenue from these arrangements?

â€”As far as the Ash- more and Cartier Islands territory is concerned, which is the only off-shore area in which there is an immediate prospect of a rent tax being payable, the States have never had any entitlement to any revenue from there, which I think Senator Durack knows. I have just been reminded that the statement put out in June 1984 committed the Government to holding discussions with the States about the royalty distribution in the rest of the off-shore areas. To the best of my knowledge those discussions have not been been held because, as I mentioned earlier, of the very long gestation period of this legislation and the fact that, with a bit of luck, it will actually pass the chamber tonight. The Commonwealth's objective at that time-and from memory I think this was perfectly clear from the statement I issued, and if not, it has certainly been made clear from many other statements that I issued around the same time or said to the industry-is to get rid of the royalty in the entire off-shore area and to replace it with the rent tax regime. Again to the best of my knowledge that was a view shared by Senator Evans, when he had the responsibility for this policy area, and it remains the view of Mr Kerin, and certainly there has been no Government decision to change that.

â€”I find that a very unsatisfactory reply. As I understand what Senator Walsh has said, in 1984-that is well over three years ago-he made a commitment that, with the advent of the resource rent tax (RRT) regime, there would be discussions between the Commonwealth and the State governments as to the sharing of some of that revenue, to replace the loss of revenue that the States would have under the royalty regime.
â€”I would have thought you should not be talking about the legislation. If ever there was a spineless cave-in by a government it was what you masterminded in 1979.

â€”It is no good shouting and going on with meaningless noises. I know it is late in the evening and well after dinner. The position is that the Minister has said that his good intentions, as the Minister, to discuss these matters with the States were shared by Senator Gareth Evans, who had good intentions of discussing these matters with the States and, in an even better performance for the Government, the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has good intentions of discussing these matters with the States. The Government has had 3 1/2 years of good intentions. Now we have the Bill about to become an Act. I know that immediately, in relation to the area to which the RRT applies, there is no loss to the States, but Senator Walsh has just announced that the object of the Government is to expand the resource rent tax regime to the whole of the off-shore areas and I think, to the on-shore areas as well. Senator Walsh may agree. What is the Government proposing? Has it proposed anything to the States or are we still in the realm of good intentions of discussing these matters with them?

â€”If Senator Durack could remember anything for more than five minutes he should remember this, because it was he who presided over one of the most spineless sell-outs that any Commonwealth Government has ever perpetrated and that is, having been given constitutional authority over the area beyond the low water mark by the High Court decision of 1975, the spineless Fraser Government then sold out and allowed all the States to have a say in what was never State territory, constitutionally determined. However, that is there. To get rid of the royalty in that part of the off-shore area other than the Ashmore and--
â€”You have never sought to change it. You would not be game to front Burke, would you?

â€”Senator Durack is complaining about my drawing attention to how he presided over that spineless sell-out in 1979. It is the Commonwealth's intention, and I have just been shown a copy of the statement that I issued--
â€”What about the spineless sell-out by the Commonwealth to protect the revenues of the Burke Government?

â€”Senator Stone is saying that Malcolm Fraser was intimidated by Charlie Court and so was Senator Durack. I have no problem with that. If Senator Stone is talking about the agreement that the Commonwealth made to forgo revenue on the North West Shelf gas project, that was an attempt to compensate the Western Australian Government for the mess that it inherited from the megalomaniac who was Premier at the time, who signed a take or pay contract and then added 50 million cubic feet a day to what he was committed to pay, for good measure, and who still had the effrontery to say that it was good business. If Charlie Court thinks that that is such good business I have invited him before to buy the gas from the Western Australian Government at the price that the Western Australian Government has to pay for it. That is about the last thing that I would have thought that Senator Stone or anybody on his side of politics should be talking about-the scandal of the stupid take or pay contract that the megalomaniac from the west signed on behalf of the taxpayers of Western Australia. This Government, very generously if I may say so, made some arrangements which lessened the financial penalties that the Burke Government had inherited from the megalomaniac who had been Premier about 12 months before it came into office.
â€”Not only inherited but enthusiastically endorsed.

â€”I have noted, and I will point this out in Western Australia, that Senator Stone wants to impose the whole burden of Charlie Court's megalomania and stupidity on the citizens of Western Australia and is opposed to the Commonwealth Government making any revenue concessions in order to ease that burden. As Senator Durack would know, I think, the Commonwealth can abolish royalties in the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Territory. To get rid of the royalty in the rest of the off-shore area would require an amendment to the legislation. After the Bill is passed, the Commonwealth will discuss propositions to get rid of that royalty. I cannot forecast what the outcome of the discussions would be, but the legal situation is that the Commonwealth can act unilaterally in respect of that royalty provided it has a majority in both Houses.

talk.start.para: -In the Senate at 1 o'clock on Thursday I was making some observations about my visit to China in November. Having completed half of my summary remarks, I reached the point where I was referring to the Thirteenth National Congress of the Communist Party of China and the very successful consolidation of the modernisation policy which the Congress has achieved for China. The full Zhao Ziyang speech is important to read. It is important for every senator interested in China-Australia relations to comprehend it fully. It is clearly the most important political document from China in this year of 1987. In our visit, just a week after that speech, it was clear that not only politicians, not only members of the ruling party but also students and members of the public, sat and listened to the speech of Zhao Ziyang on television. There are two fundamental principles which that speech and which the Chinese Government and people in their practices now endorse. One can be summarised as the principle of objective reality and the other as serving the people.

speech.para: The Liberal Party of Australia's delegation, including myself, does not have any wish to interfere with the internal decisions of China. Rather, I make the observation that these two principles do have real meaning in China. They are real guidelines to political decision-making and practice. I note as well that they also have real meaning in Australia.

In Australia we value making decisions based upon objective realities and not some wishful thinking or some ideological tenacity. Also, we in Australia value decisions that serve the people. It is not too simplistic to say that they are two principles that are common touchstones between Australia and China. In some ways, without being too philosophical about it, they can be put in terms of truth and service. I believe that any government in any country at any time will serve its people well and will continue to survive with the confidence of the people if it genuinely represents truth and service; that is, in the terms I originally mentioned, if there is a full grasp of objective reality and of serving the people.

There are some strong contrasts between contemporary China and the China of only 10 or 20 years ago. One of the strongest contrasts is that concerning freedom. During the Cultural Revolution 10 or 20 years ago no one could argue that the people of China were free. They were not free to speak, hardly free to think and not free to share an observation, political or otherwise, about developments in their own country. But in my visits in each of the last three years I have observed an enormous contrast in that the people of China are free: they do say what they think. It is a very rare question indeed that they cannot answer or that they do not wish to answer in a sensible fashion. There is a very sensible basis for discussion of every question in China today which, to anyone who was familiar with China 10 or 20 years ago, was unthinkable then.

Unfortunately, many people-including some of the present leaders of China-were put in gaol for saying what they thought during the Cultural Revolution or for making the mildest criticism of the then leadership or of the leftist policies that were dominant. The crunch came in October 1976 with the arrest of the Gang of Four. As that news spread spontaneouslyabout China it led to celebrations amongst the people. I have heard many graphic descriptions of the celebrations on that famous night in October 1976, when all fireworks were exploded. Not one unexploded firework was left in any of the cities of China. All beer and spirits were consumed and the people stayed up all night to celebrate the end of the leftist regime. Such was the spontaneity and the comprehensiveness of that celebration that when considered together with other bearings on fuller analyses of Chinese politics, I am confident-along with many international observers-that the Cultural Revolution will never be repeated in China. The people wanted to cheer the end of dishonesty, duplicity and hypocrisy and they wanted release to freedom. They wanted to be able to think for themselves and to share their thoughts with others. I still regard it as something of a miracle that we have had such a transformation towards freedom in the largest country of the world.

Some Western cynics may well put the view that students were arrested 12 months ago-in December 1986. A few academics advocating Western style democracy were demoted from their positions. But I fully recognise that, when I talk about freedom, it is not a freedom for every political idea to be advocated to the people of China as an alternative to the Government's main guidelines for political development of China. There is not an acceptance of Western democracy or of a polarised opposition to the Government's policies. There is an ability for individuals to think, to speak and to answer questions, but there is not pretence that China is advocating a Western style democracy: let every country decide its politics for itself.

There are four aspects of this freedom to which I wish to refer. The first concerns the Christian churches. As an Australian Christian, I have been aware of the suffering of Christians wrongly persecuted and misunderstood for their genuine faith and personal commitment. When I first visited China in 1968, all churches were banned. Not one church was open; there was no public worship. The churches had been expropriated by the leftist groups and were being used as centres for Red Guard revolutionary groups, storehouses and places for repairing machinery and cars. But it is genuinely a wonderful observation to me that those churches have now all been re-opened. No one can put forward evidence now of any church that existed before the Cultural Revolution that has not had the capacity to open again. I believe, but I do not know the situation as intimately, that the same can be said for other religions-Islam, Buddhism, Taoism and some others.

In China today there are 4,000 Protestant churches, 3,000 of which existed before the cultural revolution and 1,000 having been added as new centres of worship since the 1976 end to the 10 lost years. The churches that suffered damage at the hands of the leftists have been compensated by direct financial grants from the Chinese Government. Those grants have been put to good effect in the full repair and the extension of buildings, and the churches are flourishing. In addition to the four million members of the Protestant church, which is the church under the governance of the Christian China Council and the so-called three `self' movements-self-governing, self-propagating and self-financing-there is also the Catholic church, which has slightly more members and it has also had all of its churches restored. The Protestant church has 11 active and growing theological colleges one of which, in Nanjing, is a national college, and there are some 600 students in training. The churches have observed that this is an insufficient number to meet the needs of their congregations but they are glad that their membership has every opportunity to grow and expand freely in China.

I think Western churches have a lot to learn from the experiences of Chinese Christians. In addition to the formal churches there are many informal home churches, some of which are in full communion with the 4,000 Protestant churches I have mentioned and some of which, due to distance and other reasons, are not.

In 1968 I stayed at the Fu Tan University in Shanghai, which was closed down. Lectures were suspended, students were sent to the countryside and lecturers, professors and vice-chancellors were all dismissed. The universities were in the hands of Red Guard leftist revolutionaries. But now the universities have fully re-opened and are flourishing and developing. Their best graduates are able to apply for study in overseas universities and generally there is a gaining of international standards, to the benefit of China, throughout Chinese universities.

I refer, thirdly, to minorities. There are some 100 minority languages in China. I have been able to visit minority peoples in Sinjiang, the Uighur and the Kazakh people, who are mostly Islamic people on the western fringe of China, above Tibet and below Mongolia. I have also been able to visit, most recently, Yunnan, where there are 26 minority language groups. It is my observation that, consistent with the open door policy of China with regard to international affairs, China has adopted a multicultural approach to these minority peoples. They are encouraged to retain their languages, they are encouraged to have minority language and cultural institutes with research and teaching facilities and the rights of minority peoples are guaranteed, consistent with the national objectives of China. It is my observation that China, of all countries, most approximates the multicultural policies that have been established in Australia for a decade or so. There are many autonomous provinces where a greater degree of freedom is given to minority peoples in provincial government.

There has been a blossoming of a free market whereby the produce of individuals and small companies can be sold on an open market for whatever price the market can sustain. This was unheard of 20 years ago when the leadership of China was accused of being on the capitalist road. There is a higher take home real income for Chinese citizens and there is a concentration on consumer goods in the market-place. Televisions, motorbikes, pianos and the like are being sold to members of the public who are hungry to see their own families enjoy and prosper with consumer goods. Films are published in China that promote market economics and decisions in local management. Religious groups, universities, minority language groups and the market-place all have evidence of a complete transformation towards freedom in China.

I wish to refer briefly to Tibet. Exaggerated and, at times, misinformed and hostile Press coverage has been given to the demonstrations in September and October this year. These hostile Press reports have raised a potential area of misunderstanding between China and Western countries, including Australia. However, the Chinese Embassy in Canberra through its Ambassador, Zhang Zai, in a letter to the Canberra Times written by the counsellor at the Embassy, Huo Junduo, and in a four or five page circulated statement by the Ambassador, has corrected this misinformation. Undoubtedly both the Government and the Opposition in Australia recognise Tibet as being an autonomous province of China. It is clear that the demonstrations were by a small minority of Buddhist monks in Lhasa only. They were timed to coincide with the Dalai Lama's visit to the United States Congress. The Chinese call this small group `splittists', those with the romantic notion that Tibet can be split away from China. I understand that this has not led in any part of the world to any persistent misinterpretation of Tibet being part of China.

Last week the Parliamentary Library issued a current affairs paper. It gave a considerable amount of information about Tibet and indicated the developments in China over the last 20 years, especially since 1959.

I wish to emphasise the education exchange between China and Australia. With regard to English language programs, I am convinced that Australia is the best place for Chinese to gain full proficiency in English. I welcome the development that 10,000 Chinese will be studying English in Australia next year. This is a very marked increase on 1986 and replaces almost an absence of Chinese students studying English in the preceding years. Australia can assist Chinese students in this way as it has assisted the students of South East Asia over the last 40 years of the Colombo Plan. It is essential that we ensure that the good foundations that presently exist are maintained and that we do not short change the standard of the courses given to these Chinese students.

With regard to post-graduate joint programs, there is also enormous potential for jointly supervised post-graduate students taking degrees in Chinese universities but with one or two years experience in association with an Australian university. Problems arise in English in terms of a cultural bridge and good selection being followed. We should see much larger numbers of students in every field of study coming to Australia. I look forward to the way that Australia will contribute and also what Australian students will gain by similar studies within China.

I refer to Australian investment in China. It is not just a question of Australian trade having grown considerably with China, but also direct Australian investment in which, through joint ventures and in other ways, Australian technical knowledge and industrial experience can be put to the mutual advantage of Australia and China. There are excellent opportunities in terms of the open door that is given especially to Australia. We need to understand that Australia has to genuinely resolve to understand the political foundations of this investment and industrial development and to be genuinely concerned for the middle and long term success of the enterprises for which this investment is made. It is of fundamental importance that politicians such as ourselves ensure that the foundation on which this investment is based is firmly maintained.

Many Australians are now visiting the various provinces of China and increasing numbers of Chinese delegations are coming here. We must ensure that those visits are self-disciplined, that they are not just a familiarisation tour but that they achieve constructive results and, in the end, genuinely serve the peoples of our two countries.

I conclude by again emphasising that Australia-China relations have an exciting future. Over the next 20 years, or even the next 50 years, we will be able to point to increasing achievements in our relationship in all of the fields to which I have referred in my brief remarks. Australians should be stimulated by these good prospects to work not only for the present year and the next five years but also for the next 50 years towards establishing the best relations we can between China and Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, you may recall that on 26 November 1987 in the committee stage of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 I raised the matter of the sewerage rates ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory and, in particular, section 5. I pointed out that in a number of commercial buildings the occupants are paying the sewerage levy in relation to toilets that are in the public area of the buildings and they are also rated on their shops as though they contained flushing units in them when they do not. I shall not go over the whole of the statements that I made on that evening but I remind the Senate that on that occasion the Minister who was then in the chamber, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, said:

speech.para: I will take that question on notice.
Subsequently, when I continued further with the proposition I was putting, he said:
I will ensure that he-
he was referring to the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory-
acts very quickly to give Senator Reid an answer.

I have not had any response from either Senator Evans or the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown). It is a question which those who are involved with this problem wish to have answered. I ask the Minister to give this matter his attention. The Minister seems to have plenty of time to give his attention to a casino and the like and his rhetoric would indicate that he is concerned about the welfare of the private sector. He seems to imply that he recognises that it is necessary to diversify the economy of the Australian Capital Territory so that it is not totally dependent on the public sector. This is just one significant matter to which we have had no response whatever.

I have raised other matters and I refer, in particular, to the future of the aviation college which is completely within Senator Evans's responsibility; it is under the administration of his Department. As honourable senators would know, some time ago the Joint Committee on Public Works approved the college being developed at the site of the Watson High School, which is now closed, and that work should have been commenced. Over a considerable period the Department of Aviation looked at possible sites and determined that the structure should be built in the Australian Capital Territory. It is important that we acquire as many of these sorts of facilities as possible. It is not just a question of being acquisitive and of having them located here. This is the national capital and institutions of this kind ought to be based here.

I concede that there is good reason for the Maritime College not being situated in an inland capital but there is no reason for the aviation college not to be located here when it has been determined by this Government that it should be. The Department of Transport and Communications was given just five days to produce a feasibility study relating to the college being moved to Launceston. However, the Minister is still not able to give us an answer as to where the college will be. If the college does not go ahead soon it will not, in any place, be ready to commence when it ought to be. It is another example of the Minister and the Government having complete disregard for the national capital, its future and what goes on here.

There are a number of matters relating to the Government's administration of Canberra to which I have referred from time to time. Mr President, you will have heard all of them, having sat in, of course, on the adjournment when I have raised them. The third edition of the journal of the Master Builders Association (MBA) of the ACT published today raises some matters which it puts under the heading `Administration (mis) Manages Territory Taxation'. The only way in which I would differ with the MBA is that I would say that it is the Government that mismanages these matters, not the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories although, perhaps, that is a matter that could be debated. The reality is that there are some anomalies that need to be dealt with.

I refer to the new tax which is to be imposed by way of penalty on the late stamping of a contract for the sale of a property. Any contract not stamped within 30 days will acquire a 20 per cent penalty. There are a number of reasons why it may not be feasible or reasonable for a contract to be stamped within 30 days, although there can be no doubt that a contract must be stamped before the settlement takes place. However, the requirement that it be stamped within 30 days can only be a revenue raising measure, especially when a penalty is imposed at the level I have indicated. I think that the Minister should explain to us the reason for this imposition. This is especially so because I frequently get complaints about the length of time that the Department takes to approve commercial activities that people want to get on with in the Australian Capital Territory. It seems that it all works one way when revenue raising is concerned but not the other way when it comes to private enterprise wanting to get on with its activities. The editor of the MBA journal states:

The logic of this legislation is so nonsensical and oppressive that it should be rescinded and those responsible for it should be found a job in the parks and gardens blackberry eradication program where excessive enthusiasm will be of benefit to the community.
That might be drawing a long bow in some respects but I think it indicates the sort of frustration that the private sector feels when dealing with government in the ACT.

Another matter mentioned in this journal-one which I have mentioned frequently-concerns payroll tax in the ACT. The Minister was very vocal at the time of the last Budget about the need for the ACT to pay its own way. Of course, he explained this in terms of the number of local taxes which were increased at the time. The fact is that until recently we paid payroll tax at the same rate as New South Wales and adjustments in favour of the employer were made to match those in New South Wales. That is no longer the case. We are now out of step with New South Wales in that the payroll exemption in that State has risen to $400,000, while ours remain as it was about 18 months ago. Of course, this means that any business considering coming to the ACT may well consider setting up in Queanbeyan because, in fact, it would be considerably cheaper to do so. The Government ought to look at giving private enterprise in the ACT the same terms and conditions in regard to the payment of payroll tax, as apply to our near neighbour.

A further matter which this journal deals with-I have a file going back to the beginning of the group apprenticeship scheme with the Master Builders Association-is payroll tax on the employment of apprentices by the MBA. Other such schemes in Australia are exempt from the payment of payroll tax. But here the MBA pays payroll tax on second-year, third-year and fourth-year apprentices. This means that the master builders are not able to employ as many apprentices as they would be able to if they were exempt. Considering the very high youth unemployment rate in the ACT and the need to give young people the opportunity to attain skills, it is important that this scheme be given the widest possible opportunity to operate. The scheme has worked well. Over 100 apprentices have graduated through it. At present there are 98 apprentices in the scheme. The other night I was privileged to attend the graduation at which a number of apprentices received awards for a variety of successful activities in their apprenticeship courses. But it does not seem possible to get through to the Government that the ACT scheme ought not to be treated differently from similar schemes in the States. There seems to be some desire to make profit out of the fact that apprentices are being given an opportunity to acquire skills in the building industry here.

The other and quite amazing thing, which I did not know until I read this paper, is that the master builders are now required to pay payroll tax on their employees grouped together within the group apprenticeship scheme. Let me make quite clear what I am talking about. Until now payroll tax in the ACT has been administered by the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury. Under the new financial arrangements it is being passed to the ACT administration. The Government, in its wisdom in handing this over from one to another, has decided to capitalise on the existing situation of one payroll tax number for the Master Builders Association and its employees and is now insisting that the same number be used for the group apprenticeship scheme, which is a totally separate scheme. It ought to have a separate number as it has in the past. The Master Builders Association as such is not an employer. The scheme is a group scheme whereby a number of people gather together to give young people an opportunity to work in the industry and acquire skills.

This decision will have a significant effect in increasing the amount of payroll tax payable. It really is incomprehensible to me that anyone could dream up such a means of ripping money out of the system for this purpose. As is stated in the paper, not only do we tax apprentices in a way in which they are not taxed elsewhere, but also we tax a voluntary non-profit body whose aim is to help young people get training and employment. I invite the Minister to have another look at the problem and to sort it out very quickly. It is important in particular that the group apprenticeship scheme be exempt from payroll tax. It is important for our private sector that payroll tax be paid at the same rate as in New South Wales. The linking of the tax on the master builders with the group apprenticeship scheme is an anomaly that ought not to be allowed to continue.

Another matter relevant to the private sector in Canberra is a matter in which you, Mr President, may be able to offer some assistance. The tourist industry in Canberra is particularly important to us and to the number of jobs available. There is a rumour that the new Parliament House may be open for only five days a week instead of the seven days that this building and other buildings in Canberra are open so that tourists may be able to see through them during the week and weekends. If it is to be open only five days a week-I do not know which five days it would be-I would regard it as a disaster for the tourist industry in Canberra if it were to be closed on Saturday and Sunday. I would also regard it as totally unacceptable if it were to be closed on sitting days. So I cannot imagine what is being considered. The building must be open seven days a week. What has to be determined is when it will be open. The tourist industry cannot be allowed to wait until May of next year to find out what will happen. It needs to make plans for bringing people to Canberra, for package tours to the national capital.

The Government has been telling us for years that the Parliament House will promote itself; that there is no need for any special promotion of Canberra; that it will attract tourists; that all we need to do is wait until it is open and the tourists will come. If the industry does not know when it will be open, in order to make plans, it is put in an impossible situation. As I said, it must be open on Saturdays and Sundays, otherwise it will be a complete disaster and very harmful.

What are the arrangements for the opening? There are people in Canberra who want to make arrangements for that day. They want to be able to encourage people to come here to be part of the group of people who will line the route to the new Parliament House. They want to organise barbecues, food stalls and other activities. They want to know that the building will be open after 11 o'clock so that people can look at it. It is not possible to run a tourist industry when these matters have not been decided or disclosed. I do not know whether nobody cares about how other people go about their business, or what the problem is. But the fact is that the tourist industry in Canberra does not have the information it needs to make arrangements for this very important event in Canberra.

It is not just the private sector in Canberra which is concerned about what will happen on 9 May and thereafter; the airlines want to know what will happen. You would know, Mr President, that the timetables for planes into and out of Canberra are such that flights are few and far between. If thousands of people are to come to Canberra for that event, the airlines need to know what the arrangements are so that they can do something about scheduling flights to and from Canberra around 9 May. Additional traffic will be expected, and additional aircraft and additional parking for aircraft will be needed. When will the building be open to the public on or after 9 May? Will it be open seven days a week, as it must be, and when will we know what is happening?

All of these matters which I have touched on tonight, principally tax matters but also this matter affecting the tourist industry in Canberra, are important. They might in themselves appear to be quite small and insignificant. Lumped together, they indicate to me that the Government is long on rhetoric and short on doing the things that matter as far as the private sector and the Australian Capital Territory are concerned.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Reid did not raise this issue with me prior to the adjournment debate tonight. However, I am able to tell her that there was a proposal that the new Parliament House be open only five days a week, from Wednesday to Sunday, during the initial moving-in period. She will be pleased to know that the Speaker and I agreed today that the new Parliament House will be open seven days a week from 10 May. speech.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I recognise the lateness of the hour, and I shall endeavour to be as brief as possible. I wish to raise three quite separate matters, all relating to people I care about. Thus, they are important to their daily concerns. The first relates to the people in the municipality of New Norfolk in Tasmania. It is a matter about which my colleague Senator Calvert has also made representations to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans). I refer to a letter which I have received from the Council Clerk of the municipality, because I think it sets out the matter as succinctly as is possible. He refers in his letter to a recent incident which he says has exposed Telecom Australia to some criticism. The incident revolves around the desire of Telecom to remove two public telephone services from country areas in the New Norfolk municipality. The decision to remove the service was taken by an administrator within Telecom and conveyed verbally to the Council. The Council Clerk was advised by the Telecom employee that he had no intention of confirming the conversation in writing, as to do so was often a source of adverse publicity for his organisation. The Council Clerk stated that there were some facets of the incidents to which Council objected. They are:

speech.para: (1) The lack of courtesy displayed by Telecom in this instance in failing to approach Council on an official basis purely to avoid publicity which may be adverse.
In this instance it has worked to the contrary and considerable public criticism has been generated by the tactics adopted.
(2) The policies which are used by Telecom to decide which public telephone services to remove.

The letter states that the Council Clerk was concerned that a national policy exists which dictates that a public telephone service will remain only in those areas where sufficient funds are generated by that service to cover its maintenance. He went on to say that he found that quite unacceptable-as I do. Obviously, if we are looking at public telephones we are looking at what is a very basic public service. Inevitably there are occasions when such public services have to be subsidised by higher revenue-generating operations in other places. If Telecom's logic were to be applied across the board we would only have telephone boxes where a major amount of revenue was generated. That, obviously, will not help people in sparsely populated areas such as the municipality of New Norfolk. I simply ask the Minister to see whether the policies being applied by Telecom are fair to these small sparsely populated municipalities which need public phone boxes, and to see what can be done as soon as possible for the citizens in the New Norfolk municipality.

The second matter I wish to raise relates to a petition which Senator Devlin tabled today in the Parliament. It was a petition from 2,150 petitioners requesting the Government to reverse its decision to close the Medicare agency operated by the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd (APPM) Council for its work force. I have also been approached by the work force of APPM in Tasmania to see what can be done to save the Medicare agency. Mr President, no doubt you are not aware that the APPM mill is some considerable distance from the nearest shopping area with a Medicare office. As a result, a Medicare agency has been operating at the woodchip and particle board mill for some time. It services about 900 employees and their families.

This agency is located extremely conveniently for the work force. Employees would otherwise have to go a long distance to a Medicare office. The employees live in fairly scattered rural communities. The current arrangement is that an employee of APPM processes medical claims both for the company's medical benefits scheme and also for Medicare. The company receives a commission for the Medicare claims process. The company understands that the arrangements will be changed on 31 March 1988 and this will lead, as I said, to great inconvenience for the workers and presumably to additional costs for the Commonwealth as the volume of claims from this number of people inevitably must lead to an extra employee in the Devonport office. I ask the Minister to intervene urgently to save this Medicare agency leading to, I believe, a net saving to the Commonwealth in place of the proposal for change.

The final matter I wish to raise is also important to people I care about; that is, the Government's decision announced just recently concerning the defence service home loans scheme, which has been a matter of great concern to the veteran and service communities. I have raised this matter many times in this place. Senator Reynolds tabled a petition with several thousand signatures just a few weeks ago and I have also tabled a petition from many thousands of petitioners. The policy of the Liberal Party of Australia has been that the private sector should be involved in the defence service home loans scheme and there should be immediate action to reduce the long delays in the scheme.

I welcome the fact that the Government has taken action in both these areas, that there will be involvement of the private sector in the new defence service home loans scheme and that there is a commitment to stop the long backlog immediately. I also welcome the fact that the Government has seen fit to introduce portability into the scheme. I have been pushing that for a long time. It is something which is going to be of great importance not just to service people but also to the taxpayers of Australia. It makes very good sense that this portability will allow service people to take their loans with them as they are posted from one part of Australia to another.

I recognise that Senator Gietzelt has spent a great deal of time over the past years trying to get the interest of the private sector into the defence service home loans scheme. I believe that his proposals had a fatal flaw. It is something which still has not been addressed by the Government's recent announcement. I want to draw attention to that now. It is the fact that service men and women who enlisted after 15 May 1985 cannot become eligible for defence service home loans. So we still have two classes of servicemen; those who become eligible after six years of service and those who can never become eligible. I urge the Government to remedy this. It should have been remedied in the review which has just taken place. It is quite unconscionable to have servicemen serving side by side under two totally different conditions of service. Equally, the Government has a real interest in having more people in the scheme.

I understand from those who expressed interest, when Senator Gietzelt advertised for expressions of interest in the private sector, that because the cut off date in May 1985 had been implemented there was, inevitably, going to be a gradual reduction in the number of people who would be eligible for a loan. That will mean that there will be fewer people in the scheme. It will mean that for any private sector involvement the overhead costs per loan will become greater. Inevitably it will become a very expensive scheme to operate. It will be much fairer to all parties if there is a continuing flow of new people coming into the scheme as their eligibility is decided. I believe that the Government has missed out on something very important. I strongly urge it to look again at the matter.

The Senate has heard from me and from others about the discontent throughout Australia. The petitions that have been circulating ask the Government not just to preserve the existing scheme, but also to amend the scheme to increase the amount of the loan, to speed up the processing of the loans and to widen the eligibility to include all servicemen by way of recognition of their service to Australia. The Government has promised to speed up the processing of the loans. It has agreed to change the scheme so that people will be able to borrow more than the $25,000 for which they will get subsidised interest rates. I welcome that. It is a very sensible decision.

Let us not forget that in March 1987 we had 2,500 applications which had been approved and which were awaiting completion. In other words, we had an enormous log-jam. These people have been waiting anxiously to find out what was going to happen to the loans that were already approved. talk.start.para: â€”In Question Time on the last day of sitting, that is, Thursday, 10 December, I asked a question of the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) concerning overseas visits during 1984-85 by officers of the Australian Electoral Commission. I am pleased to see that the Minister is on duty in the chamber tonight. I gave him prior notice that I would be asking some follow-up questions tonight. My question last Thursday related to the fact that a colleague in the other place, the honourable member for Moreton, Mr Donald Cameron, asked a question on notice last year in which he requested details from all Government Ministers of all overseas trips made during 1984-85 by the employees of their respective departments and all statutory authorities. I asked Senator Ray whether he could advise the Senate whether the information provided by the then responsible Minister in relation to overseas trips made by officers of the Australian Electoral Commission was complete and accurate. In response to my question, Senator Ray answered, inter alia:

speech.para: The information given in answer to a question on notice-
that is, Mr Cameron's question-

has, on further examination, been proved to be inaccurate. We are talking about the very early life of the Australian Electoral Commission when two of its officers visited New Zealand to coincide with the holding of the 1984 New Zealand election. This study visit was intended to check features of the New Zealand electoral organisation for the benefit of the new Electoral Commission being established here. The understanding of the Commission officers was that, under Public Service conventions, the visits by Australian Public Service personnel to Papua New Guinea and New Zealand were not regarded as overseas travel . . .

I interpose to say that Papua New Guinea and New Zealand were mentioned as being obvious overseas travel places in the Personnel Management Manual, which I think is the former Public Service Board's manual, which was provided several years before this incident arose. Senator Ray went on to say in his answer:

I agree that those two trips, under any sort of criteria, should have been listed in that particular response. The conclusion that I draw from their omission is that I believe the officers are being truthful when they say that they misunderstood the terms of overseas travel.
I repeat:
they misunderstood the terms of overseas travel.

On my interpretation of the Minister's answer, particularly the latter part to which I have just referred, he attributed the omission of the proper information to the officers who undertook the travel. That is how I interpret the Minister's saying that he believes that the officers are being truthful when they say that they misunderstood the terms of overseas travel. Fourthly, if so, does this mean that a conscious decision was taken to delete them? Fifthly, if so, who took the decision to delete them?
