speech.para: I raise an issue of considerable concern to a significant section of the community; that is, the decision of this Government, with the support, of course, of the Australian Democrats, to impose a tax on testamentary gifts to charities. That has occurred through the operation of section 160y of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Ordinarily, when a person dies, section 160x of the Income Tax Assessment Act operates so that capital gains tax is not payable when an asset is passed from a testator to a beneficiary. What happens is simply that the beneficiary inherits the testator's cost base. If he later sells the asset, he pays capital gains tax calculated on the purchase price paid by the testator and adjusted for inflation. With the indulgence of the Minister, I now seek to have incorporated in Hansard section 160y of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which sets out the position which is of concern to me.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Asset bequeathed to tax-exempt person

160y. (1) A person is a tax-exempt person in relation to the year of income for the purposes of this section if the person is a person whose income of the year of income is exempt from tax by virtue of a relevant exempting provision.
(2) Where-
(a) a person dies on or after 20 September 1985;
(b) an asset that formed part of the estate of the deceased person and was acquired by the deceased person on or after that date has passed to a beneficiary in the estate of the deceased person; and
(c) the beneficiary is a tax-exempt person in relation to the year of income,
section 160x does not apply in respect of the asset but the following provisions of this section have effect.

(3) The asset shall be deemed for the purposes of this Part to have been disposed of by the deceased person, and acquired by the beneficiary, immediately before the death of the person for a consideration equal to the market value of the asset at the date of the death.

(4) If the asset passed from the legal personal representative of the deceased person to the beneficiary, then, on the subsequent disposal of the asset by the beneficiary, the cost base, the indexed cost base or the reduced cost base to the beneficiary of the asset for the purposes of this Part shall include any amount that would, if this section did not apply, have been included in that cost base, indexed cost base or reduced cost base, as the case may be, by virtue of paragraph 160x (3) (b).

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate. It is obvious that this is a special taxing provision for assets bequeathed to a `tax-exempt person' or persons, which, for the present purposes, can be taken to mean charities. The section deems a gift of an asset to a charity to be a disposal at market value by the testator to the charity, immediately before the testator's death. The practical effect of the section is to make a testator's estate liable to capital gains tax when an asset is bequeathed to a charity. While this is not a tax directly on the charity itself, that is the effect this will have. The truly disgraceful aspect is, however, that this has not occurred by accident. The Government is fully aware that the tax will affect charities.

speech.para: One of two events must occur under this iniquitous law. Let us say, for instance, first, the testator wills an asset to the Royal Blind Society and leaves substantial funds to relatives. The Royal Blind Society will take the asset but the estate will be required to pay capital gains tax on it before there can be a distribution of funds to the relatives. Quite clearly, if the gift of an asset to a charity means willing relatives an immense capital gains tax liability, few people making a will will do so. It is a major disincentive to leave assets to charities.

The second possibility is that there may not be enough funds in the estate to pay the capital gains tax liability. In this case there is no alternative but to sell the asset which was meant for the charity, pay the capital gains tax out of the proceeds of the sale and then pass whatever is left to the charity. In either case, one thing is clear: that is that this Government is prepared to take its cut at the expense of charities such as the Blind Society, the Red Cross and the churches. Inevitably, if the Government introduces a tax which has the effect of reducing the funds donated to charities, that tax will eventually be paid for by the poorest people in the country.

It should be remembered that governments and courts have accorded charities a special place in the general law and in revenue laws because for centuries they have recognised that charities ultimately operate for the public benefit. To be legally recognised as a charity, an organisation must be for the relief of aged, impotent and poor people; or, secondly, for the advancement of education; or, thirdly, for the advancement of religion; or, fourthly, any other purpose beneficial to the community not falling under any of the preceding three leads. No doubt Senator Ray would know that governments as far back as Queen Elizabeth I have taken very special steps to see that charities operate as efficiently as possible, because ultimately it would be for the advancement of the community as a whole. In present times, State Attorneys-General are obliged to ensure the proper and honest administration of charitable trusts. The Federal Government, for its own avaricious purposes, now attacks an important source of wealth for charities and in turn the poor, the old, the deaf, the blind, the disabled, education and religion. One need only make a casual flick through the pages of the Australian Law Journal to see the number of charities which try to attract testamentary gifts to see what an important source of income they are.

I have spoken with the Red Cross in Western Australia and have been informed that an average 75 per cent of the value of legacies to the Red Cross in Western Australia is made up of property and/or shares and hence is liable for capital gains tax before it passes to that organisation. Typically, it is the largest testamentary gifts which contain property and shares. talk.start.para: â€”Of course, the 75 per cent estimation will vary from year to year, but I leave it to honourable senators to make their own calculations and assessment of the importance of these gifts to the Red Cross in my State alone. I also remind them that this is only one State division of one charity. There are many others. Any government which claims any sympathy or compassion with the poor and needy would repeal this law. Of course, we could expect little help from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of the present Government. He has already, quite deliberately, tried to impose the fringe benefits tax on charities. He said quite openly in the House of Representatives that he thought that fringe benefits tax should apply to charities. He would have introduced it-as we know-into this House had it not been for the actions of Opposition senators. The Treasurer has stated that not to impose tax on the capital gain accrued on assets bequeathed to charities would remove it from the tax base. I ask the Treasurer how this differs from income tax deductions for donations to charities. In the case of income earned, there is a potential liability to income tax at the end of the year. If, however, the taxpayer donates his income to a charity, the Government allows a taxation deduction and the potential tax is lost, much to the benefit of charities.

speech.para: In the case of an asset, there is an accrued capital gain which is potentially subject to capital gains tax if sold. The Government says that it cannot afford to miss out on this gain if the asset is passed to a charity. One might ask: Why is it any different for the Government to forgo the capital gains tax from the Government forgoing the income tax by allowing a deduction? By clearly preferring the interests of the Australian Taxation Office, the Treasurer shows where his priorities lie. One would hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would take some action here. He said at the last election that he wanted to end child poverty by 1990. If this promise is to be regarded as anything more than election froth and bubble and the Prime Minister's word is to carry any weight, he ought to remove this iniquitous section of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is my belief that charities are better than governments at dealing not only with child poverty but with all forms of social evils. The Government therefore ought to do all in its power to induce people to bequeath gifts to charities for the poor and less fortunate, not to discourage them. It could make no better start than by allowing testators to make bequests to charities free of the fear that they will leave their relatives a capital gains tax liability.

I have gone through this speech reasonably quickly because I have no doubt that Senator Ray will not spontaneously tell me that the Government is going to announce the introduction of legislation tomorrow to remove the capital gains tax. But I hope he takes this on board and that the Government considers and contemplates it in the very near future.

Half the party, including Senator Bjelke-Petersen, went off to see Waterloo, and Mr Cameron and I had morning tea with an official of the Australian Electoral Commission. Mr Cameron wanted to know what he was doing there. He was in fact observing an election.

Senator Short raised a number of questions. He asked who the officers were. They were Mr Nugent, who is now, and I think was then, Electoral Officer, for New South Wales, and Mr Emmerson, who is Deputy Electoral Officer for Queensland. Senator Short was probably correct to say that the answer that I gave on Thursday could be misinterpreted, because I was answering in two parts. I was talking about the officers who took the trip and then about the officers who had failed to give the correct answer-two entirely separate groups. If I had paragraphed Hansard better, that would have been very clear. It was not those two individuals concerned who failed to give the correct answer. Senator Short went on to ask another series of questions. He asked who authorised the answer. I understand Professor Hughes has taken responsibility for authorising that answer.

I might add some additional information which I did not have when the matter was raised at Question Time. The study trip of the two Australian Electoral Commission officers to New Zealand took place from 7 to 17 July 1984. At that time the Government Overseas Visits Committee was still in operation and was required to approve overseas travel. It was not, however, required to approve travel to either Papua New Guinea or New Zealand. For this reason a mistaken assumption was made that for the purposes of Mr Cameron's inquiry New Zealand was not included in the normal category of overseas visits. I take on board Senator Short's reference to the manual describing what an overseas trip is.

The Electoral Commission did advise the Government on 19 December 1985 of the visit to New Zealand and the visit of another officer to Antarctica. At the time of the advice, December 1985, the Australian Electoral Commission commented that these, however, `do not constitute overseas trips within the accepted meaning of the term'. At 19 December 1985 that was its view, so it was not prompted by Mr Cameron's later inquiries. It had actually stated in a report to the Government that it did not regard them as overseas trips. Therefore, I think the Commission's bona fides are reasonable.

The two officers produced a report on their assessment of the New Zealand electoral procedures. I will make a copy of that report available to any honourable senator who may be interested. Senator Short went on to ask whether the original draft included the New Zealand trip. I do not know, but I will endeavour to find out. The next two or three questions would be predicated on the answer to that question, so I cannot help with the answers to those questions.

Senator Short asked when the Minister previous to the previous Special Minister of State knew about these matters. I will have to make inquiries. Senator Short asked when I first found out about it. I was dropped a very large hint when we were discussing other matters, I guess, when Senator Short wanted me to respond in part. So the first time Senator Short raised the matter with me was the first time I had ever heard of it. On the question of why the correction was not put to Parliament earlier, again I will need to make some inquiries in that regard. I think I have covered the matters I can. I will get the extra information, if I can, by the end of the week. I am quite happy, by the way, to give a lot more information on trips by electoral commissioners. They have made about five or six in the three or four years of their existence. I think that their examining of trends overseas is very valuable. I do not think they are making a meal out of it, and just taking junkets.

talk.start.para: â€”I am not suggesting that.

â€”No, I do not think so. I do not think the trip to Antarctica by Mr Maley, for instance, could in any way be described as a junket. I think only one or two trips are planned for the next couple of years by officers of the Commission.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the honourable senator's question as as follows:

answer.para: The Australian Government is not directly promoting kangaroo products overseas for the Bicentenary. talk.start.para: â€”On 23 September 1987 (Hansard, page 561), Senator Macklin asked me a question without notice concerning the possible establishment of further private, fee-charging institutions and the eligibility of such institutions for government subsidies, Austudy allowances and research grants. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Government is aware of several proposals for the establishment of private tertiary institutions, including those such as the Bond University and Kyoto Institute of Technology as well as others involving various forms of association between new private institutions and publicly funded institutions.

The Commonwealth recognises that developments such as these are primarily matters for the States. Commonwealth grants will not be available to such institutions. In the case of the Bond University, the proposed joint venture by the Bond Corporation and the Japanese EIE Development Company received Foreign Investment Review Board approval on the understanding that no requests would be made for Commonwealth support.

Senator Macklin also asked whether students at private tertiary institutions would be eligible for AUSTUDY allowances. Courses are approved for AUSTUDY purposes only if they are wholly or substantially public funded, whether by the Commonwealth, State or Northern Territory Governments. There is no proposal for further extension of AUSTUDY eligibility to courses in the private sector.

Senator Macklin also asked whether academics and departments in private institutions would be eligible for grants from the new Australian Research Council (ARC). That will be a matter on which the ARC will provide advice when it has been established.

The Government recognises the importance of these issues in the context of its policies for the long-term development of tertiary education. Accordingly, the Task Force established to prepare a Policy Discussion Paper on higher education issues will be addressing the place of private institutions established under State auspices within the overall framework of higher education provision, and the relationship between public and private institutions.

answer.para: As Senator Ryan stated, there is no reduction in the Government's commitment to improving the position of women in employment, education and training.

talk.start.para: â€”On 26 November 1987 (Hansard, page 2489), Senator Panizza asked me the following question without notice:

answer.para: I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the answer he gave me regarding the import duty on diesel injection pump parts and turbo charger parts. I quote his reply:

Importers of replacement parts used for diesel injection pumps and turbo chargers not manufactured in Australia will continue to have the opportunity to import their goods at 2 per cent duty irrespective of the proposed tariff changes referred to by the honourable senator.

My questions are: What exactly does he mean by `have the opportunity to import their goods at 2 per cent'? Secondly, is it automatic that those specialised parts not manufactured in Australia will remain at 2 per cent? Or does it mean that the importer will have to reapply to obtain that concession, thereby causing those importers to pay the higher 25 per cent rate of duty until the decision is made and then apply for a refund?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The honourable Senator did not quote my reply in full as I went onto explain in my initial reply to him that the opportunity to continue to import their goods at 2 per cent duty would be subject to the normal provisions of the Tariff Concession System administered by the Australian Customs. Importers of parts currently dutiable at 2 per cent, but which are due to increase on 1 January 1988 on the introduction of the Harmonized Tariff, may therefore apply for tariff concessions orders if it can be established that the imported parts do not compete with any parts produced in Australia.
Under the existing tariff, parts of goods may incur the duty rate applicable to the whole good, however, such is not the case with the Harmonized Tariff.

In the Harmonized Tariff special provision is made for parts for certain goods some of which are produced in Australia. It cannot be assumed that tariff concessions will be issued for all parts that previously attracted 2 per cent duty.
Importers have been encouraged to lodge applications for tariff concessions as early as possible in order that the legislative requirements may be met for a 1 January 1988 commencement date.
Where applications have not been finalised by 1 January 1988, normal duties will apply with refunds being obtainable when and if a tariff concession is granted.
Importers are aware that concessions may not be issued retrospectively. Consequently, concession applications submitted after 1 January 1988 may only operate from date of lodgment.
